2.US Daily Economic Notes - Two key contributors to core inflation may be stabilizing 17 May 2016 (1 page/ 226 kb)
Commentary for Wednesday: The April headline CPI (+0.4% vs. +0.1%) was modestly stronger than expected due to a 3.4% gain in energy prices, the largest monthly increase since February 2013 (4.5%). This had the effect of raising the year-over-year growth rate by two tenths to 1.1%. However, core consumer prices (+0.2% vs. +0.1%) were in line with consensus expectations, and this resulted in a one-tenth deceleration in the year-over-year growth rate to 2.1%. The details of the latest CPI report provide preliminary evidence that core inflation may level out as rents and medical prices, which together make up 50% of the core CPI, are possibly in the midst of stabilizing. 
CPI shelter costs, which have a 42% weighting in the core, increased 0.3% in April, which kept the year-over-year growth rate steady at 3.2%. This is essentially where rental inflation has been tracking since last September. There are two main subcomponents of CPI shelter, rent of primary residence and owners' equivalent rent (OER). The latter has a little over three times the weight of the former. The six-month annualized growth rate of OER peaked at 3.4% last September and has since decreased to 3.0% as of April. We expect rental prices to decelerate slightly further over the back half of the year as more housing supply comes on line, putting upward pressure on the rental vacancy rate. As the chart below illustrates, one measure of the apartment vacancy rate has already begun to rise. This makes sense as multi-family housing starts increased by 397k last year, the largest addition of multi-unit supply since 1988. Rental inflation is responsible for roughly 25% of the improvement in the year-over-year growth rate of the core CPI since last April. Thus, if rents continue to decelerate as we anticipate, they will exert modest downward pressure on core CPI inflation. 
Medical care services, which had contributed nearly 10 basis points (bps) to the 40-bp annual increase in the core CPI over the 12 months ending last March, have also begun to cool. While this series was up 0.3% in April, the year-over-year growth rate fell to five tenths to 3.1%. Medical care services prices accelerated rapidly over the last couple of quarters partly due to the "doc fix" bill signed by Congress last April, which set the growth rate of Medicare reimbursements to physicians at 0.5% per annum through 2019. The six-month annualized change of medical care services prices surged to an eight-year high this February (5%), but has since declined to 3.6% as of April. It is likely that the year-over-year growth rate of medical care prices will stabilize over the next couple of quarters. In short, two key contributors to the pickup in core inflation over the past 12 months may be stabilizing. With the economic outlook uncertain and core inflation quiescent, there is little pressure on monetary policymakers to raise interest rates in the near term. 
 
 
3.Alpha Alert - Fed messaging, G20 and the USD
 
++  The market may recently have been better than the FOMC at forecasting Fed policy longer-term, but never underestimate the Fed's capacity to forecast what they themselves will do in the next meeting or two!
 
The headlines could not be clearer.  "WILLIAMS SAYS GRADUAL MEANS 2-3 RATE HIKES THIS YEAR AND 3-4 HIKES NEXT YEAR".   Williams is hardly a hawk, and yet the world he describes includes between 5 and 7 rate hikes to the end of 2017, when the market is pricing in less than 2 rate hikes over the same period.  The Fed has some explaining to do, to a deeply skeptical market as to how they think they can tighten this much with growth struggling to track at 2%.
 
The explanation should run as follows:  Yellen has told us she thinks the current equilibrium real funds rate is a very low zero currently. This implies a nominal equilibrium funds rate at 1.5% - 1.75%.  We are some five 25bp rate hikes away from a neutral nominal funds rate. 
 
In this context, the Fed is coming from a view that:  i)  policy is extremely accommodative currently inclusive of  a  view of a very low equilibrium real rate now; and ii) even with tightening like Williams describes, this only gets the Fed to zero real rates in ~18 months, assuming inflation does not rise much in the interim! If inflation rises even moderately, the Fed will be chasing their tail, needing to tighten by more to get to ‘neutral’.   In addition, the longer-term  neutral funds rate is expected to rise over time, a view embedded in the Fed's long-term funds rate projection that has a real 'equlibrium' funds nearer 1.25%. 
 
In the immediate term, the market is deeply skeptical as to: i) whether other Fed officials represent Yellen's view; and  ii) whether the feedback loops from Fed tightening to tighter financial conditions will slow/stop the Fed.  The way Dudley and Rosengren have commented since the April payrolls report suggests there has been no material changes to the dove’s FOMC dots since March, when they strongly coalesced around 2 hikes in 2016, and that 2 hikes in 2016 would still likely be representative of Yellen’s dot.  The view that the feedback loops will stymie the Fed is more realistic argument that will keep the Fed (far?) more dovish than the Fed presumes.  The feedback loops are probably more relevant for a m/t view on the Fed, than the next rate hike.  The feedback loop that officials fear the most  -  China FX instability - is expected to be contained in the summer, and at least through the G20 meeting in Hangzhou in September. China is (whether deliberate or not) providing a window for Fed summer action. 
 
As for tightening in June or July, my personal view on the preconditions for a tightening include: PCE holding up; NFP not showing a pattern of deceleration extending much beyond what we saw in April; and, very broadly financial markets/conditions not least related to China ‘behaving’.  IF these preconditions are met, it should be no surprise to see Janet Yellen speak and drive market expectations to something much closer to the Fed’s view.   In the meantime, there is no point in her saying something until she is pretty sure about the timing of the next move.  As Brett Ryan has noted, Yellen has both the June 6th speech, and a semiannual congressional testimony to flag her views before the June and July meetings.    
 
For the FX market, we expect that the USD will have a solid run in the one month period as and when any tightening becomes more obvious.  Assuming the Fed is in play this summer, USD gains will tend to be broad-based inclusive of G4.  Versus the majors, the DXY should be able to claw its way toward 98 on a summer Fed rate hike, or be close to unchanged if they do not deliver, because risk is tenuous.                                                                                                                                                       No doubt this will be one of the angles discussed at the G20 meeting, where most participants outside Japan will have been delighted by the improved global financial conditions that followed a less strong USD after the February Shanghai meetings.  Wariness will however prevail, given the knowledge that the Fed could so easily disrupt the risk story again.   Ironically only Japan will be looking forward to the FX relief a Fed hike could deliver, IF the yen is not helped by a risk off response! If there is one thing all Central Banks can celebrate, it is that a Fed that 'only' tightens twice this year would likely leave a long gap between a summer hike and a winter hike, where risky asset can recover, albeit only if US politics do not exact their own damage! 
 
4.From: ROGER HIRST, DEUTSCHE BANK AG, LO <hirsrog@bloomberg.net>
At: 18-May-2016 05:38:26
 
There is a lot of noise around the noise around the Fed. This is because there is not much else to get our teeth into. Too much complacency and the Fed invokes its optionality. All meetings need to be live otherwise the market will invest with impunity, making any eventual rate hike even harder. The last rate hike lead to the conditions that required the Fed to relent. If the Fed now relent on their relent, then they will presumably sow the conditions for the next relent. Inflation is primarily via housing (rent) and healthcare. Both of these are a tax on spending. Productivity does not justify a rise in wages, although current rates have been far below the natural growth rate for far too long. The unconventional build up in asset prices has, however, already taken place. The economy needs higher interest rates, but can asset prices tolerate them? The SPX is flitting aimlessly around within its range. Rather than sell in May, it maybe better to do nothing and save on commission. We do have a line in the sand around 2040, which is the neckline of a small head and shoulders formation from which we have bounced a couple of times. A break here would target around 1970 and sufficient hawkish talk maybe the key that unlocks this mini trap door, but the drop would only widen out the channel to the same range that we have seen for much of the last 18 months. A hawkish Fed would also increase the chance of an excessive China response. When the Fed implied a rate hike in mid summer last year, China responded with a test devaluation in August. When the Fed raised rates in Dec, the Chinese equity market went into a mini meltdown starting January 4th (from which global activity has never fully recovered), an acceleration of capital outflows and a response that included the largest ever single quarter of Chinese Total Social Financing ($1trn in 3 months, which is the equivalent of the US engaging in an annualised $6.5trn of QE). When we did a DB China conference call in the aftermath of the Aug devaluation, 538 clients dialled in. When we did one a few days after the January jitters, 935 clients joined the call. Most other China calls have been in the region of 150-250 clients. Yesterday we had 435 join our latest China conference call, by far the largest participation outside a time of visceral stress. Perhaps it reflects a casual interest given the lack of alternative market catalysts. But there does seem to be a genuine build up of concern that has not been reflected by price action. It maybe that we are simply too bearish given the underlying levels of benign growth. Perhaps we are right to fear a hawkish tone from the Fed when a major concern is the inability of other central banks to settle on additional accommodation. For investors who have been long and laughing, selling stock and buying cheap SPX calls look attractive (lock in profits but keep a long bias). For those wanting a cheap hedge, our Asia colleagues would point to the outperformance of the AS51 (Australia) and its low volatility and skew. If the Fed are merely determined to cap asset prices and particularly the SPX, then a strong USD/weaker EUR would make the cheapening of SX5E calls conditional on the SPX around current levels look like an attractive proposition. However, all these cost commission and the best thing may still be to do nothing until the Fed make it clear that they are not joking again.

It took one chattered, so called "think tank" report, 2 Fed speakers, 1 Hilsenrath article: All of a sudden, as I warned before, market remembered that Frau Number 2 never said "I will only hike once this year." Not yet. We had gone way too much to the other extreme & we are adjusting. June 6th is next time she will take the world stage & it proves a huge day for your diaries. May 27th, we will be proud to give Yellen a medal at Harvard-Radcliffe, but I doubt she will talk about flatteners to new grads. All EM is opening nervous as I type. This time all EM asset classes. Though mind you, CEMA Credit traders talk of oil as the main decider; whereas, Asia credit traders are more nervous about sell-off in the front end of US rates.  Not all clients are pessimistic. Majority is, but "melt up" was also mentioned. The deciders on this match for next weeks will be China & Yellen relent's lifespan. Her hiking in July wouldn't shock me, but better data needed. While we are at it, FOMC Minutes tomorrow can also be hyped more hawkish. I am not sure Yellen's heart is there at all. But a spin is a spin & market is more vulnerable at the moment to that. Data itself? Well, core CPI data yesterday was so benign that even  our Torsten Slok wrote that "it helps the doves." "Hurrah hurrah USA" camp really doesn't have much predictions to be proud of at the moment. But that doesn't mean we shouldn't take advantage when the herd moves to other extreme too much. But if I am eventually right about Remain winning and Hillary leading, Summer's early fate may be determined on June 6th & with the US data the week before. If Leave wins, it will be a looongg summer. But Macro is NOT trading with that at all at the moment. With this data & China's potential answer on her mind, I doubt Frau Number 2 would make a move. But first, markets will get more nervous that she indeed may!

2.US Daily Economic Notes - Manufacturing outlook remains muted 16 May 2016 (1 page/ 246 kb)这篇对与不对，就看今晚ip了。我倾向于对
Commentary for Tuesday: The May New York Fed Empire Survey was meaningfully weaker than expected (-9.0 vs. +9.6 previously). The details of the report, which are compiled separately from the headline, were soft, as well. New orders, inventories, shipments and delivery time all declined in the month. In the chart below, the aforementioned New York Fed Empire components are weighted to create an ISM-adjusted manufacturing survey. Following two consecutive 50-plus readings, the series fell back below 50 in May (48.1). This suggests that the manufacturing ISM, which was also in expansion territory in March (51.8) and April (50.8), could register a sub-50 reading when the May data are released on June 1. 
As our regular readers know, the manufacturing ISM survey is one of our favorite gauges of economic activity because the series is highly correlated with underlying real GDP growth, and has the benefit of only being subject to minor revisions. This is not the case with other highly-followed indicators such as retail sales, which were very strong last month. Retail control, the subcategory of spending that is a direct input into GDP, increased 0.9% in April, the largest month-over-month increase in over two years. We would not be surprised if this gain were revised substantially lower. In addition to the ISM, the other key economic figures investors should monitor are: employee tax withholding receipts, unit motor vehicle sales, the Fed's Senior Loan Officer Survey and initial jobless claims. See the US Economics Weekly dated May 6 for a complete discussion of our "Top Five Economic Indicators Index". 
A weaker manufacturing ISM would be consistent with our expectation of an extended period of stagnant factory activity. While the manufacturing sector accounts for just 10% of GDP, the former is highly predictive of the latter. Our forecast of further economic weakness stems largely from excessive inventory building over the last several quarters. In turn, the need to work off stockpiles will likely weigh on new orders and production. If this Thursday's Philadelphia Fed survey corroborates the weakness in yesterday's Empire figures, the chances of a sub-50 reading on the manufacturing ISM would be elevated. Historically, the latter has been in contraction territory on 68% of the occasions when the Empire and Philadelphia ISM-adjusted series were both below 50. 
 
3.From: Torsten Slok——他的观点和lavorgana截然相反
Sent: 16 May 2016 13:58
Subject: DB: Lack of supply of Treasuries holding US rates down
 
I will be guest host on Bloomberg TV tomorrow from 6 am to 7 am to discuss the Fed and rates, and one force, which continues to hold rates down is the lack of supply in the US Treasury market, see chart below. The economy continues to do well and as a result, the Treasury has seen higher tax receipts than expected.  Consequently, the need to issue new bonds has declined. In fact, in April 2016, new issuance of Treasury notes and bonds was negative for the first time since 2008.
 
Bottom line: 10-year Treasury rates at 1.72% is not a sign that the US economy is unhealthy. Instead, negative interest rates abroad and a steady decline in the net new supply of Treasuries will continue to keep rates low. Pushing rates higher are ongoing upward pressures on US inflation and EM central banks selling Treasuries to defend their exchange rates. In the near term, I expect the technicals to keep rates low but over time higher US inflation will push the entire yield curve higher.
 
4.提到财政政策了
WINKLER... Morning notes
 
1）Mr Abe's in a pickle. He will try to manage G7 headlines around coordinated fiscal policy. The postponement of the consumption tax hike is likely a done deal and fully priced by markets, but G7 endorsement would strengthen the bullish message to Japan’s private sector. The GDP print on Wednesday could similarly serve as a kicker if it turns positive, as expected by the market. Our Tokyo economists, however, expect real GDP to have fallen by 1.3% saar. Moreover, the risk for Abe is that US warnings against FX intervention dominate headlines. The Abe government will try to manage this (see Asakawa’s comments this morning), but the ‘currency truce’ message may overshadow talk of coordinated fiscal policy. In all, the week is more likely to bring bad news for Abenomics, dampen domestic risk sentiment, and keep USD/JPY under pressure.
 
2.）Downside risks to Antipodes. The market prices the next RBA cut for Q4, but even the June meeting could become very live if the wage price index tanked on Wednesday. Consensus is 0.5% and DB models point at 0.6%, but that’s flat from Q4. The structural break in core CPI in Q1 must have come from somewhere, and wages are the leading contender. In New Zealand, inflation expectations for Q1 will likely set the RBNZ’s decision for the June meeting. It would likely take a bounce back above 1.8% from 1.63% to give the RBNZ pause, whereas a further decline below 1.6% should seal the deal. Hard to predict this, but June pricing looks vulnerable to a weak print at only -16bps.

Subject: EOD oil note - 16 May
尼日利亚继续罢工，而且工人支持油价上涨 。中国地炼进口持续增加。利比亚有望本周恢复出口。美国页岩油产出持续下降——偏牛
Oil rallied over a dollar soon after opening on possibility of further disruptions in Nigeria, and technical buying after strong rally last week. Brent gains were capped as Libya exports should restart after Vienna meeting and Qua Iboe is also expected to resume production by end of week. Gasoline-WTI margins started strong but collapsed by a dollar later in the day.
- Nigeria: Nigeria’s labor unions called for a strike over the weekend as govt plans to reduce fuel subsidy. However,  the 2 main oil and gas workers’ unions stated that they support the price increase and will not participate in the strikes. On Friday militants attacked Chevron pipeline Marakaba in Warri, but details have not been released yet. Oil companies in the region have received direct threats from Niger Delta Avengers to evacuate or meet their demands of revenue share. Exxon commented later today that it expected to ramp up Qua Iboe production later this week. Nigerian oil minister stated that countries oil production is now down to 1.4mbd (from 2.1mbd earlier) due to increasing disruptions.
- China refinery runs increased 310kbd m/m to 10.92mbd, even with heavy maintenance, as teapot refineries continued to increase utilization. Implied demand picked up by 170kbd y/y to 10.63mbd, while crude production dropped 54kbd m/m to 4.05mbd (-220kbd y/y).
- Chairman of Libya’s unofficial Eastern NOC said today that they have agreed with the western NOC to resume exports from Hariga port, and exports are due to restart in about 3 days. This will bring back about 130kbd of offline Libyan production.
- Genscape reported an estimate of 695kb build in Cushing for last week. Part of this is due to Marketlink pipeline maintenance.
- EIA drilling productivity report estimates US Shale production to fall by 113kbd in June (in line with 114kbd forecast for May), with North Dakota -27kbd, Eagle Ford -58kbd and Permial basin -10kbd

6.GEORGE SARAVELOS——最近市场似乎是波澜不兴啊
08:21:46 Morning notes – too much noise
 
1）Brexit noise – the key question going into the EU referendum vote next month is how much the market is pricing, but it is practically impossible to tell. Betting odds for “out” have been steadily declining currently around 20%, poll of polls are remarkably stable but confusing depending on online or phone, while GBP risk reversals are making new highs indicating rising probability of “out”. Perhaps the most reasonable statement is that the market will be unwilling to hold large positions heading into this binary event so difficult to see large risk-allocations in coming weeks for anything that is likely to be impacted by the outcome (GBP and EUR FX, equities). 这个话题讨论得太多，但对市场应该没有什么影响力了。赌博商的赔率几乎没有悬念了。
 
2）S&P noise – the most remarkable thing in markets is not how well S&P is holding up but how badly other risk assets are performing in comparison. EM FX has slowly but surely decoupled reversing almost half of Q1 gains and similarly both European and Japan stocks are far, far away from the year highs. This is not coordinated risk resilience but disappointing sogginess and points to the continued lack of positive catalyst with growth and downside China risks the biggest binding constraints. Own bias remains bearish and $EM bullish.
 
3）Inflation noise– perhaps the only consistent trend in recent weeks is the huge rally in oil yet the lack of responsiveness in inflation breakevens and fixed income is remarkable. Brent is at November highs yet Euro 5y5y inflation breakevens are still 30bps below. Lack of positive growth catalyst or clarity on Fed reaction function may be partial culprits, Yellen June 6th speech before FOMC purdah all the more important. Ahead of that Japan G7 May 27th meetings/fiscal decisions also coming up, market needs a delay to the consumption tax and big fiscal package above 8-10trio JPY to believe that a positive policy response is in the offing. DB house view skeptical, the less fiscal easing the more bullish JPY.
 
1 + 2 + 3 = hard to see big trends heading into June

2.US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 13 May 2016 (1 page/ 216 kb)
FOMC纪要也被猜得七七八八了，其次是明晚新屋，cpi和ip。大头都在周二
Commentary for Monday: This week's economic data docket will provide important information on manufacturing, housing and inflation. The Fed will also release the minutes of the April 26-27 meeting. This morning's NY Fed Empire survey is expected to slip slightly back into contraction territory. This is mainly because of the factory sector's need to work off elevated inventory positions, which should drag on measures of manufacturing output in the near term. The NAHB housing index should remain steady. While the index is currently at a relatively high reading, it is down seven points from its cyclical peak, which was reached last October. 
Tomorrow we get April housing starts (1.100M forecast vs. 1.089M previously) and housing permits (1.100M vs. 1.076M), as well as the April consumer price index (CPI). In our view, the latter will be of greater significance given the Fed's desire for clear signs of firming inflation, which would then enable monetary policymakers to continue the process of interest rate normalization. The headline CPI (+0.2% vs. +0.1%) will be boosted by the recent improvement in energy prices, while further moderation in the growth rate of residential rents may keep a lid on the core CPI (+0.1% vs. +0.1%). While owners' equivalent rent is up 2.9% annualized over the past three months, this is down from a cyclical peak of 3.5% in the three months ending last August. In general, we do not see much inflationary pressure in the economy. With nominal GDP up only about 3% over the last year and with corporate profit margins under pressure, companies do not have much ability to pass along higher prices. If anything, contracting profit margins, along with weak productivity growth and tepid top-down demand, raise the risk that firms will significantly slow the pace of hiring as they may be forced to trim labor costs. Later on Tuesday morning, the Fed will release its April industrial production (+0.1% vs. -0.6%) and capacity utilization (74.9% vs. 74.8%) report. We expect only a slight gain due to a modest uptick in mining hours. Typically, the US economy has experienced little inflationary pressure when factory utilization has hovered in the mid-70s. 
The April FOMC minutes, released on Wednesday afternoon, are likely to strike a more balanced tone than the dovish meeting statement. This is because various FOMC participants have made comments over the past several weeks emphasizing policy flexibility and the Fed's expectation that output growth will rebound after a soft Q1. While we expect the Fed to raise rates again in December, the risk is that rate hikes will be delayed until next year. 
On Thursday, the May Philadelphia Fed survey (-1.0 vs. -1.6) should show a similarly-soft reading to the New York Empire series. The correlation coefficient between the levels of the two series is a reasonably high 0.76. Initial jobless claims for the week ending May 14 will be released alongside the Philadelphia Fed. This week's claims data are of elevated importance as they correspond to the employment survey week. The recent spike in claims was likely due to temporary factors (i.e., seasonal adjustments and production disruptions) within a few specific states. Hence, we expect claims to retrace most of their recent rincrease (275k vs. 294k). Later on Thursday, we get the April index of leading economic indicators (+0.5% vs. +0.2%), which will be boosted by stock prices, building permits and the interest rate spread. However, the year-over-year rate of the LEI will likely slip to 2.0%. Finally on Friday, we anticipate a trend-like reading on March existing homes sales (5.25M vs. 5.33M). 
 
3.
US Economics Weekly - Dissecting the dual mandate: Why the Fed might be pausing for productivity   not a great bargin13 May 2016 (7 pages/ 314 kb)
Overview: The Fed's dual mandate of maximum employment and price stability implies substantial oversight of the private economy. We develop a proxy for nominal private GDP growth, perhaps the broadest measure of private sector activity, and decompose this proxy into two segments, one that is explicitly within the scope of the dual mandate and one that is not. Weak nominal private growth in the present cycle has been almost entirely due to the latter, in particular the abysmal trend in productivity. We conclude that while a narrow reading of the Fed's dual mandate might suggest that it is far behind the curve in terms of rate hikes, the Fed has favored a very cautious approach because it has implicitly assumed broad responsibility for nominal output growth. As the productivity slowdown is unlikely to get resolved in the near term, we expect the Fed to remain on hold through much of this year, and possibly into next year.
 
 
4.
Data Flash - Momentum of economic activity softened in April 15 May 2016 (2 pages/ 188 kb)
如果考虑地方债置换，文中所提这些就是临时的
Summary: Economic activities slowed in April. Risks to our Q2 growth forecast of 7% are likely tilting more to the downside, partly because policy stance shift seemed taking place sooner and faster than we anticipated. We continue to expect growth to slow in H2 and maintain our 6.7% full year growth forecast.
Most headline activity indicators softened in April. Industrial production grew 6.0%yoy in April and 5.8%ytd (6.8%yoy in March and 5.8% in Jan-March, Figure 1). Growth of fixed asset investment edged down from 10.7% for Jan-March to 10.5% for Jan-April, with implied monthly growth slowing from 11.2%yoy in March to 10.1%. Nominal growth of retail sales also dropped to 10.1%yoy, from 10.5% in March and 10.2% in Jan-Feb (Figure 2).
Property market is one of the few bright spots. Sales remained strong (Figure 3). Growth of sales value was 55.9% for Jan-April, a tad higher than the 54.1% for Q1. Growth of floor space sold improved more, picking up from 33.1% in Q1 to 36.5% for Jan-April. Investment strengthened further, growing 7.2% for Jan-April, versus 6.2% for Jan-March and 3.0% for Jan-Feb (Figure 4).
Another indication that Q2 growth could still be stronger than Q1 is that funds available for investment continued to improve. In April, the ytd growth of funds available for total FAI was 8.1%, higher than the 6.4% for Q1 (Figure 5). Funds available for property investment also picked up from 14.7% in Q1 to 16.8% for Jan-April. Growth of planned investment for new projects slowed slightly but remained high at 38.0% ytd (41.1% in Jan-Feb and 39.5% for Jan-March), suggesting that infrastructure investment will likely stay robust in the rest of the year (Figure 6). 
Considering all the development observed in April, including monetary data released earlier (see our report, Weak M2 in April confirms a shift in policy stance, on May 13), we see risks to our Q2 growth forecast of 7% tilting more to the downside, in part because policy stance shift seemed taking place sooner and faster than we anticipated (also see our report, China: Policy shifts from aggressive easing to a neutral stance, on May 9). We continue to expect growth to slow down in H2 (6.6% in Q3 and 6.4% in Q4), and maintain our full year growth forecast at 6.7%. We see one more interest rate cut in Q4, and three more RRR cuts, one in each remaining quarter of this year. 
 
 
5.
-          Oil: According to Reuters, in April, Iraq overtook Saudi Arabia as the top exporter to India, the first time since December. Iraq accounted for 22 percent of April Indian imports, up from about 15 percent a year ago, while Saudi Arabia's share dropped to 18 percent from about 25 percent a year ago.
Iran is also raising its share in Indian imports. The country accounted for about 9 percent of overall purchases in April compared to about 7.2 percent a year ago. Saudi Arabia also lost its top spot in China, Asia's biggest oil consumer, last month when Russia overtook it due to strong purchases by Chinese
independent refineries.

2.又会是等待戈多吗？如果今晚零售不好，戈多可是要真的出现了
From: Torsten Slok
Sent: 12 May 2016 13:20
Subject: DB: The next big macro risk: Inflation
 
I will be speaking at the Bloomberg Annual Fixed Income Forum here in Manhattan at 2pm today to discuss the outlook for the Fed and markets. Many clients I meet worry that the biggest macro risk on the horizon is another financial crisis. But why should the next crisis be similar to the last crisis? Think about it, yes, the recession in 2009 was a banking and housing crisis but the recession in 2000 was triggered by an IT bubble and the recession in the early 1990s was caused by a commercial real estate bubble. And in the 1980s, recessions were caused by policy mistakes and in the 1970s the recession was caused by oil prices going up, not down.
 
I believe the biggest risk for macro investors at the moment is not a financial crisis but a continued move higher in US inflation. And I think this is what the Fed is trying to tell us when they repeatedly point out that we are near full employment. The chart below shows that more people are buying inflation protection at the moment, but markets are in my view generally unprepared for higher inflation and what higher inflation would mean for the Fed and for long rates and for vol and markets more broadly. Wage measures have been slowly moving higher for an extended period, including in the employment report last Friday, and combining the upward pressure on wages with the ongoing depreciation of the dollar I think we will continue to see upward pressure on core PCE over the coming quarters.
 
3.US Daily Economic Notes - Consumer spending could be more concerning than claims 认为昨夜ijc可能是临时性的，今晚零售更重要12 May 2016 (1 page/ 219 kb)
Commentary for Friday: Yesterday we learned that jobless claims for the week of May 7 spiked unexpectedly to 294k, the highest level since the week of February 28, 2015 (310k). As a result, the four-week moving average increased 10k to 268k. On the surface this development is worrying. As we wrote in yesterday's commentary, claims are a very good leading indicator of the labor market and the broader economy. As long as claims hovered near their four-decade lows, an imminent labor market slowdown was unlikely. To be sure, a sustained increase in claims to about 300k would raise concerns that the labor market may be in the midst of a more pronounced slowdown. 
However, in the details of the latest claims report, we found that the entire increase was attributable to the state of New York. Initial jobless claims in New York were up 23k last week on a seasonally-adjusted basis. The historical data suggest that the jump in claims in New York could be driven by a seasonal issue: Similar distortions occurred at roughly the same time of the year in 2014 (April 26, +21k) and 2011 (April 30, +21k). Importantly, in both of the above cases, claims reverted to trend the very next week. Recall that this latest jump in claims comes on the heels of an auto-related spike in Michigan and Ohio in the prior week. The fact that the increase in claims over the past couple of weeks has not been broad based means that it is probably too soon to conclude that the pace of hiring is significantly deteriorating. That said, if claims do not retrace some of their recent rise over the next several weeks, we would become more worried about the underlying health of the labor market. 
With respect to this morning's data, retail sales will garner significant attention given the soft profile of consumer spending in Q1. The headline should be boosted by a rebound in motor vehicle sales as well as a moderate increase in gas prices. However, we expect retail control, which is the core of the report and excludes autos, building materials and gas stations, to rise by just two tenths. If this is the case, retail control would be up only 2.1% annualized through April—the weakest start to the year since the first four months of 2013 (2.0%). While income tax increases likely dampened consumer activity at the beginning of 2013, this is not the case at present. Remember, also, that real GDP growth in H1 2013 was just 1.5% as inflation-adjusted consumer spending grew a relatively weak 1.9%. In short, if consumer spending fails to firm in the current quarter, monetary policymakers may begin to question the underlying health of domestic demand. All else being equal, this would diminish prospects of rate hikes this year. 
With core PCE inflation below target, the Fed should not be in much of a hurry. Today's PPI data may provide some clues on the near-term trend of the core PCE deflator as the select healthcare industries component of the former is used to construct the healthcare series in the latter. Recall that healthcare has the largest weighting in the core PCE (roughly 20%) and has meaningfully contributed to the recent firming in the Fed's preferred inflation metric. If the PPI healthcare series slows, core inflation expectations may moderate. 
 
 
4.最近伦敦负面消息不断，这是关于房市的——伦敦现在是高价房供需两旺，平价房则是供给不足；其中高价房投资需求几乎是居住需求的两倍-不太好，但一时半会还不会崩吧
 
 
From: Oliver Harvey
 
Subject: More (bearish) charts on London housing
 
 
 
Last month we highlighted growing slowdown in the London housing market in survey data as an important risk to watch for sterling into the second half of the year. The latest RICS house  price balance came out yesterday, and the results are grim. The ‘new buyer enquiries’ balance which typically leads the overall index by around 3m (see chart 1), points to the sharpest slowdown since the global financial crisis.  
  
Talk about a bubble in London property and the common rejoinder is ‘demand-supply imbalance.’ But it depends where you look. The supply of social and affordable housing has been woefully  inadequate, but new builds of prime or semi-prime property have roared ahead in recent years to keep up with foreigncapital or demand for alternative assets. In the last two years alone, sales  of one million pound-plus flats and masionettes have gone through the roof (Figure 4). Collapsing affordability and very low rates have also underpinned the buy-to-let boom in the capital, again concentrated in those flats, terraces and masionettes (charts  5 and 6).  
  
But the tide is turning. A slowing EM cycle, macroprudential and government tightening and a social backlash against the hollowing out of central  London by absentee owners are all contributing. The massive rise in housing transactions in March (chart 7) before the stamp duty increase on second homes illustrates both the effectiveness of fiscal tightening and the dislocated nature of the market.  
  
The real test of a bubble is not whether the high quality assets are expensive, but where the low grade stuff is trading. Are the ten percent least desirable properties  in Westminster, Kensington and Chelsea and the City of London (those with views of a brick wall, for example) really worth more than twice as much as four years ago, or up to five times as much as in 2010? Even in Camden, a postcode with far less cache, prices  in the lowest bracket are 50% higher than two years previously.

 2.
Deutsche Bank - Fixed Income Research
G10 and EM Regime Machine - Follow valuation, forget monetary policy 11 May 2016 (5 pages/ 476 kb)
G10 Trendiness has risen sharply over the last week in G10 FX, while uniformity continues to remain at moderate levels. Volatility has only marginally increased. These are good conditions for momentum trading.Valuation is now the strongest macro driver of currency performance, with a correlation of over 90%. Weakness in USD/JPY accounts for much of the high beta, but price action in the Scandinavian and commodity currencies is consistent with the trend. At the same time, correlations confirm that the influence of monetary policy has waned significantly over the past quarter. Carry remains positively correlated to currencies.
 EM
In emerging markets, aggregate trendiness is still near extreme lows, while uniformity is hovering at high levels. Volatility has increased somewhat.  These are not ideal conditions for trading.
As in G10, valuation has become the key driver of EM FX. The outperformance of RUB, BRL and ZAR has been particularly influential, also helped by carry. Sovereign risk remains strongly correlated to FX performance.
 
 
3.FX Daily - USD/JPY: A threshold for 90 or 115: USD/JPY has finished the 2012-2015 upward cycle due to slower US economic momentum, in our view.Japanese hedgers are leaning to dollar selling, and investors have become cautious toward buying the dollar on dips. Investor trust in BoJ policies has retreated too. While the Abe administration wants to halt yen appreciation,
which weakens stock prices, ahead of the July election, the US added Japan to the currency monitoring list, suggesting the US is not favorable to currency intervention by Japan. JPY bulls have been revitalized by the apparent lack of measures available to Japanese authorities to stop yen appreciation as well as recent weak US economic data. Over the medium term, however, the market currently lacks a decisive factor for the USD/JPY to move to the 90 range or shift back toward 115 in the downward cycle, we think both scenarios are genuine possibilities. Our main medium-term scenario is the latter, which fits with our economist’s outlook for US economic growth accelerating to over 2%.(中长期美元还是会走强)Click here<http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/4520-24B9/4265013/

5.US Daily Economic Notes - Claims should retrace some of last week's spike 11 May 2016 (1 page/ 244 kb)
Commentary for Thursday: Jobless claims are among the best high-frequency indicators of the health of the labor market. The added benefit of this series is that revisions tend to be quite minimal. Not surprisingly, the trend in initial jobless claims is inversely related to real GDP growth. This makes sense because when jobless claims are declining, the economy is generally improving and vice versa. However, the data are prone to short-term volatility due to weather events, seasonal adjustment difficulties and other short-term production issues. Case in point, last week, initial jobless claims spiked 17k, which was the largest week-over-week increase since January 2015. Our best guess is that this was due to a temporary production disruption at a large US auto producer. 
As the chart below illustrates, jobless claims in Michigan and Ohio jumped by nearly 11k for the week of April 30, accounting for over 60% of the 17k increase in total claims. For the aforementioned states, this was the largest week-over-week increase since the last recession. Recall that last week's surge in claims coincided with the temporary idling of several GM plants, which was the result of a parts shortage purportedly due to disruptions caused by the recent Japanese earthquake. In turn, barring any further unusual shutdowns by other auto producers, we expect claims to reverse much of their recent rise over the next couple of weeks. 
The aforementioned distortion to claims highlights the importance of paying closer attention to the four-week trailing average, which, at 258k, remains near multi-decade lows. However, at this point in the cycle, we do not expect much further improvement in jobless claims. Rather, we are vigilant for any sustained uptrend that would indicate a more pronounced deterioration in hiring. This is especially the case given that we have noticed a concerning downtrend in the growth rate of withheld income tax receipts ("The tepid trend in tax receipts bears watching", US Daily Economic Notes, April 27, 2016). In our view, a sustained increase in claims to around 300k would presage a more meaningful slowdown in the labor market and substantially slower output growth. Unless and until this occurs, however, claims remain a relative bright spot on the growth horizon. Next Thursday's claims data take on elevated significance as they correspond to the survey period for May nonfarm payrolls. If claims continue to climb higher—the auto production issues should now be resolved—it may indicate that the lull in April hiring was not an aberration. 
                  
6.WHAT DO I THINK HERE? We're vulnerable & not ready for big moves either way. My Macro Client Dinner last night was a confirmation for the hard time, "unhappy" feeling Macro players & our sector in general are going through. "Nobody" is core short rates. Nobody. Of course, "you" may be the exception out there. But this is/was one of these extreme times when absolute majority does not expect any "hawkish" surprises from Frau Number 2 anytime soon. With Macy's & Disney bad earnings yesterday, fearing world growth and next US recession are again in vogue. If you want to pay some EDZ7 （欧洲美元期货，pay就是看涨利率）and/or if you believe "Remain win is such a payer," come and trade with us. You are in minority. You can win big. Many still saw EM in a "sweet spot." A big sudden choke in SPX or a jump in core rates would shake players. Micro trumps over Macro for the moment. The guys and ladies who talked with more conviction about their trades were those who "can stay away from watching bloomberg tic by tic.. I go away, do my homework.. And buy a Greece or Ukraine at distressed levels".. Or buyers of European IG.. Or of EM hard currency debt.. You get the picture. Obviousy a lot of discussion over Brexit. But at this stage, it's more of an excuse to be 'not as involved,' rather than being outright worried. If Leave wins, it could be a temporary "shock" for tables like that. Many people mention China naturally. But again timing is everything（做空中国还不是时候，要等yelen肯定会行动才行，可是会吗？）. For the short term, more seem to think that the "truce" with Yellen will hold. This brings us to "President Trump.". Some saw it as real possibility, but many were "shy" to put their hands up though. What players seemed to care more about was whether we would have "unified government" or not. If Hillary and Democrats sweep, George thought fiscal easing chances go up. Konstam wasn't a big buyer. I side more with George on this one. "Is EM on the sweet spot? Can this rally continue? Even EM local markets joined EM Credit today?". Questions Tijen got a lot. She was definitely in the more "tactical trading" camp. She likes her Turkey steepeners allright, but she didn't sound as bulled up as some of the others around the table. Full writeup on my Macro dinner impressions is already in your mailboxes. Brexit was a great excuse for some to stay on "sidelines" and/or talk about "sideways" trading. But I'd say China (and relatedly Oil) is still the Orangutan in the macro room. Konstam said Londoners are more worried than New Yorkers about China. I am not sure about that, but people are worried. Timing is everything though. And my head of Asia FIC trading Sameen will have answers for us at our next table in June! Both a sharper, sudden fall in equities and the other extreme of sudden jump higher in core rates could shake tables like last night's until then! This morning, core rates are tame. Hunt for yield is still on in EM & Credit. And those who called for USD's revival are probably hiding under the table again.

STAND：Why structural reforms are EM’s last stand: In our annual update on indicators of structural performance, we find many EM economies displaying an unsurprising and yet disappointing slippage in structural strength. 救命稻草

Sweep: what players care more about was whether we would have "unified government" or not. If Hillary and Democrats sweep, George thought fiscal easing chances go up.. Konstam wasn't a big buyer. I side more with George on this one.

2.US Daily Economic Notes - Our top five indicators index is not pointing to much of a rebound ——昨晚jolt太好了，这哥们怎么不提了？非高频？昨天提过了，认为工资预交说增速减缓，导致就业改善都是暂时的。10 May 2016 (1 page/ 237 kb)
Commentary for Wednesday: We have developed a quarterly index of our top five economic indicators. The series is composed of employee tax withholding receipts, unit motor vehicle sales, initial jobless claims, lending standards for commercial & industrial loans and the manufacturing ISM survey. We chose these five series because they are highly predictive of economic activity and have the advantage of minimal revision. For example, tax receipts and motor vehicle sales do not get revised. Our top five indicators index is shown in the chart below, along with the year-over-year change in real GDP. A more detailed discussion of how the index is constructed can be found in the current US Economics Weekly. 
The index's recent strength is almost entirely attributable to extraordinarily low jobless claims; they are hovering near a four-decade low. The only other series that performed better in Q1 2016 than its historical mean (our series dates back to Q4 1994) was motor vehicle sales. As a result, only these two variables contributed positively to the index last quarter (with almost the entire positive contribution coming from claims), while the other three variables caused the index to decrease. The last time that at least three of the five variables in our index were below their historical means was Q4 2012, when economic activity was in a slump similar to the one we are in at present. Real GDP growth as measured on a year-over-year basis was just 1.3%, which also happens to be our 2016 forecast. Unlike then, the business cycle is now much older, so there is arguably substantially less pent up demand. To our minds, this means there is downside risk to our below-consensus 2016 growth projection. 
Importantly, if we extrapolate the April readings of the aforementioned five indicators across the current quarter, our index would be unchanged from last quarter. This is one reason we are not sanguine on the prospect of a strong rebound in the current quarter: We see real GDP growing at just 1.0% this quarter, compared to its initial 0.5% Q1 reading. Moreover, as discussed above, the index is largely being supported by the performance of jobless claims: If claims were to rise by about 40k to 300k, the current-quarter projection of the index would decline by almost two tenths of one standard deviation, confirming further sub-trend economic activity. It is also important to remember that subpar Q1 GDP was not an isolated event as it came on the heels of a 1.4% gain in Q4 2015. Another quarter of below-trend growth would likely result in policymakers' rethinking the trajectory of interest rates, keeping the Fed on the sidelines for the remainder of the year, if not longer. The financial markets are already there, as they are presently discounting rate-hike probabilities of only 4% in June and less than 50% by yearend.

Subject: EOD oil note - 10 May
 
Oil traded higher as NY walked in and kept the bullish momentum, reversing yesterday’s decline. Spreads however eased as situation in Canada improved and oil companies started resuming production.
- Canada wildfires, though still growing, have moved away from oil facilities, easing concerns about lost production. Shell resumed operations at Albian Sands mine at a reduced rate, while Enbridge began inspecting its facilities. ConocoPhillips is looking to send at team to Surmont facility to assess the site. WTI prompt spreads gave up 10c, and WTI-Brent arb collapsed by over 60c.
- Iraq exported 3.23mbd Basrah last week, against a scheduled 3.09mbd. Exports via Ceyhan eased back slightly to 514kbd. June exports schedule also came out, and stands at a hefty 3.47mbd for Basrah (above the Apr exports of 3.38mbd).
- EIA revised 2016 oil demand higher by 380kbd, to 1.43mbd y/y growth, mainly contributed by China (+0.20) and India (+0.21). 2017 demand was revised higher by 590kbd, with y/y growth at 1.54mbd. 2016 non-OPEC supplies were revised lower by 260kbd, with y/y declines at 740kbd. Canada output was reduced by 150kbd, which seems too high to be caused by wildfires on annual basis (estimates are around 40-50kbd for year). April OPEC production was estimated at 31.81mbd, with Iran up 0.3mbd m/m. EIA 2016 forecast for OPEC supply is to grow by 900kbd.
- Nigeria clashes continued to escalate and 5 security personnel were killed today in the Niger Delta, worsening the situation further. Some labor unions have been calling for evacuation of oil workers from the region. However, the army has provided reassurance that they will use all available means to crush the militants.
- In Venezuela, rains have provided some relief, but water levels at Guri damn are still in the danger zone at 242.2m. Yesterday PDVSA announced that the 146kbd El Palito refinery, which had been operating at 70kbd and is the main supplier of fuel in Venezuela, will be shut for 45-60 days. PDVSA is also working on installing 3 new loading arms at the Jose terminal where 7 of the 11 arms have been down due to malfunction. The installation is expected to be completed by end of month, and the backlog of ships should begin clearing.
- APIs just came out and show a 3.45mb Crude build, with Cushing building by 1.46mb. Gasoline stocks added 270kbd, while disty stocks posted another draw of 1.36mb
 
 
4.
 
FX Daily - USD/JPY: A threshold for 90 or 115 ，今天彭博报道说日本央行采取行动的极限可能是90-9511 May 2016 (2 pages/ 257 kb)
The USD/JPY has finished the 2012-2015 upward cycle due to slower US economic momentum, in our view. Japanese hedgers are leaning to dollar selling, and investors have become cautious toward buying the dollar on dips. Investor trust in BoJ policies has retreated too. While the Abe administration wants to halt yen appreciation, which weakens stock prices, ahead of the July election, the US added Japan to the currency monitoring list, suggesting the US is not favorable to currency intervention by Japan. JPY bulls have been revitalized by the apparent lack of measures available to Japanese authorities to stop yen appreciation as well as recent weak US economic data. The USD/JPY dropped to the mid-105 level on 3 May.
It then modestly rebounded to the 109 level. We attribute the reversal to unwinding of some speculative shorts that had quickly accumulated in response to the very clear USD/JPY bear factors. Dip-buying activity by Japanese pensions and verbal interventions could have some effects to curb yen’s appreciation during such position adjustment process. However, we do not see enough support for a sustainable rebound  by the USD/JPY until concerns about a US economic slowdown have been removed. We maintain our outlook for a relatively high possibility of a battle between JPY bulls and Japanese authorities in the 100-105 range, rather than an upward shift to the 110-115 range, over a next few months.
If this outlook is correct, we view 100 as a key threshold for the USD/JPY to move to 90 or 110-115 (similar to the role of 115 in January). Key technical USD/JPY values are 100.60 as the 50% retracement from the upward cycle that lasted from October 2011 through June 2015 and 100.19 as the 10-year moving average. Japanese institutional investors could drive the USD/JPY lower if they rush hedge dollar selling in response to an increased prospect of a prolonged phase at less than 100. However, we expect a start of test buying of unhedged foreign bonds in the negative interest rate environment if sentiment spreads that the USD/JPY is firm at lower 100 range.
While the USD/JPY already roughly attained our projection of 105 at end-June from February, we think downward risk retains an edge in the near term. We cannot rule out the possibility of a steady downward trend in the USD/JPY considering the lull in US economic activity and Japan’s growing current account surplus. In the absence of a decisive factor to halt yen appreciation, we think JPY bears just need to patiently wait for US economic firmness (though still low growth), intervention, monetary easing, or fiscal action that supports risk-on sentiment, dollar buying by pensions and other investors, and overly quick build-up of speculative USD/JPY short positions.
Over the medium term, however, the market currently lacks a decisive factor for the USD/JPY to move to the 90 range or shift back toward 115 in the downward cycle, we think both scenarios are genuine possibilities. Our main medium-term scenario is the latter, which fits with our economist’s outlook for US economic growth accelerating to over 2% from late this year into next year and the Fed raising the policy rate five times during this period. We recommend JPY longs against the USD in the short term, but think it is too early for medium-term JPY shorts and can hesitate to advise an easy shift to JPY shorting even around the threshold at 100. We think it would be better for JPY longs to focus on a currency with a bearish outlook against the USD such as the EUR (rather than the USD).

1.Update - Our RMB index only shows 2% depreciation this year 09 May 2016 (1 page/ 226 kb)
The latest USDCNY rate, 6.496 at the closing of May 6, was virtually flat compared to its level at end-2015, 6.494. Nonetheless, since the USD had sizable depreciation vs. both the euro, ?4.8% YTD, and the JPY, -10.9% YTD (Figure 1), the PBoC's RMB index actually depreciated from 100.9 at end-2015 to 96.6 on May 6 (Figure 2). Some investors are concerned that the RMB has weakened so much vs. the currency basket that the PBoC would have to intervene, to make the RMB strengthen against the USD and thereby maintain a stable basket value. We do not see such necessity of intervention though. First, the PBoC officials have repeatedly explained that, they would only use the RMB index as a reference rather than embarking on a new hard peg regime. Second, the PBoC did not specify the parameters for the "stability of RMB exchange rate" that it intended to achieve. A 4.3% YTD depreciation of the RMB index is still modest, if compared with the volatilities seen in some other major currencies, including the euro and JPY. Finally, our own effective exchange rate index suggests an even smaller YTD RMB depreciation, around 2.1%. Our EER index is adjusted for the bias caused by processing trade, and therefore better measures the competitiveness impact of exchange rate movements (see our report: A new REER index for RMB, Jan 5, 2016). In particular, the JPY takes a much smaller weight in our currency basket than in the PBoC's, because of Japan's partnership with China on the global supply chain. In fact, our EER index is still 0.8% higher than end-2014, the base period for the PBoC RMB index.
 
 
 
2.
US Daily Economic Notes - Elevated inventories could offset potential demand recovery 
Commentary for Tuesday: The advance Q1 2016 GDP report indicated that inventory accumulation declined to $60.9 billion from $78.3 billion previously, thus taking 33 basis points off GDP growth. At first blush, this suggests that the economy made progress in working off excessive inventories last quarter, implying that inventories would be less of a drag on manufacturing activity and top-line GDP growth for the rest of the year. Unfortunately, aggregate demand decelerated considerably faster than inventories. For example, final sales of domestic product, measured as GDP minus inventory accumulation, were up just 0.9% last quarter, compared to 3.9% as recently as Q2 2015. Consequently, the ratio of inventories to final sales actually increased last quarter to its highest level since Q4 2008. The chart below shows this series along with our estimate of its time trend. The trend is estimated from 1985 to 2007 (and projected thereafter), during which time the ratio trended steadily downwards, likely due to improvements in inventory-management technology. The trend line suggests that inventory levels remain very elevated. Unless aggregate demand accelerates substantially, we are likely to see a much larger unwind of inventories than has occurred thus far. While it is difficult to precisely predict the timing and magnitude of inventory liquidation, our time trend estimate gives a sense of how much inventories could weigh on GDP for the next few quarters. At present, the level of inventories is about $90 billion above trend. Given our cautious outlook on demand, inventories may not return to trend until next year. Consequently, the need for further de-stocking is a downside risk to our intermediate-term GDP outlook. 
To be sure, time trend estimates are somewhat arbitrary, and the actual inventory unwind might be considerably smaller than we have estimated. However, the above analysis underscores the pernicious nature of the ongoing growth slowdown. While demand did rebound from similarly weak levels in 2012, inventories were below trend at the time. Thus, inventory accumulation picked up meaningfully in response to expected (and realized) acceleration in demand, amplifying the effect of the latter on top-line GDP. By contrast, even if demand were to recover later this year, the best we can likely hope for is that inventory accumulation will not slow. In other words, inventories are expected to dull the positive impact of a potential demand recovery and exacerbate the deleterious effects of a further slowdown in demand. 
 
3.From: Prateek Jain  ——原油已经供需平衡了
Sent: Monday, May 09, 2016 09:21 PM
Subject: EOD oil note - 9 May
 
Oil prices collapsed today after opening over a dollar higher, as Canadian production loss failed to spark further buying interest. Reshuffle in Saudi energy ministry and peace talks in Yemen also capped the gains. Products again led the market lower, with rbob-wti crack falling almost a dollar. WTI spreads however maintained the gains gathering support from Cushing data.
- Saudi Arabia appointed Khalid al-Falih as the new energy minister over the weekend, replacing veteran Ali al-Naimi in a surprising move. The June OPEC meeting was believed to be the last meeting for al-Naimi, but an earlier change follows the Doha fiasco and part of the new Saudi policy framework under deputy crown prince Muhammed bin-Salman. The reshuffle doesn’t signal any change in Saudi policy, but al-Falih strongly opposes any production cuts or freeze, taking out any lingering possibility of a coordinated production freeze.
- Canada wildfires continued to grow over the weekend, leading to further production disruptions as Syncrude, Suncor, Statoil and Husky shut down operations in oil sands. Offline production estimates are now at 1.2-1.6mbd, but cooler weather and wind directions are now helping firefighters contain the spread. Even if fires move away from production facilities, it may take up to 2 weeks to resume production as workers return, facilities are inspected and all safety checks are performed. Impact on May production would average well above 500kbd, assuming no damage to infrastructure.
- Genscape showed a 14kb build for Cushing last week, reversing the gain from first half of the week. This helped spreads maintain the gain even as flatprice came off.
- Yemen peace talks between Houthis and Saudi backed govt were complicated over the weekend when Saudi intercepted a missile from Yemen. However, Saudi-led coalition was reported to maintain truce even after this escalation. Reports also indicate that a crude cargo could be exported from Yemen by end of month as Saudi-led coalition took control of the Shihr terminal, which has been shut for over a year. Even though initial exports will likely come from storage, as much as 50kbd production restart may follow.
- Disruptions in Nigeria continue to worsen and Shell workers at Bonga oilfield were forced to evacuate today after a militant threat. Although no production is reported to be shut yet, this further adds to the militant caused disruptions in Nigeria, where production has fallen to 10yr lows.
- China crude imports picked up 250kbd m/m to 7.95mbd for April (up 560kbd y/y). 3 month average imports are up strongly by 1.09mbd with 3 straight months of strong readings. However, most of the strength comes from teapot refinery imports, estimated to have grown 350kbd m/m. However, the increasing port congestion, stockpiling and maintenance should cut May imports significantly.

2.本周前瞻！
 
US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 06 May 2016 (1 page/ 217 kb)_完全无法标注，每个数据都如此重要！
Commentary for Monday: The key day of the week is Friday, when we get the April retail sales and producer price index (PPI) reports, along with March business inventories and the preliminary reading on May consumer sentiment. Before then, March wholesale inventories and the Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) are both released on Tuesday. In general, we expect a soft economic profile that should be consistent with only a slight snapback in growth this quarter to just 1.0%, following a 0.5% gain last quarter. Last Friday, the New York Fed released an update of its Q2 GDP Nowcast, which pointed to just 0.8% current-quarter growth. For what it is worth, we have been looking for a very weak 2016 growth profile since early February.
The need to liquidate elevated inventories, combined with the lagged effect of dollar strength on net exports and still-weak energy-related capital spending, should keep overall economic activity well below trend. Remember, too, that last year the economy benefited from a sharp improvement in net exports in Q2, following a drag of nearly two full percentage points in Q1 that was largely the result of a West Coast port slowdown. This had the effect of collapsing exports at a -6% annualized rate in Q1. The current difficulties plaguing the US economy are more long lasting in our view. 
On Tuesday we should learn that March wholesale inventories fell -0.4% compared to -0.5% previously. If there are revisions or the figures are significantly different from expectations, analysts' estimates of the Q1 GDP revision, which is released on May 27, could be impacted. The Q1 inventory results could also affect estimates of current-quarter GDP. For example, if there were significant downward revisions to Q1 inventories, we would expect less of a drag on growth this quarter and next, all else being equal. 
At the same time as wholesale inventories are reported, we will get the March JOLTS. In our view, the two most important series in the report are the hiring and quits rates, because we have found these two indicators to be the most closely correlated with job and wage trends. Moreover, these series are closely watched by the Fed. The hiring rate was at its cyclical high of 3.8% in February, while the quits rate was 2.1%, a tenth below its present-cycle peak. 
On Friday, we anticipate only a modest recovery in April retail sales (+0.3% forecast vs. -0.4% previously). Retail sales excluding autos should be slightly worse (+0.2% vs. +0.2%), but not significantly so. The PPI (+0.2% vs. -0.1%) is expected to show a modest energy-related improvement—oil prices are up nearly 30% (using monthly averages) from their recent low. The core PPI (+0.1% vs. -0.1%), however, is expected to show only slight inflationary pressure. In the details, we will be interested to see what PPI healthcare prices show, as this series is used to estimate the healthcare component of the core PCE deflator, the Fed's inflation metric of choice. Seasonally-adjusted PPI healthcare prices fell -0.1% in March and are still up only 1.1% over the past 12 months. The March business inventories (-0.4% vs. -0.1%) report will contain data on the retail sector, which has shown a sharp rise in inventories relative to sales over the past several years. At 1.50, the current retail inventory-to-sales ratio is the highest since May 2009 (1.50), when the economy was on the cusp of emerging from recession. Last but not least, we expect the preliminary reading on May University of Michigan consumer sentiment (88.0 vs. 89.0) to be near its recent levels. Also of interest within this report are long-term inflation expectations, which returned to their all-time low (2.5%) in April. 
 
 
3.US Economics Weekly - April employment affirms slow start to the current quarter 06 May 2016 (9 pages/ 484 kb)
Overview: The April employment report was in line with our modest a priori expectations. This further reduces the probability of the Fed's raising interest rates next month, as there is just one more labor report before the June 15 FOMC meeting. In our view, the latest data provide further evidence that the potential growth rate of the economy may only be around 1%. This is because the unemployment rate has been steady at around 5% for the last seven months. Based on our top five indicator index, the economy is likely to show further weakness this quarter. In turn, the recent modest slowdown in job growth is likely to persist. 
Introducing our top five indicators index: Macroeconomic data can often give conflicting signals about the growth outlook. For example, the economy grew only 0.5% in the first quarter and consumer spending was soft. However, job gains were surprisingly sturdy. In turn, some policymakers may be discounting what was the third consecutive year of well-below-trend Q1 real GDP growth, anticipating a robust rebound in the current quarter, as has been the experience in each of the past two years. This time may be different. As our regular readers know, we closely track five important data series that are all highly predictive of economic activity. These are: Employee tax withholding receipts, unit motor vehicle sales, initial jobless claims, commercial bank lending standards and the manufacturing ISM survey. We have now developed an index of our top five indicators that is highly correlated with real GDP growth. The latest reading on our top five index points to only a mild recovery in current-quarter output. 
 
 
4.FX Daily - How US politics will impact FX 06 May 2016 (3 pages/ 222 kb)
The channels through which the coming election will influence the USD are complex and sometimes contradictory - which will probably mute the response to some degree. Assuming Trump and Clinton are the candidates, below are some broad FX considerations: 
1. Fed policy:  Given Trump's comments, Yellen's term will not be extended beyond January 2018 under a Trump Presidency. In any event, Yellen may choose to leave after her term ends under a Clinton Presidency, so some change in approach is possible regardless of who wins. Given Yellen is regarded as on the dovish end of the policy spectrum, this consideration could play USD positive, but it is too soon to be a major factor. 
2. Fiscal policy: On fiscal policy, there is a significant probability of some fiscal stimulus early into the new President's term, whoever is President, even with a divisive Congressional backdrop. The last three Presidents all pursued some form of fiscal stimulus at the start of their first term under varying circumstances. Increased infrastructure investment seems to be a common theme in the Trump and Clinton proposals, and has some cross party support. The fiscal-monetary policy mix is then apt to be more USD friendly post-election. This is much more relevant for thinking about 2017 than 2016. Before then, assuming the race is reasonably tight, we will be worrying about trade disputes, and a US-led increase in global risk. 
3. Trade: These stresses have predictable FX consequences in some areas - the MXN is very vulnerable – but are less predictable in terms of impact for other currencies, including for EM Asia and CNY. EM Asia will be subject to negative trade concerns, but particularly for those countries that are intervening to stop appreciation they will be under more pressure to let their currencies appreciate. All countries on the US Treasury monitoring list spring to mind, with Taiwan and Korea in EM Asia in the spotlight based on C/A surpluses and intervention patterns. Presumably, under Trump, the US Treasury monitoring mechanism will be applied with a heavier hand. This on the surface should be good for the KRW and TWD. However, watch-out for an unpredictable China impact that could dominate all other factors. Pushing China to tolerate a more market determined exchange rate, will likely lead to a weaker CNY with negative implications for all of EM Asia FX.  How any Trump administration navigates this 'contradiction' between a country running a large bilateral surplus with the US, but market pressure for their currency to weaken, will be crucial. If Trump's negotiations with China roil markets, the dominant macro story will quickly shift to a China led risk-off move, with very negative consequences for all commodity and EM FX, with the USD strengthening against most currencies, outside the other G4 currencies. A US led increase in global uncertainty would undercut the Fed policy tightening cycle, and act as a USD negative factor versus the likes of JPY, CHF, and EUR. 
4. Key appointments: Who Trump and Clinton lean towards as Treasury Secretary is very important. The unspoken flip side of comments that countries are manipulating their currencies weaker, is that the USD is too strong. The last time the US went down the path of using the exchange rate as a trade tool was with Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen in the first couple of years of the Bill Clinton administration - a period when the US was constantly talking USD/JPY lower. Any sign that we are going down that path could put the USD under some pressure versus a few select currencies, including the yen. Trump would further close the exchange rate as one key channel through which unorthodox policy works, potentially compounding concerns about unorthodox policy efficacy, with negative risk implications. 
5. Other: However, even here pre-election USD negative implications of the trade discussion, will be partly offset by the USD positive post-election thinking on the monetary/fiscal mix, and other USD positive micro issues like a 2005 HIA equivalent repatriation of US corporate tax holdings from abroad (even if most these assets are in USD already). Considerations of a possibly more 'business friendly' administration could also be an important USD positive, but again as a 2017 theme. 
6. Conclusions: As the election debate heats up, this should play EMFX and commodity currency negative versus G3. To the extent that US politics is seen leading to a rise in global uncertainties, this should be mildly USD negative versus the JPY, CHF and EUR into the election, but the fiscal-monetary policy mix thereafter could encourage the resumption of the stronger USD theme in 2017. The wild-card in the longer-term 2017 calculus for G3, is the extent to which trade negotiations roil China's markets, which would add negative pressure to EM and commodity currencies, while the EUR and JPY would likely hold their own versus the USD.

20160508  星期日，晴，空气质量良

周五nfp之夜dxy先抑后扬，现在的解释是nfp综合统计是中庸的，说美国经济后继乏力还为时尚早。虽然就业只有160k，但过去12月ma还是好的，大趋势未变，而且是薪资增加，awh增加，似乎通胀压力凸显。Wirp甚至被认为是overreacted。还有一种说法是，美国经济增长后继乏力，使得全球都开始担忧了，而这时美元作为避险资产的地位就凸显了...下面按顺序看这些文章，可以清楚地感受到我这样押注nfp很差的人，从狂喜到挠头的过程

From: ISIN SUMENGEN-ZIEL (DEUTSCHE BANK AG, LO) At: May 6 2016 14:01:01

Subject: Fwd:Alpha Alert – Locomotive in chief slowing down
Alpha Alert – Locomotive in chief slowing down
 
The US payroll report for April was disappointing.  The data suggests that US investment in labor has not completely decoupled from the slowdown in investment in plant and machinery, and weak corporate profitability.  Weaker data will raise some serious questions about the resilience of the global economy, if the US as ‘locomotive in chief’ is slowing down.  The data today is the kind of combination that fits in the terrain that could be USD negative, as Fed rate hikes are further scaled back.  However, there was not much Fed tightening to price out.  This has given the USD downside a degree of protection.  The USD is more than holding its own, which is a strong indication that EM and commodity FX are extremely nervous about global growth momentum. The JPY has been and will remain the main beneficiary of these concerns.
 
Report highlights:
 
On the negative side:   headline at 160K with net revisions -19K, is not terrible, but meaningfully weaker than expected;  U3 rate at 5% is disappointing in the context of a decline in participation rate and the household employment at -316K was very poor;  the payroll breakdown shows jobs almost solely concentrated in service producing.
 
Brighter spots include:  the U6 ‘underemployment’ rate down 0.1% to 9.7%. Hourly earnings at 0.3%; and hours worked up.  The broadest measure of activity aggregate hours worked was up a healthy 0.4% m/m and this is the main indicator suggesting the data should not be seen as very weak.  Even here the 3m annualized aggregate hours worked at 0.9% is uninspired thanks to Feb weakness.
 
Fed implications:   The probability of a 25bp rate hike in June and July was only put at 10% and 25% respectively before the release.  After the release market sees only a 50-50 chance of a hike this year.  Obviously labor market resilience was the data point making the strongest case for a summer hike.  Barring a payroll rebound in the next few months, indications of some loss of payroll momentum will reinforce the market’s dovish expectations. The good news for the USD going into the data was that there was not much Fed tightening to price out.  This has given the USD downside a degree of protection, and now concerns over global growth are taking over.
 
 
2.market narrative perhaps best described like this:
 
stage 1 - weak growth in Q1, let's price out the Fed, risk assets OK, EM likes it, dollar suffers
 
stage 2 - growth still weak in Q2, nothing more Janet can do, risk assets not so good, EM hates it, dollar becomes a flight to safety
 
Can the dynamic change again back to state 1? Yes - if market starts pricing Fed easing. But arguably the mix is nowhere near enough for that to happen so we're just left stumbling along, waiting to see what happens to China, and certainly no reason to own SPX above 2000 UNLESS growth comes back more convincingly
JOHN BENDA
13:59:16 George - chart seems to agree with you. Assuming nothing too dramatic happens before the end of the week and the data momentum is not going to flip around overnight, Dollar Index seems at crucial junction with decent short term support. On the weekly chart we are printing a shooting star candle just of the 100 week moving average, given USD has dropped ~9% in the past 6 months, arguably we could think the next 2-3% is in favour of USD across the board (DXY weekly chart attached).
