14:01:00 The Fed's broad $ index is noww up on the day.
 
3.WHAT DO I THINK HERE? Nobody seems "happy" in financial markets, isn't it? We bounce like we did on Friday night because everybody was short going into the number thinking it was one-way street. Dudley's an excuse. Shaky May maybe. But no February!
 
Friday night was supposed to give Risk a predicted bad close. NFP was a mediocre number. Hurrah hurrah USA goes further in retreat. Average hourly earnings increase is talked up, but Yellen continues to talk down inflation.
 
In the "new equilibrium," we were supposed to fear world growth again, equities were supposed to choke, dollar rise and core rates fall. It didn't exactly play out that way. Just before London dinner time, Dudley talked down the "bad aspects" of NFP, claimed it wasn't "that important" (yeah, right) and said they could still hike twice.
 
This was the "excuse" global markets used to have a good close in equities (Europe had closed firm long before), dollar strengtened and TY yields rose. Well.. To dismal 1.77%! ;)
 
The Fed will keep playing games. Understandably. When the dollar goes too far they will talk it down (for the sake of China) when the data justifies too much dollar weakness they will lean against it in the other side (Dudley yesterday). Data dependency, if you want to be fooled ;)!  They just want to steer markets in a certain direction regardless. 央妈就是vol killer
 
They get helped by the fact that the other central banks are cautious with the little ammunition they have left (well the RBA still has decent room relatively speaking). And so we continue this game of cat and mouse. Until it all gets too much. It seems still too early for a big pop. Seems increasingly like Brexit could be a y2k in the near term. Which will delay the big pop yet further.
 
Granted, this doesn't mean that those of us who were looking for an EM correction (simply was too crowded and tipsy) weren't right. And one doesn't need to get carried away! Es IS weaker than it was last Friday night!
 
But the way majority is speaking they want to see 1950s before 2100s.. I don't see that necessarily!
 
Even in EM, Friday/Saturday news are better than bears wished. China reserves were a "good" number. (Despite 3 bearish recent DB pieces on China). Turkey got upgraded (was it all Davutoglu's fault, twitter land asks tongue in cheek! ;).. South Africa didn't get downgraded!
 
If Tuesday Jolts and more importantly Friday Retails are good numbers, USD higher, US rates wider/steeper camp may try again.. But the likes of Brazil (new President next week!), Turkey, South Africa duration CAN do well.
 
Yellen may still intend to hike in July.. But data needs to get better than this mediocrity! Sorry, our NYC lunch host Dudley.——-语气很搞啊
 
Don't count September hike out, by the way. Given all this election talk.. Well in 2012, Bernanke gave "surprising QE" Sugar in Sep 2012 "helping" Obama get re-elected! Made stocks surge against majority's predictions on the contrary. I remember well because I made the call! It can happen the other way this time. But I wouldn't get carried away with any Stanley Fischer-esque "normalization" hope with this type of data.
 
Even Trump hinted that "fiscal easing/stimulus" can be the next "good news" theme in global markets. It may all begin with Japan at the end of May, in G20!
 
But you can't trade that next week. You can't trade Brexit fear or fade next week.
 
What you can trade next week is a bet that it won't get as bad as February fears.（下周重量级数据密集，甚至一些三星数据都很重要） And that many have taken risk off and are frustrated with Friday afternoon like surges.
 
Insignificant or not, buybacks the white knight savior are also starting next week.（4-18到5-6，三周） If SPX runs away from people, it will leave them frustrated because majority expected a "real" 'Sell in May' like price action. Not a few points here and there.
 
Next week also brings back my London Macro Dinner. What a suitable opportunity to feel the pulse, positioning and crowdedness of those buses! A brand!
 
What a beautiful weather in London. Enjoy your families. We miss our son in a school trip in Normandie! Leicester to be crowned tonight. Fenerbahce basketball may be crowned European Champions in Berlin next weekend! :)
 
Rest well! We deserved it!
 
4.From: SAMEER GOEL, DEUTSCHE BANK AG SIN <goelsam@bloomberg.net>
At: 06-May-2016 23:26:28
 
'Mediocrity' is maybe the most trending word post NFP. A few thoughts on what the number today means for Asia macro;
 
1. The wait for a tie breaker continues. G3 policy narrative might not provide much guidance over summer; the currency truce is fragile but holding (likely to be reiterated at the G7 summit end of the month); data surprises in Asia have peaked; regional bond underweights have been covered; and the flow momentum has already been slowing down in line with seasonality (see Asia weekly from earlier today). There are several local stories to watch for - tax amnesty in Indonesia, elections in the Philippines, a new MPC in Korea, a new President in Taiwan, etc. But will any of it be sufficient to break the ranges?
 
2. Policymakers need to go back to their drawing boards. If the US labor market too is starting to flat line, and arguably puts Fed out of action for longer, Asian policymakers need to think ahead to what might help  them turn the corner. Leaning more heavily on government spending, Asian versions of QE (bank recaps), recycling current account surpluses, improving monetary policy transmission, unsterilised intervention - the policy dial will need to get cranked up.
 
3. Inching away from the middle of the dollar smile. While this number is not bad enough to make markets panic, but growth/policy capacity concerns are again front and centre, and the fearful part of the dollar smile is not all that far away. Summer will bring with it more risk events, and lower (still) liquidity. Feels like though that for now there might be more to play for in rates (lower curves) in Asia than in FX.    
 
Trades we like at the moment (see weekly for details) - Curve steepeners in Korea; Overlent on China swaps; Overweight duration bias in India, Indonesia & Malaysia; long IDR vs THB; and long Thai linkers. 
 
Sameer Goel

Bob Iger

2.US Daily Economic Notes - Potential pause in payrolls elevates the importance of hours and earnings 05 May 2016 (1 page/ 239 kb)
Commentary for Friday: Over the last three months, private payroll gains have averaged a relatively robust 195k despite well-below-trend real GDP growth. A closer inspection of the sectors responsible for job growth reveals that retail trade accounted for a disproportionate share of the gains in private payrolls last quarter. Over the same period, temp hiring, which has historically been a leading indicator of private payroll growth, declined by -52k. Given an expected slowdown in retail hiring and the disconcerting trend in temp jobs, we expect a below-consensus gain in April payrolls. 
Job gains in the retail trade sector have averaged 60k over the past three months, which is the fastest pace of hiring since the three months ending November 1994 (61k). Retail trade has accounted for 30% of private payroll growth year to date, though the sector only makes up around 13% of private employment. The second-largest contributor to job growth in Q1 was the leisure and hospitality sector, which includes restaurants and hotels. This sector was responsible for 20% of private payroll growth last quarter, though its share of private employment is similar to that of retail. The surge in consumer-related hiring is unusual given the soft growth rate of PCE in the first quarter. Moreover, it was not one particular subsector within retail that was the source of the hiring binge as the gains appear broad based. Our best guess is that retail hiring will slow in April and revert toward its 12-month average of around 30k, which compares to a 48k gain last month. 
Another reason for our conservative forecast is temporary help services. As illustrated in the below chart, the year-over-year change in temp hiring leads that in private payrolls by four months. Admittedly, much of the correlation is driven by recession. However, it is rare for temp jobs to decline so substantially—they are down -6.9% annualized over the last three months—outside of recession. At this point, we do not expect a protracted labor market downturn as jobless claims remain very healthy—the four-week average (258k) is near a four-decade low. However, the expected below-trend April payroll gain, which would be part of an inevitable slowdown in job growth as the labor market approaches full employment, elevates the importance of average hourly earnings and hours worked with respect to overall income growth. 
 
 
3.From: Prateek Jain
Sent: Thursday, May 05, 2016 09:19 PM
Subject: EOD oil note - 5 May
 
Another choppy day in oil, with Alberta fires still raging and prolonged disruption in Libya. Oil rallied more than $2 on several bullish headlines overnight, but gave up the gains midday on stronger USD and bearish equities. WTI spreads continued higher and Jul arb tried to turn positive several times.
- Wildfires in Canada continued to rage, leading to massive evacuation in Fort McMurray. At least 640kbd of crude production is offline due to fires according to Reuters, while PIRA estimates 1mbd disruption. Even though majority of production is north of Fort McMurray, output has been reduced for safety of staff and their families and non-essential staff is being sent home. Threat of power supply disruption also looms, and can further impact operations in the region, even after the fires have been extinguished. Alberta officials stated that they are seeing extreme conditions in wildfire zone, with 49 wildfires still burning, 18 new wildfires yesterday and 7 out of control.
- In Libya, the disruption at Hariga terminal is escalating after Eastern NOC prevented a Glencore tanker from loading, which left the port yesterday. Output is reported to be down 100kbd since the stand-off and can decline another 30-40kbd as storage at Hariga runs out. Libya also ships crude from Hariga terminal to 120kbd refinery in Western Libya. Refining capacity in Eastern Libya is limited, thereby shutting in production in case of export disruptions.
- Saudi raised its Jun Arab Light OSP to Asia by a hefty $1.10, 25c premium to Oman/Dubai. This is in contrast to beliefs that Saudi is in a market share battle with Iran, particularly for Asian buyers.
- Iran NOC official commented that Iran is ready for joint action with OPEC after regaining its pre-sanction market share. Nothing new in this, but in light of comments about production close to 3.8mbd, it is possible that Iran claims to reach pre-sanctions levels in May, just in time for June meeting in hope for a coordinated action. Although if prices remain at current levels or higher by June, it is unlikely that OPEC will take any coordinated action.
- In physical markets, Forties diffs were strong today, bid 50c above last deal on Tuesday. West African market was stable, but yesterday militants attacked Chevron platform in Niger Delta, resulting in the facility being shut after the breach. Extent of damage is not known yet, but Niger Delta Avengers, the same group which caused Forcados disruption, claimed responsibility and said they have blown up the platform. This further highlights the escalating unrest in Nigeria by militants who are demanding greater share of oil revenues.
- Genscape reported a 1.375mb mid-week build at Cushing, larger than expected, but partially contributed by MarketLink pipeline maintenance which began May 2nd . Pipeline capacity is 700kbd but has been running close to 300kbd before being shut. Genscape data covers 2 days of this pipeline downtime (~600kb).
- Refinery outages/restarts:
- Lyondell Houston refinery was restarting a small CDU today after repairs, and stated that refinery runs will increased to 200kbd after restarting the bigger 120kbd CDU sometime next week. Refinery capacity is 264kbd
- Motiva port Arthur refinery (603kbd) completed the restart of its 81kbd gasoline unit, which had been shut since Apr 27th due to a malfunction
Oil Vols

2.WHAT DO I THINK HERE? Is this USD move for real? Crowded & complacent bus gets adjusted and shakes finally, but there's still potential room to go. Both EM & Commodities got hit yesterday & we certainly witnessed some "last in, first out" price action. Stemmed by China PMIs, world growth was questioned yet again, that sent core rates tigher and EM wider. USD "woke up" as part of this risk-off & with favorable positioning. Today is full of key data like non-man ISM, before we turn to NFP Friday. At one point, we'll get more nervous about Brexit polls, too. Motherland politics is tense as well. Softer market yes, sinister I still predict not! I don't know how many times I wrote "EM bus is crowded and tipsy," recently so this correction probably won't end in a day. This should continue for a while. Most fragile one is EM assets because they were the last one standing even as of Friday late afternoon. Still 3 days to play for NFP, but a very low print would bring recession talk. And a healty, big print could hurt the EM yield chase further.
 
3.From: JEROME SARAGOUSSI, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURI <saraje.lndb@bloomberg.net>
At: 04-May-2016 23:13:21
 
US PMI services is the most useful business survey to track quarterly GDP trends. The slight recovery of PMI services in April to 52.8 from 51.4 on average in Q1 is consistent historically with an underlying pace of real GDP growth around 1% SAAR for Q2 so far, a particularly mild recovery from the soft Q1 GDP print.
 
ISM non manufacturing is mostly useful for its employment component as large dislocations between ISM employment and NFP are generally resolved historically via revisions to payrolls towards what ISM is implying.(no,adp更敏感) This employment component has increased from 53 from 50.3 and the ISM composite employment index has recovered towards 52 from 49.5, which historically has been consistent with ~120k 3M MA of private payrolls (see chart below). This is a 1-sigma dislocation against consensus ~210k but keep in mind that ISM employment was implying NFP close to zero in March, a 2-sigma dislocation which did NOT translate into soft NFP data.（作者也承认这种估算误差很大） Using the input from ADP on top of ISM employment, the theoretical 3M MA of NFP would be closer to 160k, hence still downside risk to NFP relative consensus.
 
 
ISM non manuf employment has been sending a wrong signal about the softness of NFP reports in February and March. However we note that the NFP strength in Feb and March was accompanied by a collapse of the average weekly hours from 34.6 in January to 34.4 in Feb and March. In spite of the very positive change in NFP in Feb and March, labor input growth was particularly soft because of the decline in average weekly hours worked by the workforce. This drop in labor input growth was aligned with the sofness of ISM employment in spite of the strength in NFP (see chart below). 
 
 
The recovery in ISM employment in April would be consistent with a recovery in labor input growth towards 0.2/0.3% MoM in April. If the average weekly hours are stable at 34.4, this labor input growth should come entirely from job creation and change in NFP could be 200k+, if however consensus is right and the average weekly hours normalize from 34.4 to 34.5, an increase by 0.3% MoM, then this would provide the right labor input growth even in the absence of job creation and payroll could 'theoretically' be close to zero.（很可能啊） In other words the recent volatility in average weekly hours has reduced significantly the signal-to-noise ratio of dislocations between ISM Employment vs. NFP and it is critical to assess the strength of the job report on the basis of the NFP and AWH releases simultaneously. 
 
 
 
3.Global Economic Perspectives - US consumers: saving more, spending less   储蓄率升高之谜04 May 2016 (13 pages/ 549 kb)
After accelerating from 2013 through mid-2015, consumer spending growth has slowed noticeably in recent months. This slowdown has been accompanied by a steady rise in the consumer saving rate. These are worrying trends for the near-term US outlook if they persist, since the consumer has been the main pillar of strength for US growth throughout this recovery. 
The rise in the saving rate has been somewhat puzzling to us, as many of the drivers of savings have pointed to a lower, not higher, rate. The Fed also appeared to be surprised by these developments in its April statement, noting that consumer spending growth seems to be inconsistent with relatively supportive fundamentals. 
We consider the drivers of the recent rise in the saving rate. We find some evidence that wealth effects have declined and that the fall in oil prices and low interest rates also contributed to higher savings. Other structural factors (e.g., a stronger preference for saving driven by greater uncertainty about the economic outlook and more income inequality) on balance likely argue for a higher saving rate relative to pre-crisis as well.
Looking ahead, we think the saving rate can stabilize and even drift slightly lower, but a decline that significantly boosts consumer spending is unlikely unless wealth rises sharply. Moreover, the saving rate is likely to stay above the levels observed in the mid-2000s. 
For the outlook, this means that growth is likely to pickup but remain moderate, with limited upside pressure on inflation. Thus, a cautious and gradual approach to normalization by the Fed remains appropriate. A structurally higher saving rate relative to before the crisis will also put downward pressure on, or at least help restrain the rise in, the neutral fed funds rate over the coming years. 
 
4.US Daily Economic Notes - A sluggish start to spring for the labor market? 04 May 2016 (1 page/ 236 kb)
Commentary for Thursday: The April ADP private employment survey results were disappointing: We learned that 156k private-sector jobs were created last month, which is the smallest increase since April 2013 (118k). This is consistent with our forecast of a below-consensus 165k gain in private employment this Friday—we project a slightly better 175k increase in headline nonfarm payrolls. Preliminary evidence that employment is slowing would be consistent with our expectation that the rebound from another disappointing Q1 GDP reading will be relatively mild, at least compared to the Q2 quarterly growth rates from 2015 and 2014 (3.9% and 4.6%, respectively). At present, we expect current-quarter growth of 1.0%, followed by a 1.2% gain next quarter and then a 2.4% increase in Q4. We anticipate a late-year rebound for two reasons: One, energy-related capital expenditures (capex) should improve in lagged response to the bounce back in oil prices. To be clear, we do not assume a resumption of strongly positive growth in energy capex, but even slight gains in energy outlays would be accretive to economic output. Two, and more importantly, we expect that inventory liquidation will have largely run its course. In turn, we could see a jump in real GDP. If we are wrong, and output shows little acceleration in the back half of the year, the next Fed tightening would likely be pushed into 2017. 
In the chart below, we show the initial monthly change of ADP private employment compared to that of BLS private payrolls. We can see that the two series are highly correlated. The relatively soft April ADP gain is noteworthy because it is more than one standard deviation below the 12-month trailing average (206k). To be sure, ADP employment often misses the BLS private payroll figure. The absolute difference between the initial readings of the two series over the past 12 months has averaged 39k. In the details of the ADP survey, the category that captures retail hiring was up only 25k, compared to 42k previously. Retail hiring within the BLS report has been unusually strong, averaging approximately 60k over the past three months, which is well above its 12-month trailing average of 32k. The ADP report also showed a -13k decline in manufacturing-sector hiring, which is consistent with the weakness in the employment components of the various PMIs. 
For us to be more concerned about a broader labor market slowdown, we would need to see some confirmation in the weekly jobless claims data. As long as claims, which effectively proxy layoffs, remain near record-low readings, the general health of the labor market should remain intact. 
 
5.FX Daily - Trading the April Payrolls report 04 May 2016 (5 pages/ 325 kb)
The April payroll report is particularly important since it will provide valuable input on whether i) the labor market sidestepped tighter financial conditions in Q1; ii) investment in labor can continue to decouple from physical investment in machinery and equipment; or decouple from a softer corporate profits profile; and, iii) weak Q1 Temp employment has been a precursor to broader payrolls weakness. 
 
After the April ADP figure, the market is likely pricing in a NFP number toward the bottom of the 160K – 315K economist range, i.e. a number broadly in line with DB's 175K forecast. 
A payroll report consistent with the 200K median would work with Fed comments that both the June and July FOMC meetings are 'live' - a view the markets will only take seriously as the main preconditions for another rate hike (including continued solid April and May employment reports) are fulfilled. 
Yellen has said a real funds rate of zero, and therefore a nominal funds rate of 1.5% - 1.75%, is consistent with 'neutral' currently.   Arguably a 200K number fits with the Fed's 'gradual' (two hikes this year) move toward neutral. 
A 200K type NFP number would then be mildly USD positive. It would work with thoughts that recent USD weakness has overshot. A favored rebuild in long USD exposure is versus the commodity currencies notably AUD (a trade helped by valuation considerations) and CAD (given sensitivity to Fed policy). 
A 200K payroll report in line with the Bloomberg median would not be bad for vol inasmuch as keeping a Fed summer hike a possibility will also maintain market sensitivity to US data. 
A resumption of the U3 rate heading down would go a long way to putting the Fed under more pressure to respond to strong NFP data.  One of the reasons Janet Yellen has been able to maintain a dovish stance in the face of the recent strong NFP data is precisely that the U3 rate has drifted up with increased labor participation, supporting her thesis that there is still some slack left in the labor market. 
In contrast, a weaker payroll number in the 100k - 125K range would seriously dent expectations of a rate hike before the US election and would encourage very selective short USD exposure, of which short USD/JPY is preferred, not least because this trade would also stand up to even softer numbers and more elevated global growth concerns. 
A genuinely weak sub-100K number would probably be USD negative only versus the JPY and perhaps CHF and EUR, as growth-dependent commodity currencies and EM would likely seriously underperform on fears of another significant down step in global growth, against a backdrop of reduced policy efficacy.   
As for the number itself, a few elements hint at weakness: i) the April data may finally capture Q1 tightening in financial conditions; ii) as Joe Lavorgna and team note, recent weakness in temp workers is often a precursor to broader labor market weakening; iii) a long-term concern is that this cycle is unusual whereby investment in capital goods is so weak, but investment in labor is so strong; and, iv) similarly, persistent employment decoupling from the profit cycle is unusual, even if the lag between profits and NFP is long.

2.Michael Sullivan - Energy Sector Sales - Crude Sell off thoughts——原油暴跌似乎有点儿莫名其妙，可能就是程序化交易的结果

Reuters has a story out today suggesting one of China’s largest teapot refinery may cut
back on near-term crude imports (logistical bottlenecks/high storage levels there + looming maintenance). 3.意外发现营改增还有这好处——交易成本降低了，交易活跃了，市场深度恢复了
 
Asia Rates Strategy Notes - China: VAT exemptions reduce liquidity risk 03 May 2016 (1 page/ 81 kb)
Interest income from pledged repo financing and policy bank bonds investment will be exempt from VAT
China took a key fiscal reform measure on May 1 2016 with the nation-wide launch of Valued Added Tax (VAT) pilot program. Over the past two weeks, the onshore RMB fixed income market has become increasingly nervous over the possible negative implications of the VAT such as higher interbank funding costs and a widening of credit spreads of financial bonds. In our report on April 21 2016, we expressed our view that the market could have overacted and we do not think the VAT implementation will have significant impact on bond/rates pricing.
On April 29th, the Ministry of Finance issued “Notice on further clarifications of VAT implementation in the financial sector”. Specifically, the Notice confirmed that the interest income earned from pledged repo transactions on financial products and from policy bank bonds investment should be considered as interest income from inter-financial institutions therefore should be exempt from the VAT.
(a) It affirms our view that liquidity condition should start to renormalize in May. As pledged repo （质押式回购，这么翻译的啊）is the most common type of repo transactions (about 93% of the outstanding interbank repos), the immediate market reaction is to unwind the 10-14bps premium on interbank repo rates, and we expect the overnight and 7D repo rate to range between 1.9-2.1% and 2.15-2.35% respectively. Moreover, we expect the PBoC will keep liquidity accommodation to support lending growth. We estimate in April, the PBoC net injected RMB350bn via MLFs and 7D reverse repo operations and letting RMB167bn SLFs matured and RMB3.6bn PSLs to be repaid. It will continue to offer monthly PSLs to support targeted long term financing. On a YTD basis, the PBoC has maintained its liquidity accommodation with about RMB2951bn net liquidity injection, albeit at somewhat slower pace than it was in March (with RRR cut). As the capital flow balances likely will remain weak as a driver for money supply growth, we expect the PBoC continue to release liquidity via a combination of its liquidity tools.
(b) The relatively prompt clarification on the VAT for the financial sector lends support to our view that it is critical to stabilize liquidity condition in order to stabilize financing activities in the primary market and mitigate the negative spillover from credit events. Recent credit events have already led to decent re-pricing in the bond market and leverage reduction by speculative investors, which is healthy in our view to reduce the overall bond market risk. However, given there has been over RMB100bn cancellation/postponing of corporate credit issuances during March - April, we think further tightening in liquidity will likely exert upward pressure on financing costs across all bond assets, including CGBs, municipal bonds and financial bonds and significantly slow down corporate refinancing activities. Two corporations successfully raised funding in the market last week, indicating that the corporate credit market has begun to restore its primary financing function.
(c).Credit spread of policy bank bonds is likely to narrow by 10-15bps (to around 35-40bps for 10Y CDB), negating the widening in credit spreads due to VAT concerns over the past two weeks.
 
 
4.From: Prateek Jain
Sent: Tuesday, May 03, 2016 10:09 PM
Subject: EOD oil note - 3 May
 
Crude prices had a correction last 2 days, partially selling off along with bearish macro sentiment and weak PMI data from China. OPEC April production estimates also came in higher than expected as Iran, Iraq and Saudi produced more, offsetting declines in Nigeria and Venezuela. EIA revisions for Feb were also mildly bearish and rains in Venezuela over the weekend provided a short breather for the crisis. Geopolitical risk however, continues to be high and Venezuela, Nigeria and Libya remain on close watch.
- OPEC production estimates for April are 485kbd above Mar, as Iran added 300kbd, Iraq brought back 160kbd (after pipeline restart) and Saudi increased by 80kbd. Some other third party estimates however indicate only 160kbd increase as lower output from Angola, Nigeria and Venezuela offset the gain.
- Russian oil output for April was 10.84mbd, lower 60kbd m/m due to Gazprom maintenance, but up 170kbd y/y. Crude exports posted a record high 4.96mbd, up 460kbd y/y, as tax changes favored exports over refining domestically.
- EIA revised Feb US oil demand lower by 72kbd, while revising total stocks up by 4mb (gasoline +3mb). Production was revised lower by 12kbd compared to weekly estimates. However, implied production was down 266kbd, compared to 195kbd indicated by weekly reports.
- Iraq Basrah exports for last week increased to 3.543mbd, bringing April average to 3.383mbd – 100kbd above scheduled exports (March exports were 150kbd below scheduled, so April exports are partial catch up to that). May exports are scheduled at 3.09mbd, well below current export levels. Exports via Ceyhan also increased marginally to 514kbd, with April averaging 503kbd, slightly above expectations as 150kbd Kirkuk output remains shut.
- Reuters wrote a detailed report on congestion at import terminals in China due to buying frenzy from teapot refineries in Q1, leading to port congestion and stockpiles which can take 2-3 months to clear. Moreover, increased refinery maintenance in Q2 would reduce China import demand further. However, there were reports on this last few weeks as well, so it isn’t a new development.
- Venezuela received some rain over the weekend, helping Guri dam levels to increase by 0.1m to 241.57m, but still not far from shutdown level of 240m. Guri dam produces over 60% of domestic power, and low water levels have forced government to impose rolling blackouts.
- Refinery outages eased over the weekend putting pressure on gasoline and cracks, but some new ones surfaced later today
- Reuters reported yesterday that Motiva Port Arthur’s 81kbd FCC which was shut on Apr 27th due to malfunction is expected to restart Tuesday, compared to initial estimates of 7-10 days of repair work. However, further reports today suggested that it may take up to Wed or Thu to restart.
- Lyondell Basell expects to boost output at its 264kbd Houston refinery this week, after the restart of a VDU on Sunday night. The refinery has been running at 32% capacity since April 15th, when the VDU was shut.
- The 135kbd Pipe Still 7 CDU at 560kbd Exxon Baytown refinery was shut Monday evening due to a malfunction, though Exxon commented that impact on production will be minimal. This is second time in three weeks that this unit is out of production, and the previous outage lasted 2 days
- Chevron reported an unplanned shutdown of one of the units at 330kbd Pascagoula refinery on Apr 29th.
- Libya’s Eastern NOC (unofficial) has disrupted loadings at the 140kbd Hariga terminal, telling its workers not to load the tanker which had been waiting since 2 days. This is in response to the failed attempt at exporting crude by the Eastern NOC last week, after UN blacklisted the vessel and  returned it to a port in western Libya. Any prolonged delay at Hariga terminal raises the risk of Libyan production falling back to 250kbd.
- APIs just came out reporting a below expectation 1.3mb crude build, with Cushing stocks adding 380kb. Gasoline inventories fell 1.2mb as several refineries faced outages. Disty continued to draw strongly, with stocks falling by 2.6mb last week with another week of strong agricultural demand.
 
 
5.US Daily Economic Notes - Preliminary Q2 data point to shallow rebound ——我有点儿信了03 May 2016 (1 page/ 220 kb)
Commentary for Wednesday: When the week is complete, we will have updates on our five top economic indicators, namely, the manufacturing ISM survey (Monday), the Fed's Senior Loan Officer Survey (Monday), unit motor vehicle sales (Tuesday), jobless claims (Thursday) and employee tax withholding receipts (daily). The news this quarter remains mixed at best and suggests that the projected rebound in growth could be quite modest, at least relative to the previous two Q2s（前两年的Q2）: Recall that growth bounced back to 4.6% in 2014 and 3.9% in 2015. Economic activity recovered in Q2 in each of the last two years partly because the foregoing Q1 weakness was related to harsh winter weather. Last year, Q1 output was also hurt by the West Coast port slowdown. In fact, net exports subtracted 190 basis points off Q1 2015 real GDP growth. This was the largest hit to output from the external sector since Q1 1984, when the US dollar was in the midst of an extended period of appreciation. 
The fact that growth was so weak last quarter despite the lack of any extenuating factors does not bode well for growth in the next few quarters. As we noted in yesterday's US Daily Economic Notes, inventory positions remain elevated relative to slowing aggregate demand. For example, final sales to private domestic purchasers were up only 1.2% last quarter, the slowest growth rate since Q3 2012 (0.9%). Meanwhile, nonresidential fixed investment was down -5.9%, and there is evidence that this weakness was not due to weak energy-related spending alone. With the US Presidential Election soon to enter full swing, we doubt the corporate sector will significantly ratchet up spending soon. By contrast, the strongest major component of Q1 GDP was residential investment, which was up 14.8%, affirming our view that housing is a bright spot in an otherwise fragile economic outlook. On balance, we believe that growth is likely to disappoint again this quarter; we continue to forecast 1.0% Q2 2016 real GDP growth, as we did back in early February when we penciled in our strongly non-consensus call of a 0.5% gain in Q1 2016 GDP. 
In terms of our aforementioned indicators, the April manufacturing ISM slipped one point to 50.8, while the Fed's Senior Loan Officer Survey showed a further tightening in lending standards for commercial and industrial loans, which are highly correlated with economic activity: Tightening standards often foreshadow slowing growth. At the time of this writing, motor vehicle sales were expected to rebound to over a 17M annualized rate, which if sustained would point to an improvement in retail sales. Jobless claims are likely to continue to remain near record-low readings, which suggest the job market is still healthy. However, as our regular readers know, employee tax withholding receipts continue to slow, with their year-over-year rate now down below 3%. This hints to us that while job gains may continue to be healthy in the short term, underlying income growth is not particularly robust. This would explain why overall inflation-adjusted consumer spending has not been stronger despite the sharp drop in gasoline prices that began in the summer of 2014 and the nearly 5 million jobs that have been created since then.

2.US Economics Weekly - Q1 GDP disappoints yet again, but Q2 rebound less certain 29 April 2016 (7 pages/ 455 kb)
可能的确是增长乏力了 
Overview: The initial snapshot of Q1 real GDP growth showed an economy that expanded at just a 0.5% annualized rate. This was the second consecutive quarter in which growth was meaningfully softer than its post-recession trend. Most troubling to us was the broad-based weakness within the report and the fact that inventory positions remain elevated. The upshot is that we are likely to see only a modest recovery in output this quarter and next. In turn, the Fed is likely to remain on the sidelines. 
Peeling back the onion of recent job growth: Over the last three months, private payroll gains have averaged a relatively robust 195k despite well-below-trend real GDP growth. A closer look at the sectors responsible for job growth last quarter reveals that retail trade accounted for a little over 30% of the 586k gain in private payrolls. In fact, the 181k increase in retail hiring was the largest three-month gain since November 1994. Over the same period, temp hiring, which has historically been a leading indicator of private payroll growth, declined by -52k. Given an expected slowdown in retail hiring and the disconcerting trend in temporary help services, we expect a below-consensus gain of 165k in April private payrolls, released next Friday. 
 
3.US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 29 April 2016 (1 page/ 220 kb)
Commentary for Monday: The economic calendar is filled with key data beginning today with the manufacturing ISM survey, which is one of our top five economic series for investors to follow. While the sector accounts for only around 10% of GDP, manufacturing activity is highly correlated with the former. Hence, it is prudent for market participants to closely follow the ISM index, which we expect to slip back below 50. If so, this would provide preliminary evidence that the projected Q2 rebound will be quite modest following yet another soft start for GDP growth—the third consecutive year of well-below trend Q1 output. The construction spending figures will take a backseat to the manufacturing ISM, but any surprises in the former may impact expectations for Q1 GDP revisions, which are released on May 27. 
Throughout the day tomorrow, we get April unit motor vehicle sales (17.2 million forecast vs. 16.5 million previously)（谣传17.5）, which are another favorite indicator of ours. Auto sales should rebound in April after a very disappointing March, but gains will likely be limited going forward. This reflects two factors: One, there is much less pent up demand than there was earlier in the cycle. Last year's 17.3 million annual selling rate was the best since 2000 (17.4 million). Two, the subprime-share of auto lending has risen close to its record high, which may suggest a future dearth of credit-worthy borrowers. If this is the case, then further gains in vehicle sales may be limited. 
On Wednesday morning we get the April ADP private employment survey. We are projecting a 165k increase, which is moderately below the last couple of 200k-plus increases. This will be followed by the March international trade balance (-$41.0 billion vs. -$47.1 billion), which will show a substantial narrowing based on the already-reported drop in the advance international goods trade deficit. At the same time as international trade, the BLS will release Q1 productivity (-1.3% vs. -2.2%), which is poised to contract for the second consecutive quarter. This should result in a boost to unit labor costs (+2.2% vs. +3.3%) but their growth rate would still be quite modest—similar to the year-over-year change in the Q1 employment cost index (ECI). Later on Wednesday morning, we get March factory orders (+2.0% vs. -1.7%), which should be lifted by a modest rebound in nondurable goods, a function of the recovery in petroleum prices. The non-manufacturing ISM survey (54.0 vs. 54.5) is the last of Wednesday's data releases. This series should remain near its recent reading as the service sector remains relatively healthy compared to the subdued performance of the manufacturing side of the economy. 
The only data release on Thursday is jobless claims, which are projected to rise slightly from a nearly four-decade low (265k vs. 257k). Friday's April employment report is the main highlight of the economic data docket this week. We estimate that nonfarm payrolls increased a still-respectable +175k last month compared to 215k, previously. The results should be mildly less robust for private payrolls (165k vs. 195k). The unemployment rate is poised to remain at 5.0%, and the nonfarm workweek is expected to edge up to 34.5 hours from 34.4 hours, previously. Similar to what we saw in the Q1 ECI, average hourly earnings (+0.2% vs. +0.3%) should show subdued wage pressures, as their year-over-year growth rate should remain in the low 2s. The week concludes with March consumer credit ($14.0 billion vs. $17.2 billion), but investors will have had plenty to digest by then and will likely ignore it. 
 
4.US Daily Economic Notes - Unless demand accelerates, a larger inventory correction is ahead 02 May 2016 (1 page/ 235 kb)
Commentary for Tuesday: Last week's advance Q1 2016 GDP report indicated that inventory accumulation declined to $60.9 billion from $78.3 billion previously. As a result, inventories took 33 basis points off GDP growth. At first blush, this suggests that the economy made progress in working off excessive inventories last quarter, implying that inventories would be less of a drag on manufacturing activity and top-line GDP growth for the rest of the year. 
Unfortunately, aggregate demand decelerated considerably faster than inventories. Final sales of domestic product, measured as GDP minus inventory accumulation, were up just 0.9% last quarter, compared to 3.9% as recently as Q2 2015. Consequently, the ratio of inventories to final sales actually increased last quarter to its highest level since Q4 2008. The chart below shows this series along with our estimate of its time trend. The trend is estimated from 1985 to 2007 (and projected thereafter), during which time the ratio trended steadily downwards, likely due to improvements in inventory-management technology. The trend line suggests that inventory levels remain very elevated. Unless aggregate demand accelerates substantially, we are likely to see a much larger unwind of inventories than has occurred thus far. While it is difficult to precisely predict the timing and magnitude of inventory liquidation (these depend on manufacturers' estimates of future demand), our time trend estimate gives a sense of how much inventories could weigh on growth in the next few quarters. At present, the level of inventories is about $90 billion above trend. Given our cautious outlook on aggregate demand, inventories may not return to trend until next year. Consequently, the need for further de-stocking is a downside risk to our GDP forecast. 
To be sure, time trend estimates are somewhat arbitrary, and the actual inventory unwind might be considerably smaller than we have estimated. However, the above analysis underscores the pernicious nature of the ongoing growth slowdown. While aggregate demand did rebound from similarly weak levels in 2012, inventory levels were below trend at the time. Therefore, inventory accumulation picked up meaningfully in response to expected (and realized) acceleration in demand, amplifying the effect of the latter on top-line growth. By contrast, even if demand were to recover later this year, the best we can likely hope for is that inventory accumulation will not slow. In other words, inventories are expected to dull the positive impact of a potential demand recovery, and exacerbate the deleterious effects of a further slowdown in demand. 
 
5.Commodities Digest - Can the oil rally continue?——rather bullish
29 April 2016 (7 pages/ 542 kb)
 
Download the complete report: http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/8691-78D8/49805126/DB_CommodsWkly_2016-04-29_0900b8c08b124b6d.pdf<http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/8691-78D8/49805126/DB_CommodsWkly_2016-04-29_0900b8c08b124b6d.pdf>
 
Crude Oil: Can the oil rally continue?
 
Asking the question of how sustainable the rally is should probably be put in perspective by remembering that oil prices fell sharply in late August 2015 to USD 42/bbl Brent in sympathy with the Shanghai Composite but then rallied quickly back to USD 54/bbl.  So USD 47-48/bbl may still be regarded as a moderate price in this context.
 
Admittedly, our worry that the rally would pause has been premature.  Floating storage inventory, although high, has only moved to a new record high.  The same can be said for non-commercial investor positioning.
 
Looking ahead, there is one key factor which could continue to drive positive sentiment.  We are nearing an inflection point in US inventories at the end of April, when seasonal builds typically turn to seasonal draws as refineries return to service in preparation for the summer demand period.  On our estimates this means that inventories could begin to level out and then fall over the course of Q2, although perhaps not as quickly as we project if US production again shows resilience.  Other possible drivers could be US vehicle miles travelled which grew by 4.6% yoy in February on a seasonally adjusted basis (highest growth rate since 5.0% in Jan 2015) and US product demand which has seen a string of four relatively strong weeks.
 
It is not until Q3 that OPEC production upside could be a dampener, according to our review of current outages (Looking forward to OPEC in 2017, 28 April 2016).  An as-scheduled restart in UAE and Nigerian production, combined with a continued Iranian ramp-up could result in OPEC production exceeding our Q3-2016 assumption by 370-470 kb/d.  We believe our 2017 assumption of 33.1 mmb/d of OPEC production, however, remains sound.
 
Iron ore: It's not all about speculation
 
We agree that, the rally in iron ore and steel has been turbo charged by speculation. One only has to look at iron ore trading volumes on the Dalian exchange (Figure 1) and the SGX Asiaclear (Figure 2) to find evidence of this. The dramatic increase and volatility in prices is reminiscent of the rally and subsequent collapse of the Shanghai Composite index in early 2015 (Figure 3). The Chinese authorities have however moved far more quickly to cool the degree of speculation, but increasing margin limits, trading fees and shortening trading hours. We think this has had an immediate effect with iron ore shedding USD10/t in a week, and the near term spreads on the forward curve moving back into a backwardated position, after a brief foray into contango (Figure 4).
 
However, there is more to it than just credit fueled speculation. Whilst we can debate about how long the cyclical recovery will last (for the record we have said that the peak in total social financing is likely in June, based on the 12/13 cycle), there are real signs of improving demand beyond a simple restocking event from low levels. Our China real activity index has rebounded sharply, and is heading close to breaking into positive territory for the first since November 2014 (Figure 5). In response to the improving outlook, steel mills have been increasing output (Figure 6), but so far we have not seen a dramatic increase in inventory (Figure 7). Even the closely watched property indicators have shown some signs of life, with momentum in floor space sold, and importantly floor space started (Figure 8). We would however point out that although we think the peak in the Chinese credit cycle is mostly likely in June, iron ore pricing momentum stayed positive well beyond the credit cycle (Figure 9).

2016-04-29 随手札记

2.Looking ahead to OPEC in 2017
Download  the complete report: http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/13473-72A9/64132739/DB_SpecialReport_2016-04-28_0900b8c08b10618e.pdf  
 
Unplanned outages have complicated the outlook 
Despite the rise in Iranian production of +390 kb/d since December of last year, a spate of disruptions in Iraq, Nigeria and UAE have meant that OPEC production  has instead declined two months in a row from January.  The implication is that a sustainable rise in OPEC production may be just around the corner, and that the rally may pause for breath in the third quarter as it has taken place in the context of these  outages. 
UAE maintenance may conclude in April 
Maintenance in the UAE at fields supplying the Murban grade of crude oil began in February.  Although production was reportedly affected by 350 kb/d, we  observed only a 180 kb/d reduction from the preceding six month average.  The maintenance period is scheduled to end in April, implying a rise from current production of 2.73 mmb/d to the previous 2.91 mmb/d production rate in May. 
Nigeria pipeline attacks will affect production at least until June 
A series of two pipeline attacks have affected the ability of field production to reach ports in Nigeria.  A leak appeared in the 48-inch underwater Forcados  Pipeline in February, triggering Shell to declare force majeure, while a different pipeline experienced an outage in April.  Return to service may take some time and leaves production down by 150 kb/d for the time being. 
Iraqi dispute restricts NOC flows to Kurdish pipeline  
The completion in 2013 of the independent Kurdistan Export Pipeline running from the Taq Taq field to Turkey has luckily meant that the portion of Kirkuk  field operated by the North Oil Company has been able to export following the Islamic State occupation in June 2014.  However this flow of 150 kb/d has been halted by the Iraqi government in a continuation of a ongoing revenue dispute with the Kurdistan Regional  Government and may remain shut for some time. 
A further Iranian ramp is likely 
Iranian production has grown from 2.87 mmb/d in November 2015 and was reported to be up to as much as 3.5 mmb/d on 16 April according to Reuters, with  further upside to 3.7 mmb/d by the second half of 2017 mainly on account of some of its largest and oldest oilfields.   
OPEC central case and Q3 upside 
Taken together, these developments lead to our conclusion that total OPEC production in 2017 is likely to be in line with our existing assumption of 33.1  mmb/d, with upside risks originating from Libya and Saudi Arabia, and downside risks from unplanned outages and spending cuts in Iraq.  However, there is 370-470 kb/d upside to our Q3-2016 assumption of 32.6 mmb/d if restarts in UAE and Nigeria occur either  on time or with minor delays.  Alternatively, a five-month delay to these restarts would imply no change to our Q3 assumption.
 
3.From: Alan Ruskin
Sent: Thursday, April 28, 2016 02:54 PM
Subject: Alpha Alert – BOJ/JPY big picture, 5 big questions
 
Alpha Alert –BOJ/JPY  big picture, 5 big questions
 
·         Did US Treasury/Yellen end Abeconomics?  No, but the pivot to focusing on USD-China has contributed to the demise of a weak yen policy that has been (too) central to Abeconomics.
 
·         In baseball terms we are probably still in the first or maybe second innings of Japan life and pension fund buying yen to add to their hedge ratios on their foreign assets that will add to a broader market tendency to sell any USD/JPY upticks.
 
·         Japan has likely added to the international constraints against intervening, since intervention after not easing, works against the desired G20 protocol of focusing on domestic policy rather than the exchange rate.  Speed could be used as ‘an excuse’ for action, although intervention should not be expected until much closer to Y100.
 
·         BOJ has limited immediate implications for the Fed or its policy capacities, and the weaker USD is obviously helpful for US equities. EM risk should take its lead from US risk bellwethers like the S&P and not the Nikkei.
 
·         The bigger picture USD recovery story remains as dependent as ever on the Fed tightening this summer, and the BOJ’s actions won’t change the Fed’s reaction function materially.
1.  Is this the end of Abeconomics?
Without the third arrow, Abeconomics was too heavily dependent on unorthodox monetary policy that works through three main channels (portfolio displacement, the price of credit, and the exchange rate).  Arguably all three channels are faltering badly, including the most powerful channel, the exchange rate.  The problem Abeconomics faced, was that there has been a global pivot to focusing on USD-China, and by early this year additional USD strength was seen  as negative for US, China and global risk.  Japan has been caught in the fall-out of a less strong USD, and is now in an independent loop where yen strength drives an increase in Japan hedge ratios on foreign assets that drives yen strength.  Did US Treasury/Yellen end Abeconomics?  No, but they are contributing to its demise.
2.    What innings are we in for Japanese hedging?
The relatively light hedge ratios from the long 2011 - 2015 period of yen weakness, only received serious review when USD/JPY went below Y115.  In baseball terms we are probably still in the first or maybe second innings of Japan life and pension fund hedging of their foreign assets.    There may be a gap between  Y100 and  ~Y103 when Japan hedging disappears as participants watch to see if Y100 holds, but below Y100 hedge related yen purchases would accelerate again!
3.  Will the BOJ intervene?
As suggested in earlier Alpha Alerts, when it comes to intervention, speed is much more important than levels, especially since the JPY is still far from ‘expensive’ by any metric.   What is new is that in many ways Japan has just added to the international constraints against intervening.   If the BOJ eased even incrementally, and the Yen strengthened the MOF and the BOJ could point to ‘the perverse’ FX market reaction.  However intervening after not easing, would run against the desired G20 protocol of focusing on getting domestic policy right (and in this case the need for more accommodation) rather than focusing on the exchange rate.   An obvious additional constraint to intervention is that it is apt to work like a red rag to a yen bull, and we would expect heavy selling into any BOJ inspired pop in USD/JPY.  There is close to no chance of any coordinated actions unless Japan events become globally systemic which is unlikely.  In the end speed could be used as ‘an excuse’ for action, although intervention or at least an unofficial bid, should not be expected much above Y100.
 4. What are the implications for other risky assets?
The BOJ inaction is without question a comment on Central Bank’s diminished ammunition.  Nonetheless, for the US, the BOJ has limited immediate implications for the Fed or its policy capacities, and the weaker USD is obviously helpful for US equities.  Do not expect follow through in US equity market sell-off, at least as it relates to international events.   EM risk should similarly take its lead from US risk bellwethers like the S&P and not the Nikkei.
5.  How should the yen move impact other currencies?
Arguably G10 currencies, are each dancing to their own drummer.  There is nothing here to suggest the top end of the EUR/USD range between 1.14 and 1.15 is not a sell.  GBP is a Brexit story.  AUD has hit m/t valuation constraints near 0.78, Kiwi probably near 0.70.  USD/JPY is still a sell any upticks strategy as per the above, which fits with ongoing ‘normalization’ of CNY/JPY lower.    The bigger picture USD recovery story remains as dependent as ever on the Fed tightening this summer, and the BOJ’s actions won’t change the Fed’s reaction function materially.
 
 
4.BOJ进退两难，认为日本央妈已经处于失败的边缘
 Bank of Japan Finds It Can't Win Either Way: Mohamed A. El-Erian
 
By Mohamed A. El-Erian
 
Pity the Bank of Japan. Disappointed by the central bank’s decision at Thursday’s policy meeting to delay further stimulus measures, markets pushed the yen higher, making exports less competitive, and drove share prices lower, which damped animal spirits. This makes the prospects for a recovery of Japanese growth even dimmer.
     Yet these reactions are similar to those of a few weeks ago, when the central bank surprised markets with its activism, taking policy rates into nominal negative territory.
     QuickTakeAbenomics
     Although it is unfamiliar in advanced economies, this seemingly inconsistent market behavior is quite common in emerging economies where policy ineffectiveness is a concern. And it speaks to an important reality: Among the systemically important central banks, the Bank of Japan has come closest to the line that separates effective policy measures from ineffective, if not counterproductive ones.
     Central bank stimulus is one of the three "arrows" that the Japanese government said it would use in a renewed effort to decisively pull the economy out of two decades of economic stagnation. In practice, however, considerable central bank activism -- in the form of negative interest rates and large- scale asset purchases (both in magnitude and coverage) -- has been accompanied by inconsistent implementation of fiscal actions and insufficient structural reforms.
     As the other two arrows failed to fully materialize, the Bank of Japan decided earlier this year to experiment further with unconventional monetary policy. But its attempts produced counterintuitive results, including an appreciation of the yen even as interest-rate differentials and asset purchases were widening compared with the rest of the world. The result was to expose the central bank to considerable public questioning, in particular through the political process.
     In such an environment, it is understandable that officials decided on Thursday to hold off further policy activism. But in doing so, they find themselves in a Catch-22 of contributing to anti-growth asset-price movements seemingly regardless of what they do or don’t do.
     Such a policy outcome is rare in advanced economies, where policy credibility and institutional robustness are taken as givens. After all, central banks in these economies can even affect outcomes through verbal intervention, including the deployment of the all-powerful "whatever it takes" mantra.
     These kinds of results are far more common in emerging economies where policy credibility and institutional strengths aren’t established. That often is demonstrated when central banks lose control of the currency -- most in the context of disorderly depreciations -- almost regardless of their interest rate actions.
     The Bank of Japan’s policy predicament should be monitored very closely by other central banks, starting with the European Central Bank and the People’s Bank of China -- which, along with the Federal Reserve, have been forced to rely on the prolonged use of unconventional policy actions and forward guidance to keep their economies humming in the absence of a comprehensive policy response.
     The market response on Thursday highlights the urgent need for a policy handoff -- away from over-reliance on central banks and toward measures that involve pro-growth structural reforms, a rebalancing of aggregate demand, addressing pockets of over- indebtedness and improving regional and global policy coordination.
     The advanced world already has experienced one unpleasant set of circumstances that is more common to emerging economies: structural rather than cyclical headwinds to economic recovery. Now some of these developed economies may be about to experience another unfamiliar form of disruption. The Bank of Japan’s evolving experience should serve as an important warning sign that central banks should take seriously the risk of growing policy ineffectiveness. 
     This column does not necessarily reflect the opinion of the editorial board or Bloomberg LP and its owners.

2.US Daily Economic Notes - The tepid trend in tax receipts bears watching 27 April 2016 (1 page/ 227 kb)
Commentary for Thursday: The latest economic data have been mixed: The labor market figures have been relatively robust, but other series such as retail sales and various surveys of business sentiment have generally been soft. When the economic data send conflicting signals with respect to the near-term outlook, it is useful to focus on series that investors may overlook. Withheld income tax receipts are one of our favorite indicators, and the recent trend in this series has elevated our concern about overall income growth.
Withheld income tax receipts are highly volatile on a daily basis and are subject to changes in the tax code. Hence, we smooth the daily data in order to distill the monthly and quarterly trends and adjust the series for changes in the tax code. As the chart below indicates, the growth rate of withheld income tax receipts began to trend lower in Q4 of last year, and has continued to deteriorate through April. As a reminder, these data track taxes withheld from employees' paychecks and do not include estimated tax payments, which citizens pay each April. At present, tax receipts are up just 2.8% from a year ago, which is down from the 5%-plus growth rate that had been the trend from Q2 2014 through Q3 2015. The last time that tax receipts were tracking this low through the first four months of the year was 2012, which happened to be the weakest year of real GDP growth (1.3% Q4/Q4) in the current business cycle.
There were a number of factors that weighed on growth in 2012, namely the European debt crisis, the US Presidential election and uncertainty with respect to the impending "fiscal cliff". At present, Europe is much less of an issue, but concerns about global growth, particularly in Asia, remain elevated. The Presidential election and its implications for fiscal policy may also be impacting corporate sentiment. Case in point, the Conference Board's CEO confidence survey is near its 2012 post-recession low. This is partly why we expect subdued real GDP growth of just 1.3% this year.
At present, our baseline forecast is for growth to gradually accelerate following what will likely be another year of soft Q1 output—the initial figures are released this morning. The upshot is that the Fed will likely remain very cautious with respect to interest rate hikes over the next couple of quarters. We continue to expect just one rate hike this year in December. However, if tax receipts continue to slow, we would become more concerned about an already fragile economic outlook.
 
 
3.Economics Research | Instant Insights 27 April 2016——市场解读偏鸽偏鹰很不一样
 
As we expected, the FOMC took a cautious interpretation of domestic and external developments at its April meeting. As such, we retain our baseline outlook for two rate hikes for the remainder of the year, but the timing will be highly dependent on the evolution of domestic activity and external risks. While our forecast continues to call for a rate hike in June, the hurdle is high and the second hike could slip to July or September should progress toward the dual mandate occur slower than we anticipate.
 
The committee downgraded the pace of activity. In the first paragraph, the committee downgraded the pace of economic activity relative to March, but it sees the slowing as transitory, since it points to solid real income growth and high consumer confidence as suggesting any slowing in consumption should be short-lived. The committee said economic activity “appears to have slowed” and “growth in household spending has moderated.” Both are downgrades relative to March. The recovery in housing was described as having improved further. Elsewhere, business investment and net exports where characterized as “soft,” in line with recent FOMC statements and consistent with our expectation that both will be drags on Q1 growth in tomorrow’s advance release of Q1 GDP.
 
Labor markets improved, but the committee does not see much evidence that inflation and inflation expectations are firming. In regard to labor markets and inflation, the committee said that labor markets improved further despite the slowing in activity. Leading with labor markets is likely reflective of the committee’s belief (and ours) that labor markets send a clearer signal about the pace of activity than does GDP. Hence, strong labor markets likely mean the moderation in activity will be reversed. Turning to inflation, the April statement dropped the reference to inflation having “picked up in recent months” in favor of more neutral language that says “inflation has been running below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-run objective.” The March CPI report, which contained a reversal of core goods inflation after strong January and February core inflation outturns, likely caused many on the committee to see the early-year rise in inflation as reflecting transitory moves and not evidence of a firming trend. Inflation expectations and inflation compensation were both described as stable at low levels, similar to the March statement. Altogether, the April statement suggests the committee remains confident with the state of labor markets while it still awaits evidence that inflation is firming.
 
The committee removed reference to global economic and financial developments posing risks, but neglected to characterize risks. As we had expected, the committee acknowledged the improvement in financial conditions, likely on account of incoming data that point to stabilization in China activity and oil markets. Both of these factors – a faster slowdown in China growth and further declines in oil prices – were cited by Fed Chair Janet Yellen in her recent speech as risks to the outlook.  This was likely behind the decision to remove the “pose risks” language. However, the committee did not choose to characterize the balance of risks, suggesting it desires maximum optionality. The committee merely says it will “closely monitor inflation indicators and global economic and financial developments.” It may well have felt a stronger upgrade was unwarranted, given the slowdown in domestic activity and the upcoming UK referendum. We suspect that many committee members desire to see actual evidence that domestic activity is rebounding, inflation is firming, and potential negative spillovers from the UK referendum have diminished before moving to a second rate increase. However, there was likely disagreement about when this may take place and, as a result, the committee chose to say less as it watches the incoming data evolve. Some on the committee may also see balance of risk language as inconsistent with a data-dependent framework, and we look to the minutes for the discussion of this issue.
 
We retain our baseline outlook for two rate hikes in 2016, but the timing of the next hike remains fluid, and risks are skewed to only one. Given the outcome of the April statement and optionality for policy, we retain our view that the economy will evolve in a manner consistent with two rate hikes this year. Our outlook calls for those in June and December. That said, the timing of a mid-year hike is complicated by, among other factors, the degree to which US activity rebounds in Q2 and whether financial market stress intensifies as a result of the UK referendum. Hence, the statement, as written, gives the committee flexibility to evaluate the June-July-September period for its next move. If domestic activity rebounds slowly, market stresses accelerate ahead of the UK referendum, or other external factors arise, it can defer its next policy move and the risk to our baseline is that the Fed only raises rates once this year. In contrast, should the economy improve and external risks diminish, a rate hike in the June-July-September period is likely on the table, as would be another one before year-end.
 
 
4.DOMINIC KONSTAM : So it's pretty clear how to read this（特别反感这种语气）.. as Joe highlighted on the hoot. It is dovish becos on the policy front all they did was to move the risks to growth from global/financial down the paragraph as to something that they are now monitoring. so they've gone from being very nervous on growth to being quietly confident but not out of the woods. Really it's reflecting their success in steering risk assets to stability and higher with a softer dollar. That said they have had to admit explicitly to weaker growth in the first para. So in current time clearly zero case for a hike now and zero case for a June hike. September is a possibility..maybe July if u think they want to mess with the press conference but unless the econ really recovers wouldnt bet to heavily.. 
 
We r arguing that the fed can steer real yields lower by seemingly being behind the curve as long as nominals are capped due to negative term premia in turn due to negative yields in euro and japan. With the potential for still lower jgb yields idea is to still like reals and therefore support risk assets that are v sensitive to reals like inv grade and gold. breaks can do well to but they have certainly front run the oil rally so prefer oil to breaks while em and HY all seem fair value to breakevens as well.  Really though the story ultimately is whether the Fed can continue to depress real yields vs JPY and euro, so far so good and the dollar should weaken furtherr but for now yen is wary of  BOJ tonight and the euroland uncertainty probably artificially keeps euro weak.
 
 
5.Fed Note: What we got from the April FOMC statement – Edging closer to June
 
The FOMC’s message was modified, on balance, from the one it had delivered in March, in a direction that moved it at least slightly closer to a rate hike.  While the statement did not give an explicit signal for a possible move in June (via inclusion of a balance of risks), it clearly left the door open for one if the data improve.
 
On economic developments, the Committee was more downbeat about recent growth performance.  Specifically it observed that growth of economic activity "appears to have slowed� as "household spending moderated.�  But this negative change was modified importantly: the surprise in growth has been a consumer-driven slowdown that seems inconsistent with fundamentals.  In particular, the statement also observes that  "households’ real income has risen at a solid rate , and consumer sentiment remains high.�   It is evident that the Committee will be watching closely to see how consumer spending fares ahead—if it bounces back soon, a June move comes back more clearly into play.  At the same time, the Committee continued to see, on the one hand, further improvement in the labor market and on the other hand, ongoing softness in business investment spending and net exports, as well as an inflation picture that remains weaker than desired.  Overall, it was not the text on economic developments that makes us think they edged closer to a June rate hike, rather it was two other factors.
 
Another important change in the statement was the removal of negative references to "global economic and financial� developments or risks, not once but twice in the statement (once each in the first two paragraphs).  Evidently, the Committee is feeling better about these risks at this juncture.  Had it not been for the weakening of economic activity, they may very well have reinserted a "nearly balanced risks� statement.  They are feeling better about these risks, but they also say they will continue to monitor them closely.
 
The second reason to think they have edged closer to a move in June is the absence of a dissent by Cleveland Fed President Mester.  In a recent speech in New York, she indicated that she saw the risks as balanced, and seemed in favor of raising rates at least by June.  We suspect she would have dissented if the Committee had not given some indication that the odds in favor of a June move have improved a bit.
 
Where do things go from here?  It is clear that the path ahead is very much data driven.  If consumer spending bounces back, the labor market continues to improve, inflation develops in line with Fed expectations, and global economic and financial conditions remain well behaved, June comes back into play. In this case we can expect some Fedspeak preparing the markets ahead of the June meeting.   This set of conditions may be a tall order in the minds of many, but to this observer, the initial market reaction to today’s statement was to read it as more dovish than warranted.
 
 ubject: EOD oil note - 27 Apr
 
Today’s price action highlights the bullish sentiment in the market where any bearish news is shrugged off and dip gets bought aggressively. Oil opened higher on API report showing a stock draw for last week, and WTI traded close to $45 before DOE data came out. A largely bearish report took prices down over $1, but market bounced back quickly and reached pre DOE levels. Not only was the DOE report bearish compared to APIs, it was bearish compared to estimates before APIs, and oil still failed to give up any gains.
- Venezuelan power crisis is escalating, and resulting in severe refinery run cuts apart from production disruptions. Water level at Guri dam, the main power source, is at critical point (241.6m), the lowest level it has ever been. Below 240m the turbines will be shutdown to avoid damages, and this level may reach in 2 weeks in absence of rain. Government has now reduced public sector work to only 2 days a week and implemented rolling blackouts to save power. Refinery runs have been reduced drastically, and PDVSA was seen buying product cargoes for May delivery due to shortage. Impact on production due to power shortage at upgraders can be over 200kbd if critical water level is breached.
- Adding to refinery outages, Phillips 66 shutdown a 64kbd crude unit and VDU at 306kbd Wood River refinery after a power outage resulting from heavy storms. It is unclear when the unit would be restarted. Shell also reported a unit shutdown at 156kbd Martinez refinery due to operational issues.
- DOE Comments
- Overall bearish, both crude and products. Crude stocks built 2mb with Cushing adding 1.75mb and P3 building by 1.11mb as refinery outages increased. Even lower imports (-637kbd), which more than offset lower refinery runs (-257kbd) could not result in a net stock draw as suggested by APIs. Product stocks build as well (+3.25mb) and demand eased by 400kbd. Gasoline stocks built by 1.61mb even with higher refinery outages. Disty draw (-1.69mb) was the only supportive data, aided by planting demand.
- Imports fell by 637kbd, with lower imports from Saudi, Kuwait, Ecuador and Mexico, while imports from Iraq and Canada picked up.
- Reported production fell by 15kbd in L48, easing pace of decline, while implied production jumped back to 8.97mbd, taking 4w average to 8.875mbd (60kbd below reported)
What’s bullish
- Imports eased by 637kbd, lead by P3 -438, which could be a result of the heavy rains and flash floods in Houston last week.
- Disty stocks drew 1.69mb, likely resulting from demand for planting. Implied demand however fell by 154kbd
What’s bearish
- Crude stocks built 2mb (vs 1.91mb last year), with Cushing building 1.75mb
- Refinery runs fell by 257kbd, as outages increased
- Gasoline stocks built by 1.61mb and demand eased by 129kbd. East coast stocks increased 1.30mb as imports ramped up 180kbd in the region
- Total stocks built 5.25mb, and product demand eased by 400kbd (first decline in 6 weeks)
- Pace of production decline eased marginally to 15kbd

2.US Daily Economic Notes - International trade data could keep the economy from shrinking ——总是用一个很小成分项的恶化推断整个项目的恶化..还有那些很不可靠的回归关系26 April 2016 (1 page/ 245 kb)
Commentary for Wednesday: Today's advance goods trade balance report could impact analysts' last-minute expectations for Q1 real GDP, which is released tomorrow. Yesterday's durable goods data for March, which also had the potential to impact Q1 GDP projections, were even softer than we had expected. Nondefense capital goods shipments excluding aircraft (i.e., core shipments), which are a direct input into the capex estimates within the GDP data, were up just 0.3% in March after declining -1.4% and -1.8% in January and February, respectively. The -9.6% annualized decline in Q1 2016 core shipments marks the weakest quarter since Q2 2009 (-21.2%), when the economy was just about to emerge from recession. Incredibly, if we subtract the machinery component from core shipments, because this is where energy-related spending is captured, the data are even weaker. Core shipments less machinery were down -13.8% last quarter. This tells us that spending outside the energy sector also plunged last quarter. If not for the possibility of a significantly smaller goods trade balance, the much weaker-than-expected durables figures would have caused us to reduce our projection of Q1 real GDP growth. To be sure, downside risks to our consumption estimate remain, based on disappointing retail sales.
Recent data from West Coast ports indicate that the goods deficit may narrow sharply in March. As the chart below illustrates, over the last five years the month-over-month change in inbound loaded containers to the ports of Los Angeles, Long Beach and Oakland has been meaningfully correlated with that of non-petroleum goods imports from the Census data. Last month, inbound loaded containers plunged -24.8% on a seasonally-adjusted basis relative to February. This compares to a modest -2.3% decline in outbound loaded containers in March. If the March trade deficit is much smaller than expected, the anticipated drag from net exports would be substantially less. In turn, analysts could revise up their estimates of Q1 real GDP, all else being equal.
The bigger issue for investors is what happens to GDP growth going forward. Unlike 2014 and 2015, we expect a smaller rebound in activity this year because of the economy's need to work off excessive inventories—it typically takes several quarters for this to occur. Provided financial conditions do not unexpectedly tighten anew, the economy's growth rate should strengthen to a 2%-plus annualized quarterly pace in Q4. Maybe then the Fed could nudge the funds rate up another 25 basis points. As we discussed in yesterday's US Daily Economic Notes, we expect the Yellen-led Fed to remain dovish for now.
