外国人看央妈“ it's a pattern that has been repeated in the past, ie you get initial reports, then they get denied, then they mostly end up being confirmed - so wouldn't read too much into this, the  overall messaging on more "prudent" policy over last few days has been pretty consistent”
 
FANG:facebook,amazon/apple,netflix,google
 
2.US Daily Economic Notes - Weak Q1 GDP likely to keep FOMC dovish for now 25 April 2016 (1 page/ 223 kb)
Commentary for Tuesday: The April FOMC gathering concludes Wednesday. There will be no press conference and updated forecasts will not be provided. The post-meeting statement should continue to strike a dovish tone, because we do not expect the Fed to add the "balance of risks" sentence back into its communiqué. In January, the Fed removed the balance of risks assessment due to global economic and financial developments, which the Fed continued to see as posing risks in the March meeting statement. Since the March 15-16 FOMC meeting, global equity markets have improved, largely due to diminished expectations of Fed rate hikes this year, the dollar is down sharply and oil prices are up significantly. In addition, recent economic data from Europe and Asia have shown modest improvement. Hence, in the second paragraph of the statement, the risks from global economic and financial developments may be described as "having diminished somewhat".
However, aside from the labor market, the US data have been disappointing. Real GDP growth in Q1 is expected to be sub-1%, which would mark the second consecutive quarter of below-trend output growth. More importantly, the momentum in consumer spending deteriorated over the course of the quarter, as was evident in the retail control figures. Under similar circumstances last year, the April 2015 meeting statement indicated that "Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in March suggests that economic growth slowed during the winter months, in part reflecting transitory factors." We may see a similar opening preamble this Wednesday, except that improved winter weather this year means the growth slowdown might not be viewed as "transitory". Household spending can continue to be characterized as "increasing at a moderate rate", but note that the housing data have slowed since the beginning of the year. Barring any meaningful upward revisions to this morning's durable goods data, the Committee will likely repeat that "business fixed investment and net exports have been soft." Only the labor market description can remain upbeat.
With respect to the inflation language, the Fed may remove the phrase "inflation picked up in recent months" due to the soft March CPI figures. The Fed will continue to acknowledge that "inflation continues to run below the Committee's 2% longer-run objective, partly reflecting declines in energy prices and prices of non-energy imports". However, the FOMC may note recent deterioration in survey-based measures of inflation expectations given that University of Michigan long-term inflation expectations fell back to their historical low. Market-based measures of inflation compensation remain depressed, thus we see little need to change this assessment.
In short, domestic uncertainty will likely render the FOMC unable to reach a consensus on the balance of risks, and the absence of such an assessment would reduce the probability of a June rate increase. Given that the FOMC's ability to respond to economic shocks is asymmetric, the Committee will remain cautious and wait to see whether another year of Q1 weakness gives way to a noticeable rebound in the second quarter.
 
3.Hooper on FOMC: Doves will be disappointed_和我观点一致啊SummaryIn brief, expect a mixed assessment of recent economic and financial developments and a statement that is neutral about prospects for rate moves ahead. The Committee will not say that it sees reason to move as soon as June, nor will they rule out that possibility at this juncture. Market participants expecting the Fed to signal that it is still concerned enough about global risks (as well as domestic slowdown) to remain on hold through June will likely be disappointed.Economic and financial conditions——喜忧参半The Fed will see an economic picture that has weakened in some respects since it last met, but that has improved somewhat in other respects. Growth in Q4 has turned out slightly stronger than seen earlier, but Q1 looks to have been weaker than FOMC projections were anticipating. The most recent Fed nowcasting model put it at less than 1% (AR). A softening of consumer spending has augmented the ongoing sluggishness in business spending, and net exports remain a significant drag on growth thanks to lagged effects of past dollar appreciation and ongoing sluggishness in global economic activity. At the same time, employment continues to grow at a robust pace, inflation indicators continue to move generally upward, and financial conditions continue to improve following their mid-winter swoon. In particular, the stock market has returned to near 2016 highs and volatility indicators to near 2016 lows, while corporate credit spreads have gained back much but not all of their losses since last fall. The dollar has drifted lower on a broad weighted average basis since the March meeting, and is now down more than 5% from its mid-January peak. Near-term uncertainties about China have receded and commodity markets (oil in particular) have gained a little more ground. Survey measures of inflation expectations have drifted sideways recently, while inflation compensation measures have gained a little ground.A June move?Overall, this is a picture that gives the Chair ample room to be cautious for now, but not so much that she can rule out a possible rate hike as soon as June. The June scenario would likely have to entail (1) a rebound in consumer spending indicators for April and May, (2) continued robust employment gains, and an inflation picture that was generally seen as remaining on its recent gradual improving trend, and (3) financial markets remaining calm ahead of Brexit—i.e., no significant deterioration in financial conditions ahead of the vote. Even so, the Committee would likely have some work to do to bring market expectations more in line with a possible rate hike that soon. How the market responded to such verbal guidance from the Fed could affect the outcome. Financial conditions globally are seen as somewhat fragile in the presence of geopolitical risks in Europe, and expectations of the Fed being on hold for some time to come have been generally supportive. A strongly negative reaction to a Fed tightening signal could well give the Committee reason to pause in June.What they signal this week.So we can expect that the April statement will observe the recently mixed data. This includes (1) the softer growth performance, (2) the generally improving labor market and inflation picture (with room for further improvement in both), and (3) financial and some global conditions continuing to regaining lost ground. Reading between the lines, the statement should be neutral with respect to policy moves ahead. The door will not be closed on June, but further improvements in the data will be needed to get us there. The Committee does not need to signal a June move at this juncture. That could be done if needed after the data have proven significantly stronger over the next two months.How will the market react to this statement?Hard to say. Investors expecting the Fed to signal that it is still concerned enough about global risks (as well as the more negative aspects of recent domestic economic news) to hold off for next meeting or two will be disappointed. If market participants are generally expecting a neutral and noncommittal stance from the Fed, this could be a big yawn. A significantly hawkish tone in the statement—for example by reinserting the notion that the risks are now "about/almost/nearly balanced," and thereby preparing the market more explicitly for a possible move in June—is not totally out of the question. But that would come as a significant negative surprise to the markets as well as to this observer. The more likely time for that signal is after some significant additional robust data.Looking beyond the current meeting.Our own view remains that data will not be improving enough in the months ahead to warrant a move in June, and that instead the next Fed rate hike will be put off until later in the year. We’ll have more to say on that after the meeting this week.March FOMC statement(原文，看了太多分析之后，觉得还是看原文踏实)Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in January suggests that economic activity has been expanding at a moderate pace despite the global economic and financial developments of recent months. Household spending has been increasing at a moderate rate, and the housing sector has improved further; however, business fixed investment and net exports have been soft. A range of recent indicators, including strong job gains, points to additional strengthening of the labor market. Inflation picked up in recent months; however, it continued to run below the Committee's 2 percent longer-run objective, partly reflecting declines in energy prices and in prices of non-energy imports. Market-based measures of inflation compensation remain low; survey-based measures of longer-term inflation expectations are little changed, on balance, in recent months.——现在的情况和1月份没有太大区别Consistent with its statutory mandate, the Committee seeks to foster maximum employment and price stability(通胀就业，再加维稳？). The Committee currently expects that, with gradual adjustments in the stance of monetary policy, economic activity will expand at a moderate pace and labor market indicators will continue to strengthen. However, global economic and financial developments continue to pose risks. Inflation is expected to remain low in the near term, in part because of earlier declines in energy prices, but to rise to 2 percent over the medium term as the transitory effects of declines in energy and import prices dissipate and the labor market strengthens further. The Committee continues to monitor inflation developments closely.Against this backdrop, the Committee decided to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 1/4 to 1/2 percent. The stance of monetary policy remains accommodative, thereby supporting further improvement in labor market conditions and a return to 2 percent inflation.In determining the timing and size of future adjustments to the target range for the federal funds rate, the Committee will assess realized and expected economic conditions relative to its objectives of maximum employment and 2 percent inflation. This assessment will take into account a wide range of information, including measures of labor market conditions, indicators of inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and readings on financial and international developments. In light of the current shortfall of inflation from 2 percent, the Committee will carefully monitor actual and expected progress toward its inflation goal. The Committee expects that economic conditions will evolve in a manner that will warrant only gradual increases in the federal funds rate; the federal funds rate is likely to remain, for some time, below levels that are expected to prevail in the longer run. However, the actual path of the federal funds rate will depend on the economic outlook as informed by incoming data.The Committee is maintaining its existing policy of reinvesting principal payments from its holdings of agency debt and agency mortgage-backed securities in agency mortgage-backed securities and of rolling over maturing Treasury securities at auction, and it anticipates doing so until normalization of the level of the federal funds rate is well under way. This policy, by keeping the Committee's holdings of longer-term securities at sizable levels, should help maintain accommodative financial conditions.Voting for the FOMC monetary policy action were: Janet L. Yellen, Chair; William C. Dudley, Vice Chairman; Lael Brainard; James Bullard; Stanley Fischer; Loretta J. Mester; Jerome H. Powell; Eric Rosengren; and Daniel K. Tarullo. Voting against the action was Esther L. George, who preferred at this meeting to raise the target range for the federal funds rate to 1/2 to 3/4 percent.
 
4.Asset Allocation - Signal And Noise In GDP Growth
25 April 2016 (5 pages/ 223 kb)
 
Download the complete report: http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/9076-4844/46444851/0900b8c08b0c43df.pdf<http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/9076-4844/46444851/0900b8c08b0c43df.pdf>
 
 
How much to make of subdued GDP growth in Q1?
 
The consensus sees 0.6% growth in Q1, which compares to an average of 2.1% in this recovery. But how much is a signal and how much just noise?
 
The vol of GDP growth is remarkably high: one standard deviation is 1.7%
 
GDP growth in this recovery has averaged 2.1% +/- 1.7%, indicating inherent volatility is large and the signal to noise not very high. A realization of the consensus for Q1 would leave growth within a normal one standard deviation variation band around average, after which growth should pick up. The vol of GDP growth reflects both inherent idiosyncratic and temporary noise; and it reflects the impacts of shocks, of which there is a long list in this recovery (2010 double dip recession fear; 2011 US debt downgrade; 2012 European financial crisis; the rapid rise in the dollar in 2014-15; accompanying collapse in oil prices; and the severe winters of 2014 and 2015).
 
But the vol of GDP growth in this recovery is the same as in previous ones
 
Despite the popular narrative of vulnerable growth in the face of a large set of realized and prospective shocks, this has not been evident in higher GDP growth vol. Assuming inherent noise in GDP growth is about the same, shocks do not appear to have been larger or more frequent than previous recoveries.（GDP内生增长就是高度波动的）
 
When economic time series are volatile, it is better to focus on the evolution of the level within the trend recovery channel
 
Focusing on trend channels is common practice in looking at asset prices given their high volatility. But despite the significant volatility in economic time series, the approach is not very common, though it often provides a very different perspective compared to growth rates. Using trend channels naturally resolves "base effect� issues since growth should depend on where the level is in the channel, not independently of it which is what focusing on growth rates does. When GDP is high in the channel, growth should be expected to slow and vice versa. US GDP has been in a 2.1% trend channel in this recovery with a span of 1.4pp, hitting the top and bottom several times.
 
An outcome of 0.6% growth in Q1 would see GDP move from near the top to the middle of its channel: not a particularly notable but a normal development
 
The weakness in Q1 GDP is in line with its normal vol, even before considering the impact of various factors such as residual Q1 seasonality, market volatility and lagged effects of the dollar and oil on growth. Indeed, a move of GDP only to the middle of the channel suggests activity has actually been relatively resilient to the impacts of these factors.
 
In our reading, for good reason the equity market is looking through weak Q1 GDP growth. The Fed should too, but it will wait for confirmation: stay short July Fed Fund Futures which still offer a 1:4 risk reward。即便是0.6%，也是正常的
 
In line with the Fed’s practice in this recovery, we expect it to proceed more slowly and wait for confirmation. As we have argued previously, prospects for data surprises suggest a June hike is likely and we stay short the July Fed Fund future (FFN6) which still offers a 1:4 risk reward (Gauging The Fed’s Data Dependence, Mar 2016).

--------------------------------

WHAT DO I THINK HERE? Bond rout or BoJ-led-one-more-sugar-rush?! Yellen may be the short term decider on that, as usual, by which she decides to emphasize on her FOMC statement. I am not surprised by this "wider core rates, stronger USD" revival attempt, as the (lack of) positioning made it all perfect for it. It could have happened any time in the last 10 days or so, given Oil's stability & Equities' strength. Macro Land called Draghi's stage yesterday "low expectations," but Micro European Credit traders loved the details. As for FX/Rates land, I guess some believed in the "helicopter love" too much, hence the 9 bps disappointment. Draghis & Carneys will "cold shoulder" the helicopter while Risk rallies. When we choke, things (and tones) will be different. 
债市崩溃或者再来一次日本领衔的甜蜜时光？和以往一样，耶伦可能通过强调其FOMC生命而成立短期内的决定因素。对于现在这种“核心利率走高，美元走强”试图逆转的走势我一点儿不稀奇，尽管仓位（不够）使得这种尝试很完美（就是个尝试，而不是反转？）在过去大概10天当中，这应该是已经发生了，因为油价企稳股市走强。宏观方面对于draghi的预期很低，但是微观上欧洲信用债交易员喜欢细节（mario公布了公司债购买细节，并延长了期限）。对于FX/RATES品种，我猜测有人过于相信hm嗜好了，导致eur涨9bps。Draghi和Carney联手抵制hm，在当下风险资产上涨的时候。要是跌了，情况就应该不同了。
This morning, more signals from BoJ for "ECB way": Not more negative rates, but ETF buying! There's now increased expectation to give more "juice" on both monetary & fiscal front! If Yellen is hawkish & BoJ disappoints, Risk will choke big before it waits for May. If Yellen is dovish disappointing "hurrah huurah USA hike probabilities" for the third time & if Kuroda delivers the next morning, we can BOOOOOMMM into May..Only to eventually sell off in May, of course! "Those rates will sell off a lot more." We had moved to the other extreme so much & the positioning was (is) so empty that it's natural they try for a few sessions more. If you believe in your own version of Yellen, you may again be disappointed on next Wednesday! But these sessions, the momentum should still be with USTs wider, Bunds wider. Recently very very popular EM rates trades wider. 
这个早上，BOJ表达出更多“ECB”模仿的意味：不仅要nirp，还要扩大etf购买。同时在货币政策和财政刺激两方面放水刺激的预期在放大。如果耶伦表现得鹰派且BOJ未能放水，风险资产就会在五月之前（就是下周）大跌。如果耶伦继续鸽派，第三次搞定那些“屋里哇啦美国加息可能性啊”的一派，且野村行长第二天（周五？Yellen是中国时间周四凌晨）早上说要放水，我们就一直涨到5月。当然，也就是5月跑掉啦（作者长期不看好，短期炒作）。我们已经相当深入到一个极端，仓位过去是（现在还是）如此空挡，这样再多几个交易时段也是自然。如你确信自己版本的耶伦，下周四可能会失望。但是现在这些交易时段，动量还是ust走高，德债走高， 时髦的em债走高（价格下跌，收益率上涨）

3.US Economics Weekly - Housing activity should continue to outperform, but will it be enough? 22 April 2016 (9 pages/ 613 kb)
Overview: The outlook for housing is a mixed bag. Healthy household balance sheets, strong job growth, easing lending standards and the relatively low share of housing in output suggest that the sector could be ready for a strong expansion. On the flip side, recent signs that demand could be slowing, despite the blatant inadequacy of the housing recovery, bear watching. On balance, we remain cautiously optimistic on the housing sector, expecting it to outperform the rest of the economy, but not to the extent that it engenders a substantial increase in real GDP growth. 
The week ahead: GDP and the Fed. The April FOMC gathering headlines a crowded economic events calendar next week. The post-meeting statement, released Wednesday afternoon, should continue to strike a cautious tone, but for different reasons from last month, as the Fed may acknowledge the recovery in global asset prices. Additionally, recent economic data from Europe and Asia have been modestly encouraging. However, the FOMC will likely refrain from reinstating the balance of risks. This is because most of the domestic data, except employment, have deteriorated over the intra-meeting period. The Fed will not have the advance Q1 real GDP figures (released Thursday), but policymakers will likely be anticipating well-below-trend growth. The March personal income and consumption report, the Q1 employment cost index and the Chicago PMI (Friday) will be important for the near-term outlook. 
 
 
4.US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 22 April 2016 (1 page/ 222 kb)
Commentary for Monday: The April FOMC gathering headlines a crowded economic events calendar this week. The post-meeting statement, released Wednesday afternoon, should continue to strike a cautious tone. There will be no press conference and updated economic and financial forecasts will not be released. We do not expect the FOMC to add the "balance of risks" sentence back into its communiqué at this point. Doing so would be quite bearish for risk assets as it would definitely open the door for a June rate hike. Over the past week, the probability of a June move increased, although the chances are still relatively low. At the time of this writing, the June 2015 fed funds contract was discounting a 23% probability of a 25 basis-point rate hike, compared to just a 14% probability one week ago. 
One reason the Fed is expected to be cautious is Q1 real GDP, which is the second-most important event this week. While policymakers will not have the data when their meeting ends on Wednesday—the figures are released on Thursday—expectations will be for a soft print. Our estimate is 0.5%, and the consensus is 0.6%. Remember that the latter had been around 2% to start the quarter. A troubling aspect of our forecast is that most of the major categories of GDP likely moderated further after only 1.4% top-line growth in Q4 2015. 
However, expectations of advance Q1 GDP could change based on the March data for durable goods orders (+1.0% forecast vs. -3.0% previously), released on Tuesday, and the advance international goods trade balance (-$60.0 billion vs. -$62.9 billion), released on Wednesday. Regarding the former series, aircraft orders should boost the headline, while orders excluding transportation are projected to increase modestly (+0.5% vs. -1.3%). Trade will potentially be more important for Q1 real GDP expectations, because of recent activity on the West Coast. Port data for March indicate that inbound loaded containers into Long Beach, Los Angeles and Oakland plunged -25% on a seasonally-adjusted basis relative to February. As a result, imports could have slowed dramatically last month. In this case, all else being equal, the trade deficit would be much narrower. We have been hesitant to change our GDP forecast, which was well below consensus at the outset of the quarter—most estimates have now come down to ours—because some of the weakness in March imports could show up in lower inventories; if so, the net effect on GDP growth could be neutral. 
On Friday, we get the March personal income and consumption data, which will provide more details on the quarterly profile of consumer spending, as well as the latest reading on core PCE inflation. However, because these data will already have been incorporated into the Q1 GDP figures, they will take on less significance. We expect 0.3% gains in income and spending, compared to 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively, in February. Regarding core PCE inflation, we project a 0.1% increase because of modest deceleration in healthcare prices. This would have the effect of lowering the year-over-year rate a tenth to 1.6%, which is the Fed's yearend 2016 median projection. The tepid trend in inflation should also be evident in Friday's ECI (0.7% vs. 0.6%) report. This series might improve modestly, but its year-over-year rate should remain at 2.0%. Finally, in terms of the factory sector, we get the April Chicago purchasing managers' index (49.5 vs. 53.6) on Friday as well. The very soft April Philadelphia Fed survey (-1.6 vs. +12.4) increases the chances of a weak Chicago report. If this turns out to be the case, then the manufacturing ISM survey, which is released on May 2 and is one of our top five indicators, is likely to fall back below 50.

Article No. 222
20160422  星期五，晴，空气质量好
2016-04-22 随手札记

1.昨天下午5点，市场上有人在大举买入ffk6，加息预期就要来了。这种情况下，美元肯定升值，对大宗有一定影响。主要考虑：1）伊朗说5月会议会有协议，俄罗斯不屌他。第一印象是负面，但伊朗核利比亚是四月会议流产的主要原因，这次是伊朗愿意谈了，应该是利多。2）brent近端backdation了（昨天下午6:20又有消息说伊朗在强烈表态）。总之，认为大宗这一波还没有走完，想再等等.。今早再看，还好，43+，ffr升1bp，比预期小很多。但是最多一周，美元就要走强了。下周三之前一定要清掉A股。

Mario说美资发行人的债券也可被ecb购买

3.奥黑演讲词，太美了——脱欧基本上是小概率事件，应该对英镑重新定价了
 
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/21/as-your-friend-let-me-tell-you-that-the-eu-makes-britain-even-gr/
 
As your friend, let me tell you that the EU makes Britain even greater
 
In 1939, President Franklin D Roosevelt offered a toast to King George VI in the White House. "I am persuaded that the greatest single contribution our two countries have been enabled to make to civilisation, and to the welfare of peoples throughout the world," he said, "is the example we have jointly set by our manner of conducting relations between our two nations."
 
Nearly 80 years later, the United Kingdom remains a friend and ally to the United States like no other. Our special relationship was forged as we spilt blood together on the battlefield. It was fortified as we built and sustained the architecture for advancing stability and prosperity in Europe, and our democratic values around the globe. From the ashes of war, those who came before us had the foresight to create the international institutions and initiatives to sustain a prosperous peace: the United Nations and Nato; Bretton Woods, the Marshall Plan, and the European Union. Their efforts provided a foundation for democracy, open markets, and the rule of law, while underwriting more than seven decades of relative peace and prosperity in Europe.
 
4.Oil is still the king,虽然过气儿的
 
Subject: EOD Oil Note - 21 Apr
 
Oil ended lower today, after Libya indicated they can quickly ramp up output if stability returns. USD sold off after ECB, but was bought back quickly leading to a choppy market for most of the commodity complex. News flow was relatively light today.
- Libya NOC’s chairman Sanalla said today that Libya will unite the two rival factions of the NOC in the next few weeks and will be able to double oil output (from current 360kbd) within weeks after if the new unity government is formed. The UN backed unity govt is still not approved by Tobruk house of reps, but efforts are underway to restore stability in the region. Libya aims to restore production to 1mbd by year end if peace is restored. Although Libyan production was 1.6mbd before disruptions, bringing back output will be challenging given the state of infrastructure. Moreover, the peace talks led by UN have been largely unsuccessful and there is little evidence of any progress till now.
- Saudi exports for last week were estimated at 7.25mbd, bringing April average to 6.9mbd, still lower than 7.48mbd for March（传言沙特本地消费大增）. Exports from the kingdom are set to fall further in May with 0.4mbd estimated production maintenance and stocking for summer burn.
- China’s implied oil demand for March fell by 0.32mbd y/y to 10.30mbd, lead by apparent diesel demand falling by 0.44mbd. However, this doesn’t include demand fulfilled through stock draws, and March inventory figures should indicate heavy diesel stock draw and higher actual demand. Gasoline demand was up 0.2mbd (7.7%) y/y. China crude imports were strong in March again (7.7mbd), slightly lower than record Feb imports (8.027mbd)
[cid:image001.png@01D19BDF.2A200990]
- In physical markets, West African grades were under pressure today, as the grades get priced against dated brent which has been trading at strong premium to Dubai and WTI reducing interest from Asian and North American buyers. North Sea diffs were weak as well and traded at lowest in 2 weeks, as surplus of April barrel grows. No VLCCs have been reported to depart for Asia this month, but one is being used to store Forties for next month.
 
5.
Commodities Digest - Silver overtaking gold 
 
{http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/1990-FAC0/13800298/DB_CommodsWkly_2016-04-22_0900b8c08b0b1a43.pdf}
 
Silver: Overtaking gold, but how much further to go? 
 
Silver is known by a number of pseudonyms, but most of the names in a financial context relate to gold; "Poor man's gold" and "High-beta gold" to name just two. It is therefore not surprising that silver's value is often referenced to gold in terms of the gold-silver ratio. Since the infamous Hunt brother's cornered the market and were unceremoniously squeezed out in the late 70's / early 80's, silver has tended to amplify gold's trading patterns, both on the upside and on the downside. The silver revaluation cycles tend to be multi-year, with earlier cycles as long as a decade. We are not suggesting that this is the cusp on a long term rerating cycle but even within a de-rating cycle, silver can remain dormant and underperform gold for significant periods before suddenly catching up; it tends to be a late cycle play in the precious metals space. When this happens, it tends to happen quickly as has been the case this week. Silver is now up 25% year to date, versus gold at 18%. We think momentum could carry silver as high as USD20/oz in the near term. 
 
In order to see a continued rerating of silver versus gold, we need to see a number of financial conditions either continue or for momentum to continue. The first is a favourable environment for precious metals in general. The dovish Fed, an accommodative ECB and market expectations of a low probability of a Fed hike in the near term means that the financial conditions for gold remain favourable. In our view, a near-term catalyst to drive gold higher is not obvious, but we think the metal remains well supported. The long-term gold silver ratio (since 1973) is 57.7. The more recent range is however 85 during the depths of the global financial crisis to 35 during the period of recovery and unprecedented Quantitative Easing; Figure 2. If gold stays relatively range bound at c.USD1,250/oz, a silver rerating to 66.6 (the average 1983 – 2003), the silver could trade up to USD18.8/oz, and a silver rerating to 61.1 (the average since 2003), then silver could trade as high as USD20.5/oz. 
 
The key question is what other conditions are required for silver to continue rerating versus gold. There are specific catalysts such as the launch of the first silver ETF in 2006. Silver is more of an industrial metal compared to gold with c.60% of demand from industrial applications, versus gold at less than 10% of demand. We note that when the US ISM rises sharply or continuously over an extended period, silver tends to rerate as investor global growth expectations improve dramatically. The corollary also applies that when the US ISM falls, silver tends to de-rate versus gold (Chart 3). More recently, we note that the gold silver ratio also shows some sensitivity to the China manufacturing PMI (Chart 4). We expect both the US ISM and the China manufacturing PMI to show positive momentum over the next few months, which is positive for a silver rerating. The change in sentiment towards silver is being reflected in positive ETF inflows, which up to now have been quite stable, especially in light of the sharp price falls (Chart 5). Investor positioning is however close to record net long levels on the Comex, so for momentum to continue, we would expect new record net long positions to be printed (Chart 6). 
Base Metal positioning: reluctant bulls 
Base metal positioning on the LME has continued to turn more bullish since the turn in mid January. Positioning is by no means extreme is well off record levels which suggests to us that investors (Money Managers on the LME) remain skeptical of the longevity of the cyclical upswing in China. The exception is zinc, which on this gauge is the most preferred base metal. Money manager net longs now represent 13% of the open interest on the LME versus a peak of 22% in June last year. We continue to favour zinc as our preferred base metal, but concede that for pricing to move higher, we need to see incrementally better macro data points from China. 
Crude Oil: Fundamentals supportive of a flattening curve 看起来油价似乎要看不懂地涨起来
The weekly data from the US was supportive in that a modest build in inventory occurred despite a pickup in imports. This was accompanied by an on-trend decline in production and strong product demand for a second week driven by gasoline. In fact US product demand has strengthened enough that it could eventually justify lifting our conservative assumption for US demand at flat this year. Altogether this supports improving sentiment which took a tremendous leap forward as far as longer Brent positioning from 198 to 238 thousand contracts defying expectations of a reversion to the mean. This was the largest weekly increase in net long positioning since April 2014 and was as much a cutback in short positioning as it was an extension of length. A flattening forward curve has moved in lockstep with sentiment to the tightest level since late 2014. 
Outside the US, consistent signs of decline in non-OPEC ex-US production from an assortment of producers in March data suggest that our 2017 assumption of non-OPEC production is too high and could be revised lower by several hundred thousand barrels per day. Although some declines may be owed to unplanned outages which could recover later this year (e.g., Colombia), several other cases are more likely to extend to further decline next year (e.g., Mexico, Kazakhstan). For the fundamental balance this would likely make 2017 a net deficit year on average, meaning that we could expect global inventory to fall between now and H2-2017. Since the market has clearly moved past any expectation of OPEC action this narrows the number of scenarios which would imply a retest of Q1 lows.
 
6.US Daily Economic Notes - Manufacturing back in the doldrums? 21 April 2016 (1 page/ 242 kb)
Commentary for Friday: The April Philadelphia Fed survey（三星级数据，主要是可能意味着ism下去，但似乎问题不大） unexpectedly softened, nearly reversing the previous month's improvement. To wit, the headline figure was -1.6, compared to 12.4 in March. Remember that the headline index is based on a separate question on the survey; the various subcomponents are not used to construct it. We can see in the chart below that when the details are used to create an ISM-adjusted series, the Philadelphia Fed figures imply a sub-50 manufacturing ISM reading. The ISM-adjusted Philadelphia Fed figure is 43.1 in April, compared to 51.7 in March. April's reading is the lowest since July 2009 (41.9), which was only one month after the recession ended. The component of the Philadelphia Fed survey that decreased the most was shipments, which plunged nearly -33 points in the month, the biggest decline since January 2001 (-34.6 points). But employment (-18.5 in April vs. -1.1 in March) and new orders (0.0 vs. 15.7) also fell substantially this month. The readings on supplier deliveries (-9.9 vs. 0.3) and inventories (-20.5 vs. -12.7) were also lower. In terms of the manufacturing ISM (49.0 forecast vs. 51.8 previously), we now expect the series to fall back below 50 when the data are released on May 2. 
As we wrote a few weeks ago, excessive inventory building poses ongoing risk to the factory sector, meaning there is a risk that production and hence employment would have to decline as stockpiles are reduced to a level more consistent with underlying demand. If the manufacturing ISM survey were to remain near 50 this quarter, the projected Q2 bounce back in real GDP would likely be very modest. Remember, too, that the Fed has almost never raised interest rates when the manufacturing ISM survey has been below 50. Consequently, if the data were to remain soft, the probability of a June FOMC rate hike would remain low and perhaps drop further. At the time of writing, the futures market was pricing roughly a 22% chance of a 25 basis-point interest rate hike in June (and a 63% probability of a hike by December). 
Despite the weak Philadelphia Fed report, jobless claims made a new cyclical low, down -6k to 247k. The last time claims were this low was November 1973. Since the data cover the employment survey week, there is a high likelihood we will see another sturdy gain in payrolls when the April data are released on May 6. Despite these impressively low claims, the trend in employee tax withholding receipts continues to slow—they are currently growing at only around a 3% year-over-year rate, compared to nearly 6% growth at this time last year. Going forward, it is likely that either claims will rise or tax receipts will accelerate (or both), because the divergence between the two series is unusual. Stay tuned. _工资预缴税增长低于就业增长，作者认为或者初请增，或者预缴税增，可能后者吧

It's "funny" to see that former colleague, now PBoC Chief Economist Jun Ma's comments on "signalling less appetite for Stimulus" triggered the selloff. It shows you how much still we rely on "sugar."

2.Okt’s color——em还是好消息不断，但是虽然现在谈反转还早，但也快了，下周。。Okt的感觉，也可能是boj，也可能是em数据很差，尚不可知
 
WHAT DO I THINK HERE? Just when the bus got "tipsy(adj.醉了)," Shanghai started shouting "Hellloo" from the rooftop. Weakness in Chinese stocks made all Risk observe some profit taking, but we are already recovering in EMFX & ranges are not broken in core rates. It's "funny" to see that former colleague, now PBoC Chief Economist Jun Ma's comments on "signalling less appetite for Stimulus" triggered the selloff. It shows you how much still we rely on "sugar（央妈的水）." With ECB & BoJ approaching, stories on "helicopter money" (I share the Carney skepticism on ultimate help) & Japan discussing consumption tax hike again make rounds, but at the moment Emerging Markets really lead Macro sentiment. Oil's lower with Kuwait being back, but that didn't sour mood either. Historical $16.5 bio Argentina "comeback" deal lifts EM & other asset spirits! This is how buses get crowded. Too early to stay in front of the bus. Later closer to May, we will probably get worried about something we wouldn't now. And sell off. Not today's problem. In fact, Shanghai led Risk profit taking may just be a prelude. Yesterday was a historical one for Argentina. Back into the market. It lifted off not only EM, but spirit of other asset classes as well. Meanwhile, Brazil impeachment excitement is almost overshadowed. Receiving rates interest should continue there as well. Taking about receiving rates, the new Turkish Central Bank Governor is likely to start his tenure by cutting rates 50 or 75 bps. Low housing number yesterday ensured core rates stayed glued. And that in itself makes the search for yield more attractive. We get more housing data today. In the G7 currency land, GBP is the one with the biggest move, post more Remain poll win hopes. That remains my personal prediction. GS results came as bad as most feared. Especially in FIC are.. Doha has been disappointment. But both just shrugged off. Low expectations from ECB Thursday. Probably higher expectations from next week's Kuroda, but probably too early for that. Italy banks still sending signs that some people are thinking sinister. But today's not the time for it. At the moment, music is for the bus to get more full. Sooner or later, post positioning getting more crowded, we will find reasons to get more nervous. Like we did overnight.

5.提心吊胆前行——似乎下周只要大婶在声明中提及美国经济缺乏动力了，就足以撼动市场了
 
Fwd:How long can EMFX (and risk) stay in the sweet spot?
From: SEBASTIAN LIVESEY, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURI <slivesey3@bloomberg.net>
At: 20-Apr-2016 21:34:26
 
  It has been a fairly magical couple of weeks in EM as we enjoyed the holy trio of a weak USD, rallying global equities, and higher commodities.  Strong inflows in March look to have continued in Aprils, helped by seasonal trends.  Long USD positioning finally appears to have been squeezed out, though it is difficult to say yet whether sizeable shorts have built up.  Brazil's impeachment and Argentina's jumbo bond issue brough even more attention to our asset class, raising questions over how many tourists have gotten involved.  Jerome Saragoussi did a great PCA piece that showed that the majority of the broader risk rally was driven by the return of a perceived "Yellen put"（还是依赖美国央妈兜底的意思）.  So what can we expect heading into next week's Fed?
  Simply put, I see pitfalls.  Frontend rates in USD came alive today as the market finally tried to reprice a Fed hike in 2016, getting us close to a full 25bp for the year.  Is that enough? Given how much financial conditions have eased, will Yellen pass on the opoprtunity to send a trial balloon like she did in Oct15?  US Growth has certainly lost momentum, but external risks have stabilized.  If Yellen remains dovish next week, she will have to cite domestic growth softening... dangerous for risk in a world supposedly powered by the US engine.  If she doesn't, and June / July goes live, bye bye Yellen put.  For the former scenario, sell MXNJPY... the latter sell AUDPLN.  What do you think?
 
6.还是油价
 
From: Prateek Jain
Sent: Wednesday, April 20, 2016 08:11 PM
Subject: EOD oil note - 20 Apr
 
Oil opened lower overnight on news of Kuwait strike ending. However, market shrugged the bearish developments once again after DOE reported modestly bullish data, and rallied to make new WTI highs for 2016. Today was the last trading day for WTI May contract, so prompt contract continuation chart will pick up $1.3 from contango overnight. Spreads didn’t budge surprisingly and WTI Jun/Jul spread ended almost unch.
- Kuwait oil workers strike ended overnight after 3 days, but production recovery may take another few days, with average impact for April estimated at 100-150kbd.
- Iran exports for last week were 2.2mbd, bringing average imports for April to 1.986mbd. However, part of the exports are the cargoes which slipped from March program (Mar exports 1.43mbd vs 1.7mbd scheduled), and are expected to normalize around 1.8mbd. April exports are scheduled to be around 1.76mbd. Even though exports have ramped up almost 600kbd post sanctions, significant volume is believed to come from storage, and production growth estimates are around 350-400kbd
- On Monday, Nigeria’s state government ordered Shell to cease production at the 220kbd Gbaran Ubie oil and gas facility for operating without a permit. However, state spokesman said today that Shell has defied the order and appropriate actions will be taken to prosecute them. Shell hasn’t commented on this yet, but any prolonged outage will cause a force majeure on Bonny Light exports.
- Iraq deputy oil minister said today that Major OPEC and other oil producers will meet in Russia in May to revive output freeze proposal. However, Russian energy minister refuted the statement and said that there is still no agreement on an oil meeting in May. Venezeula oil minister commented that oil prices will collapse if key producers don’t make a deal. It seems that noise about freeze may continue, but after the lost credibility at Doha, market may not react as much to these comments.
-  Saudi production maintenance for May is estimated at 0.4mbd, and expected to be predominantly heavy crude. This should lower imports from Saudi into USGC by 0.3mbd, and should accelerate draws as it coincides with higher refinery runs. Given the disruptions in Latam/Nigeria, those barrels may be difficult to source, leading to slightly lower imports in May.
- Comments
- Overall bullish tone in these stats. Crude built 2.08mb, but P2, P3 and Cushing (main regions with stock surplus) had small draws. Disty impressed with a 3.55mb draw. Total stocks drew as well after increasing for 5 weeks. Product demand increased for third straight week above 20.2mbd. Refinery runs also picked up 163kbd against an expected decline due to unplanned maintenance. Gasoline draws disappointed though, and East coast had a build, which may cap RBOB gains.
- Imports picked up 247kbd, as Keystone flow resumed. Higher imports were noted from Canada (+422), Ecuador (+288), Angola (+257), Mexico (+204), Kuwait (+200) and Nigeria (+198). Imports from Iraq fell back (-563), and lower imports from Colombia (-232) and Venezuela (-116) are now below ytd average, pointing at possible disruptions.
- Reported production fell 24kbd, with Lower 48 down 19kbd. Implied production nose dived to 8.553mbd (-735kbd) bringing 4w average (8.926mbd) back under reported production.
What’s bullish
- Cushing drew 250kb, along with P2 (-340kb) and P3 (-60kb) draws
- Disty stocks drew 3.55mb, and demand increased 423kbd (highest since Sep 2015). Part of the pull in disty demand is due to agricultural demand during the planting season, and is expected to be strong this week as well.
- Product demand picked up by 241kbd, reaching 20.23mbd
- Total stocks had a draw of 430kb (vs 9.2mb build last year)
- Refinery runs increased 163kbd, against an expected decline due to unplanned maintenance
What’s bearish
- Gasoline stocks drew only 110kb, with East coast stocks building by 1.60mb. Implied demand fell by 189kbd.
- Imports increased (+247) for 2nd week in a row as Keystone flow from Canada resumed. Imports are now back above 8mbd, and are expected to average higher than last year with falling domestic supply
 
 
7.彭博新闻记者一篇，算是quant的一种思路吧_用网络爬虫检测t账户组，用语言识别判断每个有价值信息源的敏感度，然后综合起来，blabla...
Andrew Lo Study Says Twitter Can Help You Trade Fed Meetings
-It looked at sentiment `polarity' in days before the FOMC met
-Researchers found a predictable enhancement of returns
 
In the social media cacophony, some of the noise rises to the level of stock market signal.
 
That’s the finding of a working paper overseen by Massachusetts Institute of Technology’（MIT！）s Andrew Lo, which says a trading strategy based on views posted on Twitter prior to Federal Reserve policy meetings regularly turned a profit. A one-standard-deviation increase in tweet sentiment can be exploited to boost Fed-day equity returns by 0.62 percent, it found.
 
Quant investors have been obsessed for years with pulling signals out of social media, where roughly 1.8 billion active users opine in real time on everything from tech valuations to celebrity breakups. The MIT study, which examined 3.9 million tweets over seven years, joins an expanding pool of research examining topics such as the role of tweets in market volatility and the accuracy of crowd-sourced earnings estimates.
 
“The key problem with Twitter is separating useful data from the noise,” Pablo Azar, a Ph.D. candidate in the economics department at MIT who co-authored the report, said by phone. “We decided to focus the information from Twitter into one event that we know moves markets, and we found that there’s real economic knowledge to be gathered.”
 
Social media’s role in the stock market has been expanding since the networks were invented a decade ago. Dozens of companies, including Bloomberg LP, the parent company of Bloomberg News, have products to analyze sentiment expressed on Twitter about markets and economies. ALPS Advisors Inc. just announced the Sprott BUZZ Social Media Insights ETF, which tracks stocks with bullish investor perception based on Twitter and Facebook.
 
The MIT researchers monitored the tweet flow in the 24 hours before Federal Open Market Committee meetings and developed standards to evaluate how people felt about the outcome. In a model portfolio, they used what they found to adjust exposure to stocks on the day when policy makers met. The system “outperformed on several dimensions a comparably levered benchmark market portfolio.”
 
One possibility Lo and Azar considered was that Twitter becomes more useful in the days before events with a predictable market impact -- meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee were investigated for this reason. They found that the helpfulness of Twitter is “negligible” on non-Fed days.
 
The paper, titled “The Wisdom of Twitter Crowds: Predicting Stock Market Reactions to FOMC Meetings via Twitter Feeds,” was co-authored by Azar and Lo, finance professor at MIT’s Sloan School and chairman of AlphaSimplex Group LLC, a quant research firm. They used natural language processing techniques to assign a “polarity” score to each tweet, meant to reflect the emotion in the text. That score was then used as a proxy for sentiment.
 
It’s worth testing social media to see if they can improve conventional measures of sentiment, things like technical indicators and survey data that are based on a “relatively sparse” population, they wrote. “The rise of social media allows us to overcome these drawbacks and measure the sentiment of a large number of individuals in real time.”
 
Tweet sentiment as a predictive measure was addressed in a 2015 paper by Johns Hopkins University assistant professor Jim Kyung-Soo Liew, who found that it had power to forecast post-earnings excess returns. Also that year a group of researchers led by University of California-Santa Barbara Ph.D. student Gang Wang found that while social media messages had “minimal correlation” to stock performance in aggregate, a subset of “experts” does in fact contribute more predictive content.
 
One caveat of the MIT study is that it could only examine a relatively homogeneous segment of the market history, the period after which Twitter emerged, which has been marked mostly by rising stocks and an accommodative Fed.
 
The next step for the research will be to see if the strategy of calibrating equity exposure based on Twitter sentiment continues to outperform under more hawkish conditions. Regardless, the findings of the study should be viewed as a piece of a bigger puzzle, according to Azar.
 
“One way people can use our results is as a component in a larger strategy,” he said. “If tweet data can help predict these movements before they happen, then it can help portfolio managers control their exposure to market risk.”
 
8.这个...咳咳，新知识点
 
Data Flash - China: Capital controls became more effective in March 21 April 2016 (1 page/ 199 kb)
 Tightened control on illegal capital outflows contributed to the rebound in FX reserves in March. This is confirmed by the cross-border bank payment data the SAFE released today. In our report Unveiling the channels of capital outflows (Feb 29), we highlighted overpayments for imported goods as a major channel of illegal capital outflows. Between Aug 2015 and Jan 2016, overpayment for goods imports totaled some USD300bn, equivalent to over 70% of the FX reserves decline during that period. We predicted the discrepancy between bank payments and actual imports to narrow, as the government continued to strengthen its control on illegal capital outflows. As data released today show, such gap has indeed declined significantly, from USD57bn in Jan to slightly over USD30bn in March, getting close to the lowest level seen in the past 20 months. This gap will likely remain low, or even shrink further, in coming months. Together with improved near-term growth outlook, it will help to keep FX reserves and USDCNY outlook stable in Q2. The pressure on RMB could come back in H2 though, when growth slows and capital outflows emerge again. We therefore maintain our current forecast of 7.0 for USDCNY by end 2016.
 
 
9.US Daily Economic Notes - Gains in the LEI might be deceptive 20 April 2016 (1 page/ 238 kb)
Commentary for Thursday: The breadth of economic performance is generally a measure of durability. In other words, if the economy is generating broad-based gains, growth is more likely to be sustained. This is because the economy would not be relying on just one or two sectors to drive growth. We remain extremely cautious on the near-term economic outlook because the projected Q1 slowdown in real GDP was likely relatively broad based: Consumption, investment spending, housing and net exports are all anticipated to have slowed relative to their Q4 2015 growth rates. Unlike Q1 2015, when most of the weakness in output was due to a plunge in net exports that resulted from the West Coast port slowdown, there are no such excuses this year. In fact, the weather has been much better this year, as well. In the first quarter of 2014 and 2015, record cold temperatures afflicted much of the Midwest and Northeast, and could have weighed on factory sector output. Recall that many shipping lanes across the Great Lakes were frozen. If anything, this year's more "normal" weather conditions should at the margin have been a mild positive for growth. Instead, it appears the economy expanded by only 0.5% last quarter, which is extremely disappointing given the fact that output grew only 1.4% in the quarter before. 
More troubling to us than the expected weakness in Q1 2016 real GDP is the diminishing breadth of gains in the composite of leading economic indicators (LEI). In the chart below, we show the three-month moving average of the diffusion index of the LEI, because the data can be volatile. Incidentally, data for March are released this morning. While we are projecting a 0.3% increase in the March LEI, most of that gain will be attributable to the rising stock market. Therefore, the decline in breadth may continue. We can see from the chart that breadth has been declining: In February, only four out of the 10 series contributed positively to the LEI (jobless claims, new consumer goods orders, yield curve and leading credit index); five series made a negative contribution (ISM new orders, nondefense capital goods orders, building permits, stock prices and consumer expectations) and one series (average workweek) had no impact on the LEI because its reading was unchanged. Notice, too, that breadth in the LEI tends to peak well before the onset of recession. For example, prior to the 2001 and 2007 downturns, the three-month moving average of the diffusion index was 23% and 27%, respectively. Consequently, we should be on guard for sub-30% readings. 
 
What you have to do and the way you have to do it is incredibly simple. Whether you are willing to do it, that's another matter.
Peter Drucker,management consultant and writer

2.US Daily Economic Notes - Housing: Glass half full or half empty? （窥一斑而知全豹还是一叶障目？）19 April 2016 (1 page/ 250 kb)
Commentary for Wednesday: This week's housing data have thus far been disappointing. Yesterday's housing starts (1.089M vs. 1.194M) and building permits (1.086M vs. 1.177M) reports showed sharp declines, and Monday's National Association of Homebuilders' (NAHB) housing market index (58 vs. 58) was unchanged at a level well below last October's cyclical high (65). It would be concerning if housing demand were to slow materially—in addition to the aforementioned data, the Senior Loan Officer Survey shows declining demand for residential mortgages over the past two quarters—despite the fact that housing-related activity remains suppressed by historical standards. 
The chart below shows the share of housing-related spending in nominal GDP. The former equals the sum of private residential investment, housing and utilities services expenditures, and spending on furnishings and durable household equipment. Between 1960 and 2000, the housing-related share of GDP averaged 17.9%. Although this historical average omits the housing boom of the 2000s, it is well above the share as of Q4 2015 (17.4%). 
To be sure, the housing market was expected to be weak in the aftermath of the recession, as households repaired their severely-impaired balance sheets. However, household deleveraging is now complete, mortgage rates are low and banks have been loosening lending standards for residential mortgages. Therefore, an optimistic perspective is that the recent data are an aberration and housing will contribute meaningfully to growth in the remainder of this cycle. After all, housing-related spending has exceeded its historical average in every economic expansion since 1960, peaking considerably in excess of 18% in most cases. Moreover, the peak has generally occurred late in the cycle, suggesting that an acceleration in housing activity could be imminent. 
However, it appears that the housing sector will take an extended period of time to fully heal from the structural damage wrought by the collapse of 2007-09. Even though job growth has been strong, housing starts and building permits remain substantially below historically normal readings of about 1.5M. The weakness in these series, combined with the fact that housing inflation has consistently been running over 3%, suggests that housing supply is inelastic: Increased demand appears to have manifested disproportionately in elevated prices rather than greater real output. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that income growth is now slowing. Therefore, although we do expect the housing sector to outperform the rest of the economy in the next few quarters, we are only cautiously optimistic on housing. 
 
 
3.美国《纽约时报》和有线电视新闻网（CNN）18日分别援引各自消息源称，沙特外交大臣阿德尔朱拜尔上月访问美国时，曾向美国国会发出警告，一旦这一法案获得通过，沙特将“不得不出售”多至7500亿美元的美国国债及沙特持有的其他美元资产，以免它们遭美国法院冻结。报道说，美国国务院和国防部过去数周一直与国会方面“紧张讨论”沙特方面的警告，美国政府方面敦促国会不要通过这一法案。政府方面警告国会，一旦沙特采取这一措施，会危及美国经济。就如果国会通过这一法案，奥巴马总统是否打算行使否决权以阻止法案生效，一名美国政府高级官员没有正面回应，只是说国会必须“更加审慎地考虑”法案可能引发的后果。沙特阿拉伯是美国在中东地区的主要和传统盟友。针对沙特所发警告，曾主持国会调查“9c11”袭击的前参议员鲍勃c格雷厄姆16日接受美国有线电视新闻网记者采访时回应道，他对沙特的反应“十分愤怒，但不意外”。格雷厄姆说：“沙特人知道他们在事件里干了什么。他们也知道，我们知道他们干了什么，至少美国政府最高层知道（他们干了什么）。”——还好尚处在参议员层级，trump会拿这儿说事儿吗？
 
4.很少发欧洲的单篇，就是提醒自己欧洲情况还是不错的..也是提到了财政政策
European Economics Quarterly
 
Under the threat of political risk
 
 
Read the full report »<https://live.barcap.com/go/publications/email?FC2227416&m=1457766006145&v=MdhpP0k3qcd2uMttUXAuFoU16Ycnw3iYhXKWNcANZX0Ma8AXj1FqHeRJUmAOrArZ>
 
·         Economic activity has been resilient in the face of the global economic deterioration so far, but business surveys, both for the euro area and the UK, are now pointing to clear downside risks. We expect growth to slow marginally in the euro area from 1.5% in 2015 to 1.4% in 2016, and more significantly in the UK from 2.3% to 1.5%, respectively, as a result of uncertainties in the run-up to the referendum on EU membership.
 
·         Despite very expansionary monetary policies all across Europe, inflation has remained well below central banks’ targets over the past two years and is likely to remain so at least until the end of 2017(油价有望站稳40+，估计这句话很快就要删了). In the euro area, we expect inflation to average 0.1% this year and to rebound only to 1.0% next year.
 
·         (Geo)political risks are taking centre stage. The humanitarian disaster in Syria and Europe’s struggle to cope with the migration challenge, outstanding hurdles to the Greek programme review, political instability in some member states and mounting euro scepticism in others could be exacerbated by a UK vote to leave the EU.
 
·         After the easing package announced at the March meeting, we think the ECB’s monetary policy is approaching the limits of what it can reasonably do to support demand and inflation. We think that a more growth-friendly fiscal policy at the aggregate level, the clean-up of banks’ balance sheets in some countries (including Italy and Portugal), along with decisive steps towards a full-fledged economic and financial union would restore confidence in the future of the currency union and support economic growth. We would consider such a policy response as essential for Europe in the event of a UK vote to exit the EU.
 
 
5.近期市场热点
 
Afternoon notes – central bank vol killers
 
1. Queen Yellen – the S&P (and EM FX) rally is impressive but looking behind the party curtain it’s worth highlighting that it seems to be mostly conditional on one thing: a very dovish Fed（提防7月）. It’s not really a growth story as US data is mixed ( {CESI index <GO>} again topped out at zero ) and very much focused on US equities that are massively outperforming everywhere else, note S&P a few % points of 2015 highs compared to a staggering 20% for Europe/Japan/EM (same goes for inflation breakevens)（sp只是涨了一点点，欧日都跌去两成以上，谁比谁不那么差）. This then makes next week FOMC hugely important, could they complain against no 2016 hike priced (like last October) and lead things to unravel（市场上还有一种说法，就是fed非常重视股市强劲带来的财富效应）. Given data not convincing and Yellen speeches recent, find it doubtful/too soon.
 
2. BoJ vaguely interesting – somewhat contrary to purpose central banks have been the major sources of vol in recent years yet beyond the Fed hard to see ECB on Thursday generating excitement either. Draghi is highly likely in “wait and see” mode leaving only BoJ next week as interesting(4-27/8). Certainly can’t rule out potential higher ETF/JGB program but given little priced hard to see this as risk-disruptor either. In FX note CVIX hugely lagging VIX and with most near-term metrics showing EURUSD and USDJPY close to fair value (1.15 and 110 respectively,同是db分析师用beer法测量是105) main conclusion seems further collapse in vol/carry rally. 
 
3. Time to forget oil – for all the focus on oil what is notable is that the market is fast losing interest, the 20-day correlation with stocks or US high-yield spreads is rapidly deteriorating. The market is trying to transition into a new theme/market narrative which for now seems to be one of no news is good news（只要央妈们不说话，当下大宗涨股市涨日元企稳等等就会继续）, especially from central bankers. Best guess is disruption eventually comes from central banks (Fed), geopolitics (Brexit) or major fiscal story (China stimulus runs out of steam,可能吗) but in meantime hard to call it quits on the silent disco.
 
6.28日当晚q1 GDP，可能不到1。
Sent: Tuesday, April 19, 2016 01:17 PM
Subject: DB: Upside risks to Q2 GDP
 
Clients are asking me whether the weak first quarter GDP will be followed by a strong second quarter GDP, as has been the pattern for the past five years, because then we should over the coming months expect higher rates, higher dollar, and higher equities. The underlying question is whether the deep recession in the first quarter of 2009 created "residual seasonality," which will distort first quarter GDP estimates for many years, see chart below. The Fed has also been debating this issue, with the San Francisco Fed saying that there is evidence of residual seasonality and the New York Fed saying there is no evidence of residual seasonality, see also these two pieces here:
 
Fed (San Francisco): The Puzzle of Weak First-Quarter GDP Growth
http://www.frbsf.org/economic-research/files/el2015-16.pdf
 
Fed (New York): The Myth of First-Quarter Residual Seasonality
 
 
7.crowed bus是house特别爱用的一个表述，往往因profit-taking引发调整而导致市场转向
 
This is how buses get crowded. Too early to stay in front of the bus. Later closer to May, we will probably get worried about something we wouldn't now.. And sell off. Not today's problem.
Today was a historical one for Argentina.. Back into the market.. It lifted off not only EM, but spirit of other asset classes as well.
Meanwhile, Brazil impeachment excitement is almost overshadowed.. Receiving rates（看低巴西利率） interest should continue there as well.
Low housing number ensured core rates stayed glued. And that in itself makes the search for yield more attractive.
In the G7 currency land, GBP is the one with the biggest move, post more Remain poll win hopes.. That remains my personal prediction.
GS results came as bad as most feared.. Especially in FIC area.. Doha has been disappointment.. But both just shrugged off. Oil is higher than Friday levels.
Low expectations from ECB Thursday.. Probably higher expectations from next week's Kuroda, but probably too early for that.
Italy banks still sending signs that some people are thinking sinister.
But today's not the time for it.. At the moment, music is for the bus to get more full. Sooner or later, post positioning getting more crowded, we will find reasons to get more nervous.

3.http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/10657-B0C2/87399937/DB_SpecialReport_2016-04-18_0900b8c08b043f3f.pdf<http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/10657-B0C2/87399937/DB_SpecialReport_2016-04-18_0900b8c08b043f3f.pdf>
 
Freeze would not have been a meaningful constraint
 
Even if producers had agreed to freeze oil supply at the January 2016 level for six months until October, this would have meant little for market fundamentals (OPEC slushy?, 7 April). We say this because the prospective agreement was said to exclude both Iran and Libya, the only countries with potential to grow production in the short term. Our fundamental supply-demand model therefore remains unchanged.
 
Symbolic positive turns into a negative
 
As it happened, the rift between Saudi Arabia and Iran proved to be the decisive factor, turning what might have been a symbolically positive event into a negative and casting a shadow over the potential for any agreement at the next scheduled meeting on 2 June. In other words, it now appears likely that both Saudi Arabia and Iran will maintain their incompatible positions.
 
How does the Kuwait oil strike factor in?
 
Simultaneous with the producer meeting in Doha, Kuwait oil workers went on strike on Sunday over cuts to salaries and benefits, with 7,000 of 13,000 workers walking off the job immediately as a result. While the impact to oil production has been significant with a reduction from 2.8 mmb/d down to 1.1 mmb/d, according to Reuters, a government spokesman stated that oil production was already recovering and that a normal level was not far off.
 
A possible recovery in the Partitioned Neutral Zone
 
In the absence of a freeze, the Partitioned Neutral Zone shared between Saudi Arabia and Kuwait could theoretically pose an additional upside risk to supply beyond Iran and Libya. Kuwait have claimed that there is an agreement to restart the offshore Khafji field (220 kb/d) this year. However, the fact that neither Saudi nor Kuwaiti oil production has suffered substantially since the gradual shutdown of the Neutral Zone over 2014-15 suggests that a restart may simply take the pressure off of other fields which may now be compensating for lost production.
 
2017 non-OPEC production likely to be modestly lower
 
Looking into 2017 we believe risks for non-OPEC production in a year's time are rising as Q1-2016 year-on-year production growth figures now show a number of non-OPEC countries where last year's growth has turned into this year's decline, and other non-OPEC countries where declines from last year are continuing this year. As a consequence we expect balances may be tightened modestly in 2017 as a result.
 
4.US Daily Economic Notes - Risks to factory sector abound despite modest recovery 18 April 2016 (1 page/ 244 kb)
Commentary for Tuesday: March housing starts and building permits(今晚8:30) are expected to show slight gains, led by the multi-family sector. Going forward, we are projecting residential construction gains in the high-single to low-double digits. Residential construction will remain a relative bright spot in what has been a historically weak economic expansion. This is another reason why the Yellen-led Fed will be extremely cautious in raising interest rates. Policymakers do not want to do anything that could adversely impact the housing market. 
Tomorrow we get March existing home sales (5.15M vs. 5.08M), which are expected to grind higher. Unless we create more housing supply—meaning housing starts return to normal readings of around 1.500M per annum—the selling rate of existing homes is likely to be capped at 5.50M units. 
On Thursday, we get jobless claims for the employment survey week (285k vs. 253k), the April Philadelphia Fed survey (+5.0 vs. +12.4) and the March index of leading economic indicators (+0.5% vs. +0.1%). Claims are expected to be temporarily elevated due to the Verizon strike. Excluding this one-off factor, however, claims are extremely low by historical standards. 
The Philadelphia Fed index is expected to remain in positive territory for the second consecutive month, consistent with the rebound in the New York Fed Empire Survey, whose results were released last week. More importantly, another positive reading on the Philadelphia Fed Survey would point to another 50-plus reading on the manufacturing ISM, which is one of our favorite economic releases. The chart below shows that the New York ISM-adjusted series also suggests a modest expansionary reading on the latter. 
The sharp recovery in US stock prices and a significantly weaker dollar have together boosted purchasing managers' sentiment. This has been most evident in the new orders component. However, we are still cautious on the factory sector, because if equity markets wobble or the US dollar re-strengthens, purchasing managers' recent optimism could quickly fade. Moreover, economy-wide inventory positions are elevated relative to demand. This suggests we could still experience a pullback in production. Additionally, the global economy is weak, implying that US exports could stay soft. In general, it is hard for us to see the economy doing much better than just muddling along. Lastly, while the index of leading economic indicators is expected to increase after declining at a -1.6% annualized rate over the previous three months, the breadth of the gains in the series is likely to be fairly narrow.
