2.US Daily Economic Notes - Will inflation lose momentum? 14 April 2016 (2 pages/ 225 kb)
Commentary for Friday: We learned on Wednesday that headline producer prices were down -0.1% last month, as were core prices. The most relevant series in the report is the healthcare component, which is almost perfectly correlated with healthcare PCE inflation. The former series also decreased by -0.1% in March. As a result, the year-over-year rate fell from 1.4% to 1.1%, partially reversing a substantial acceleration in healthcare prices that began last fall. Healthcare is the largest component of the core PCE, with a share of 19%. Therefore, it is no surprise that core PCE inflation has increased from its recent trough of 1.26% in July 2015 to 1.68% as of this February. Of this 42 basis-point (bp) increase, the table below shows that healthcare has been responsible for over a third (15 bps). However, the March PPI report implies that healthcare could suppress core PCE inflation in March by about -5 bps. 
Meanwhile, housing inflation remains above 3%, propping up the core. The effect of housing prices on core inflation is even more pronounced in the CPI because shelter comprises 42% of the core CPI, while housing is just 18% of the core PCE. Yesterday's CPI report showed that core prices increased by 0.1% in March, causing the year-over-year rate to fall by a tenth to 2.2%. While this is still a fairly robust reading, core inflation ex shelter remains weak: The 12-month growth rate of this series fell a tenth last month to 1.5%. This suggests that the strength in core inflation is not broad based. To be sure, ex-shelter core inflation has shown meaningful improvement in the past two quarters, as its year-over-year rate was below 1% as recently as October 2015. It is particularly important for this series to maintain its upward momentum because there are nascent signs that housing inflation could soon start to decline. First, rental vacancy rates have stabilized after falling rapidly since the end of the recession. Second, the Senior Loan Officer Survey suggests that demand for residential mortgage loans declined over the past two quarters. 
A slowdown in core inflation would be consistent with the ongoing deceleration in income and personal consumption. In fact, we expect both core CPI and core PCE inflation to decline slightly from their present levels by yearend. Price pressures should remain quiescent next year, as well. For this reason, we expect that the Fed will have very limited scope to raise policy rates in the next several quarters
 
 
3.US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 15 April 2016 (1 page/ 217 kb)
Commentary for Monday: Today is likely the only day of the week on which we will hear from monetary policymakers as we are about to enter the self-imposed FOMC blackout period. Of the scheduled speakers, NY Fed President Dudley should garner the most attention as his views have been closely aligned with Chair Yellen's. The Fed meets on April 26-27. There will be no press conference and updated forecasts will not be released. The Fed will not have the Q1 GDP data, but policymakers will go into the meeting assuming that Q1 growth was weak. The April FOMC statement is expected to be dovish, thus making it very difficult for the Fed to hike at its next meeting in June. The fed funds futures market is discounting approximately a 15% chance of a June rate hike. Our own estimate of the probability is slightly less. In terms of this week's economic data, they are mostly on the residential housing market. 
Today's National Association of Homebuilders' (NAHB) housing market index is expected to increase slightly, continuing what has been a historically modest housing recovery. The NAHB series peaked at 65 last October and slipped to a 58 reading in both February and March. We are expecting the series to remain range bound because mortgage rates have been steady, and job gains have been relatively consistent at roughly a 2% annualized rate. 
Tomorrow brings the March housing starts (1.200M forecast vs. 1.178M previously) and building permits (1.200M vs. 1.177M) figures. We are looking for slight gains in both series, led by the multi-family sector. Going forward, we are projecting residential construction gains in the high-single to low-double digits. Residential construction will remain a relative bright spot in what has been a historically weak economic expansion. This is another reason why the Yellen-led Fed will be extremely cautious in raising interest rates. Policymakers do not want to do anything that could adversely impact the housing market. 
On Wednesday we get March existing home sales (5.15M vs. 5.08M), which are expected to grind higher. Unless we create more housing supply—meaning housing starts return to normal readings of around 1.500M per annum—the selling rate of existing homes is likely to be capped at 5.50M units. 
We get jobless claims, the April Philadelphia Fed survey (+5.0 vs. +12.4) and the March index of leading economic indicators (+0.5% vs. +0.1%) on Thursday. Claims remain extremely low by historical standards, and next week's figures take on elevated importance because they correspond to the April employment survey week. The Philadelphia Fed index is expected to remain in positive territory for the second consecutive month. If so, it would point to another 50-plus reading on the manufacturing ISM survey, which is one of our favorite economic releases. However, we do not believe the manufacturing sector is out of the woods yet. Inventory positions remain elevated relative to demand, which means we could still experience a pullback in production, and the global economy is weak, implying that US exports could stay soft. However, the sharp recovery in US stock prices and a significantly weaker dollar have together boosted purchasing managers' sentiment. These trends could continue in the near term, which would be a definite plus for an economy that is only muddling along. Finally, the index of leading economic indicators (LEI) is expected to increase after declining at a -1.6% annualized rate over the previous three months. The catalyst behind the expected gain in the LEI is the surge in stock prices. This highlights the manner in which financial market conditions can influence real economic activity. 
 
 
4.Everyone Worries Too Much About 'Black Swans'
 
In his 2007 book "The Black Swan: The Impact of the Highly Improbable," finance writer Nassim Nicholas Taleb attempted to educate the public about the danger of rare, unusual events. This is obviously important in the world of finance -- asset market crashes come infrequently, but have an enormous impact on investors’ wealth, and potentially on the economy. Taleb implies that human beings underestimate the risk of these so-called black swans -- in fact, he started one<http://www.businessinsider.com/why-didnt-nassim-taleb-make-money-after-911-2009-6> hedge fund (which closed in 2005), and advised another<http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nassim-talebs-black-swan-fund-made-1-billion-this-week-2015-08-28-171033431>, based on this thesis. But how often do people low ball the odds of catastrophe? And is it possible that we might do the opposite, overestimating the risk of things like stock-market crashes, pandemics and wars?
 
The problem with rare events is that they’re almost impossible to predict by looking at the past. Usually, when we want to determine how likely something is, we rely on some variation of a basic, classic procedure. We take the frequency that the thing has happened in the past, and this becomes our guess of how likely it is to happen in the future. If Atlanta has had sunny days 74 percent of the time during the past 50 years, then our best guess for the probability of a sunny day in Atlanta is 74 percent. Usually, we bring in other data, like recent global weather patterns or seasonal variations, to help improve the estimate.
 
But those guesses come with a lot of uncertainty. The rarer something is -- a volcanic eruption or an asteroid strike -- the more hazy our projection about its probability becomes. If we only have a short period of history with which to formulate our guesses, the problem is even worse -- imagine trying to predict the likelihood of a hurricane hitting Houston based only on the weather report from the previous week. And if we have no good underlying theory of why something happens -- for example, nobody really knows what causes stock-market crashes -- then our job of estimating the probability is basically hopeless.
 
This is a very big problem in investing. There are lots of rare events that matter a huge amount -- market crashes, regime shifts and bond defaults. We don’t have good theories for why most of these things happen. So statistical analysis, though it can help a little bit, isn't very effective in assessing the risk of disastrous financial-market events.
 
What do we do when we have to make a forecast, but the past offers little guidance? We rely on other things -- our hunches, gut reactions and untested theories.
 
In 2007, Harvard economist Martin Weitzman showed how<http://scholar.harvard.edu/files/weitzman/files/subjective-aer.pdf> this could explain the high returns we’ve seen in the U.S. stock market during the past few decades. The phenomenon of mysteriously high investment returns, called the equity premium puzzle, has been studied by financial economists for many years, but Weitzman’s explanation is probably the most compelling. When people have only vague notions about the underlying forces driving the stock market, they will change these ideas frequently as events unfold. Those changing guesses represent a kind of risk, which lowers stock prices today, causing them to have a higher return in the future. Essentially, people avoid stocks because they’re afraid they don’t understand what’s going on in the market.
 
Weitzman shows how people can act like they believe in black swans even if no black swans are actually present. But his model also implies that even if black swans do exist, people will act as if these unusual events occur much more than the historical record indicates.
 
In other words, Taleb might be wrong -- people might be overestimating, rather than underestimating, the risk of market crashes.
 
Some recent survey evidence<http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2750638> indicates that this might be true. William Goetzmann, Dasol Kim and the Nobel-winning economist Robert Shiller looked at 26 years of survey data, and found that people consistently say they expect things like stock-market crashes and earthquakes to happen more frequently than they really do. This is exactly the opposite of what Taleb might predict.
 
Of course, survey research like this has to come with a caveat -- people are probably not able to precisely report their own guesses about probabilities. But surveys have proven increasingly useful<http://noahpinionblog.blogspot.com/2015/07/survey-expectations-some-more-evidence.html> in predicting investor sentiment, so this evidence shouldn’t be discounted.
 
So what does this mean for investors? It says that simply betting that the market is understating the probability of a crash is unlikely to yield market-beating returns. People following the opposite advice -- buying and holding stocks for long periods of time -- have done much better over the long run than people who think stocks are consistently overvalued. Maybe the way to make money is acting as if black swans don't exist, even if they do show up from time to time.

William Shakespeare,playwright and poet

2.US Daily Economic Notes - If rather than when 11 April 2016 (1 page/ 220 kb)
Commentary for Tuesday: Nonfarm payrolls increased 209k on average over the last three months. While this pace of job growth is down from its recent peak of 282k for the three months ending December 2015, it is reasonably solid. Yet, real GDP growth has been weak. The economy expanded just 1.4% at an annualized rate in Q4 2015, and we project that the initial Q1 2016 snapshot of real GDP, released on April 28, will show only 0.5% growth. Expectations of soft Q1 output (for the third consecutive year) will likely keep the FOMC in a dovish stance when it meets on April 26 and 27. Policymakers will not have the GDP data at the time, but relatively downbeat expectations may cause the Fed to continue to strike a cautious tone. Unless the economic data between now and the upcoming FOMC meeting are significantly stronger than what we currently anticipate, which is possible but unlikely in our view, policymakers will refrain from re-adding the "balance of risks" sentence to the April meeting statement. If so, it will be very difficult—but not impossible—for the FOMC to raise rates at its June 14-15 meeting. However, the British EU referendum is on June 23. The Fed will be cognizant of the fact that a rate hike would exacerbate likely US dollar appreciation due to "Brexit". 
While a rate hike at the July 26-27 meeting is possible, its odds are somewhat reduced by the fact that there is no press conference after this meeting. Note also that this meeting coincides with the Democratic National Convention (July 25-28) and is only a few days after the Republican National Convention (July 18-21). The September 20-21 FOMC meeting is relatively close to the Presidential Election (November 8), so unless there is strong evidence that the US economy is growing above trend, and global financial markets are relatively stable, we expect the Fed to refrain from hiking in September. We highly doubt the Fed would raise rates at its November meeting, which is six days before the US election. If by the December 13-14 FOMC meeting underlying GDP growth were tracking above 2%, then perhaps the Fed could raise rates. The futures market is signaling essentially the same scenario: The implied probability of one 25 basis-point rate hike this year is barely above 50%. Given our tepid expectations of real GDP growth, the risk is that the Fed does not hike at all this year. As long as policymakers fear that any rate hikes could dampen growth, they will remain on the sidelines. But if employment is so strong, how bad can the economy really be? 
Real GDP growth approximately equals the sum of the growth rates of labor input and productivity. The former can be robust while the latter is weak, and that has indeed been the case. Productivity declined -2.2% in Q4 2015 and is up only 0.5% over the past year. In the process, corporate profit margins, which are a leading indicator of the economy, likely shrunk further last quarter. Employment, specifically nonfarm payrolls, can oftentimes be a lagging economic indicator. Hence, it should come as no surprise to students of US business cycle history that job gains can be relatively robust shortly before the onset of recession. To be clear, we are not projecting an outright recession, whose probability we put at around one in three. However, investors should take little comfort in what has been very good job growth over the past couple of years. Rather, market participants should be focusing on leading indicators of the economy. In that regard, jobless claims, which are among our favorite leading indicators, remain low, a good sign for continued employment gains. 
 
3. From: ALEKSANDAR KOCIC (DEUTSCHE BANK SECURI) At: Apr 11 2016 15:54:57——交易哲学，就是第一段和后面的似乎没什么联系
Subject: Fwd:The tropic of chaos
Despite record corporate profits we are not seeing a commensurate(相称的) rebound in demand. Behind this disconnect lies continued trend of consolidation, growing concentration of ownership and general focus on increasing the monopolistic power (i.e. giving up commitment to competition). Backed by strong shareholder mentality and strict fiscal discipline, the profits are effectively being hoarded（堆积）. Anyone who has recently traveled on one of the major airlines (coach, of course) would have no difficulties connecting the dots: Even as the price of fuel (one of main expenses) collapsed, little of that benefit was passed on to consumers (or airline employees). The airlines story is paradigmatic （范式）as it captures rather accurately the mechanism behind the US economic slowdown.
 
The existing economic paradigms no longer seem to be relevant to the problems we are actually facing. Current market trends have created environments where standard macroeconomic models are of little help. As a consequence, people are gradually giving up general macro frameworks and embracing tactical trading. With shrinking of the time horizons and the help of technology, short-term has become so fast that it leaves no room for human intervention. So, all efforts are aimed at designing automated (black-box) platforms capable of competing in an ever accelerating environment. In this way, responsibility has not been eliminated; it has been merely averted from the forecasting to the design stage.
 
Bottom line, we are experiencing a gradual loss of all frames of reference. The market is trading without a backbone -- it has lost its robustness and stability and become highly vulnerable to even minor disruptions. Without a backbone markets become non-adaptive and disoriented: the market dynamics is defined by black boxes talking to each other. There is no informational value in the market flows and subsequent reaction and output they trigger have no informational content or value either. The system becomes chaotic, i.e. highly sensitive to initial conditions.
 
As long as there is no disturbance to the market, some kind of stability could be maintained. However, relatively benign shocks are capable of causing unforeseeable changes. The apparent calm that we have been experiencing in the last weeks could be deceptive and short lived. We would use current decline in vol as an opportunity to buy the wings as a hedge against market turbulence in the second half of the year. We recommend:

Its down as much as 3.7% post mkt.

2.US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 08 April 2016 (1 page/ 221 kb)
Commentary for Monday: There are no economic releases of consequence either today or tomorrow. Wednesday is the first day of the week we get meaningful economic information. It comes in the form of retail sales, the producer price index (PPI), business inventories and the Fed's beige book. Of these aforementioned series, retail sales are the most important, because they provide us with information on the state of consumer spending, which accounts for nearly 70% of real output. Thus far, the Q1 expenditure data have been disappointing. For example, the level of February real spending is up only 1.7% at an annualized rate compared to its Q4 2015 average. This pace, if sustained in March, would be the weakest for inflation-adjusted consumer spending growth since Q1 2014 (1.3%). We are projecting flat headline retail sales because of softness in unit motor vehicle sales, but retail sales excluding autos should be up modestly (+0.3% estimate vs. -0.1% previously). 
While we are generally constructive on the state of consumer spending—the job market has been healthy and household deleveraging has been completed—it is the non-consumer portion of the economy that investors should worry about. Currently, the ratio of nonfinancial corporate debt to national income is nearly 45%, an elevated reading that suggests corporate balance sheets are not in particularly good shape. The situation is exacerbated by what appears to have been another quarter in which corporate profit growth and profit margins were under pressure. The nearly 2% increase in employment growth last quarter, combined with our expectation of just a 0.5% increase in Q1 economic output, points to a second consecutive quarter of negative productivity growth readings. Of course, real GDP growth could rebound later this year—our view is that the snapback will be modest and the economy will simply muddle through. But if activity strengthens, the labor market would tighten further and the likelihood of faster wage growth would increase. In turn, this would engender more Fed rate hikes. This would not necessarily be good news for the corporate sector because in this environment, the labor share of income would be rising while the corporate share of income would be declining. At present, it is hard to see a sharp upturn in capital spending even if energy prices have bottomed and are on the mend. 
The March PPI (+0.2% vs. -0.2%) is released alongside retail sales and should be up due to higher energy prices. Meanwhile, the core PPI (+0.2% vs. Unch.) is slated to increase on the back of stronger services prices. Business inventories, which are released later in the morning, are likely to decline (-0.2% vs. Unch.). We are looking for a relatively large inventory correction in Q1—we estimate that de-stocking could take roughly one percentage point off output. 
On Thursday, we get the March consumer price index (CPI). Similar to the PPI, the headline CPI (+0.2% vs. -0.2%) should be boosted by the recent rebound in energy. However, we expect a smaller increase in the core (+0.1% vs. +0.3%) because of significantly weaker apparel prices, which had risen by a record amount in the previous two months. While the CPI is a top-tier indicator for the financial markets, the near-term data may be somewhat less relevant given Chair Yellen's recent emphasis on the broader global economy. We finish the week with the April NY Fed Empire survey (+1.0 vs. +0.6), March industrial production (-0.5% vs. -0.5%) and April preliminary University of Michigan consumer sentiment (91.0 vs. 91.0) reports on Friday. On balance, these data are expected to be relatively soft. 
 
3.From: Torsten Slok  换一种角度看美国经济前景近期
Sent: Saturday, April 09, 2016 10:35 PM
Subject: DB: 10 downside risks to the US economic outlook
 
I have been marketing in Europe this week and many clients continue to worry that the US economy is at the cusp of a recession. When I ask clients what the source of a significant slowdown should be then I hear different combinations of the following arguments:
1) Late cycle signals from credit markets
2) Slowdown in earnings, including ex-energy
3) Profit margins at all time highs
4) China, including Chinese FX policy, NPLs in Chinese banks, and too much leverage and too much dollar denominated debt in Chinese corporates
5) Worries about banks' ability and willingness to lend
6) More downside risk to oil prices and more adjustment coming from the energy sector
7) Inventory correction
8) The economy cannot handle higher rates and therefore the Fed will create a recession when they hike rates
9) "Too much debt"
10) Increased vulnerability of the US economy and the global economy as central banks have run out of ammunition
 
Many of these issues are indeed real risks to the outlook and taken together this list of downside risks is worrying.
 
But the first question to ask yourself is the following: If these 10 headwinds are so strong, why is nonfarm payrolls still +200k? If these headwinds are so strong why have we seen a solid rebound in both manufacturing and nonmanufacturing ISM? Is the solid move up in manufacturing ISM not a sign that the negative effects of low oil and high dollar on the economy are beginning to fade? Similarly, is the move up in core PCE from 1.3% six months ago to 1.7% today not a sign that the negative forces holding US inflation down (dollar and oil) are beginning to fade?
 
More generally, it is important to think about the nature of each of these 10 downside risks to the outlook. Looking at each of the risks, the question is if they are new or have been around for a long time or if some of the risks aren't simply fears of something that has not happened and may not happen in the future.
 
With this in mind, let's take a look at each if these downside risks to the outlook.
 
1) Late cycle signals from credit markets.
Some parts of credit markets related to energy and resources are indeed flashing red. But, credit markets at the moment are bifurcated with some parts of indexes at very wide spreads and other large parts of credit markets trading at narrow spreads. This shows that some sectors in the economy are not doing well but the rest of the economy is doing just fine. In other words, this does not point to an economy-wide recession but to a recession in certain sectors in the economy. Also, IG markets are four times bigger than HY, and IG markets are open for business showing that the credit system is functioning well for the vast majority of companies with solid balance sheets and business plans.
 
2) Slowdown in earnings, including ex-energy.
We have seen a slowdown in S&P500 earnings, also outside energy, materials, and industrials. What is important to keep in mind is that the economy has not only been hit by lower oil prices but also by the rising dollar. These two shocks are therefore the relevant dimensions when looking at equities and earnings.  And the key is to ask what earnings look like outside energy and manufacturing (which was hit by the dollar). With the big fall in oil and big dollar appreciation behind us and with manufacturing ISM rebounding there are good reasons to believe that the slowdown in S&P500 earnings is temporary and we should over the coming quarters see a rebound is overall earnings. So yes, earnings have been slowing but given the turnaround in oil and the dollar, earnings are likely to accelerate again over the coming quarters.
 
3) Profit margins at all time highs.
This argument is peculiar, why should the level of profits have any predictive power on the business cycle? From a profit margin perspective the issue going forward is that wage growth is likely to continue to be lower than topline growth. As a result margins are likely to continue to stay high.
 
4) China, including Chinese FX policy, NPLs in Chinese banks, and too much leverage and too much dollar denominated debt in Chinese corporates.
These risks are truly exogenous to the US economic outlook, and the transmission channels to the US economic outlook and the magnitude of any impact is very difficult to quantify. In my view, the Chinese authorities have over the past several decades again and again proven they have the willingness and ability to manage problems in their economy and I continue to think that they will also be able to manage their current challenges. A hard landing or a significant disruption in the Chinese financial system or a big FX devaluation would be undesirable from a political and social stability perspective.
 
5) Worries about banks' ability and willingness to lend.
The weekly data for US bank lending growth continues to be around 7% to 8% indicating that there are no signs of any credit crunch in the banking sector. More importantly, all banks globally have been shrinking their balance sheets, which also means that more credit in the economy comes from other sources than banks namely credit markets and the shadow banking sector, including a rising share from Fintech. This doesn't mean that the banks don't matter but it means that the banks from a macro credit extension perspective are less important today.
 
6) More downside risk to oil prices and much more adjustment coming from the energy sector.
Oil prices can potentially fall back into the $20s again but the consensus expects oil at $50 by the end of the year, and it continues to be the case that lower oil prices is a net benefit to the economy. Also, the energy sector has been stepping on the brakes since 2014, with energy capex essentially falling 50% and we are getting to the end of the runway where the negative impact on GDP will be smaller and smaller. Or put differently, imagine how much higher nonfarm payrolls today would have been if we had not been through the adjustment in the energy sector over the past 2 years.
 
7) Inventory correction.
We wrote about this a few weeks ago in our GEP and the bottom line is that an inventory correction is obviously temporary and generally only lasts one or two quarters.
 
8) The economy cannot handle higher rates and therefore the Fed will create a recession once they hike rates.
This is a popular prediction. First, many people in 2015 said that the Fed could not even raise rates once, because once they did it the economy would crash. Obviously this turned out to be a wrong prediction. Second, FOMC member Brainard has said that the turbulence in markets in January and February tightened financial conditions so much that it corresponded to 2-3 Fed rate hikes. Let's now look at how the economy did in the face of 2-3 rate hikes in January and February. It did just fine with nonfarm payrolls at +200k. In other words, we have just been through a period that corresponds to 2-3 Fed hikes and the economy performed very well. This suggests that the economy is able to handle higher rates and the Fed hiking rates over the coming quarters is not going to generate a recession.
 
9) "Too much debt"
I hear this argument frequently, and every time I discuss this with clients I ask what the link should be from debt levels (government, consumer, corporates) to the US economy? Debt levels on their own don't matter for growth, what matters are the costs of borrowing, which generally continue to be very low for both the private sector and government sector in the US.
 
10) Increased vulnerability of the US economy and the global economy as central banks have run out of ammunition.
This issue is not an argument why the US should enter a recession soon. It is more a hypothetical topic in case the economy is hit with a negative shock. But what if we later this year finally reach full employment in the economy and begin to see inflation move higher. Will the market then be focusing on the uptrend in core inflation or on the fact that the Fed during some hypothetical future recession may - or may not if interest rates move higher - have fewer tools?
 
More generally, in many of my client discussions at the moment the expectation is that the next crisis will be a financial crisis like in 2008-2009. But why should that be the case? Think about what the sources of recessions have been over the past 50 years. In 2008-2009 the recession was created by a banking and housing crisis. But in 2000-2001 the recession was triggered by a big IT capex bubble. In the early 1990s the recession came from commercial real estate and in the 1980s the recession was a combination of policy mistakes and in the 1970s the recession was because of too high oil prices (not too low oil prices). The bottom line is that investors should not think that the next recession will be driven by the same forces that triggered the last recession.
 
Instead, one big macro risk in 2016 is that core PCE continues to trend higher and moves above 2%, which could trigger a reaction from the Fed and/or from the long end of the curve. When I say this some clients respond that "we will never see inflation again". If you don't believe that we will ever see inflation again then think about the following: Why has the Fed then already started hiking rates? Why are retailers currently raising minimum wages for workers, why didn’t they do that in 2009 when the unemployment rate was 10%? Why are we currently seeing discussions about raising minimum wages to $15 in California and New York and several other states, why wasn’t this done in 2009? Investors should not ignore these trends and anecdotes, the Fed is watching these issues carefully and they are a very important driver of the speed with which the Fed will raise rates（有点RBS的味道）. And if the Fed decides to ignore these anecdotes and the uptrend we are seeing in core inflation then the risks will grow that the long end of the curve will start reacting.

2.US Daily Economic Notes - Elevated participation is related to employment growth 07 April 2016 (1 page/ 263 kb)
Commentary for Friday: In recent research, we calculated the extent to which non-demographic factors have suppressed labor force participation since the start of the recession ("Participation is not a problem but inventories are an issue", US Economics Weekly, March 18, 2016). Using the latest data from the March employment report, we estimate that this effect is about 1.0 percentage points, or 2.54 million workers. The effect on the unemployment rate of adding these workers to the labor force would depend on whether they were employed. In the worst case, if they were all unemployed, the unemployment rate would be 6.5%. However, this scenario appears to be unduly pessimistic. 
Between September 2015 and March 2016, the labor force expanded by 2.42 million workers, due to net flows from outside the labor force of 1.01 million into employment and 1.41 million into unemployment. In the same six months, the unemployment rate fell from 5.1% to 5.0%. This is because the influx of nonparticipants into unemployment was nearly offset by net flows of 1.37 million from unemployment into employment. As a result, total unemployment was up only 41k, while total employment increased by 2.38 million. 
The chart below shows that flows into the labor force have been more closely correlated with flows into employment than flows into unemployment. We show rolling six-month totals in order to highlight the full extent of the recent increase in participation. Since 2000, the correlation between the change in the labor force and net flows into employment from outside the labor force (86%) has been much higher than the correlation between the former variable and net flows into unemployment from outside the labor force (46%). We have also found that year-over-year labor force growth has historically had a fairly strong negative correlation with the unemployment rate. The upshot is that if we continue to see large increases in participation, it is reasonable to assume that they will be accompanied by relatively strong employment growth. This is intuitive – nonparticipants are more likely to enter the labor market if they are able to find jobs or if they expect to do so soon because other unemployed workers are finding employment. To be sure, we cannot rule out the risk that employment growth will slow briefly even as participation growth continues along its recent trend. However, we doubt such a dynamic would be sustainable as labor force growth would likely soon slow in response to weaker job prospects. Therefore, we do not believe that increased participation poses substantial upside risk to the unemployment rate. In turn, a further increase in participation will be viewed by policymakers as an unambiguous positive.
 
 
3.GEORGE: welcome back QE!
 Over the last few days have been writing about the increasing importance of JPY for risk appetite and the market’s perception of central bank credibility, but there is an additional even more direct linkage with fixed income. The more JPY strengthens the more the odds of FX intervention out of Japan rise. Whether this will work for FX or not is another question (doubtful it would), but in any case such a move would essentially represent an increase in QE flows in the US and possibly Europe. This is because any intervention dollars (and euros) accumulated by the Japanese would end up back into the treasury market. Of course this has been happening with other markets (cf Switzerland) earlier on in the crisis, but the key difference with Japan is that it is a huge market, so intervention could easily increase to the 100s of bn of dollars. For instance, in the last intervention episode in 2010-12 they accumulated 200bn USD. This is arguably an important consideration driving down global fixed income yields. Welcome back, QE!
DAVID GEISKER
14:43:03 George. The ironic point is the world is actually looking better when we are more worried aboout QE
GEORGE SARAVELOS

So the more we expect it, the more we worry that it's not really doing anything. Worst of every world! ce distortions, higher inequality: But still no growth"

4.Special Report - Rebalancing opportunities in Q2 07 April 2016 (6 pages/ 404 kb)
We analyze seven risk factors in the bond market and present our investment outlook in Q2.
(a) Liquidity outlook: In the near-term, we feel the risk of sharp RMB depreciation has dissipated, which will make the BoP condition more balanced and is positive to onshore RMB liquidity. However, the risk of Fed rate hike implies BoP balances may be volatile later this year, which requires the PBoC to maintain domestic liquidity buffer with greater flexibility. We expect the PBoC to rely on RRR cuts and medium to long term liquidity facility (and fiscal spending) to inject liquidity and we share the view of our Chief China Economist, Zhiwei Zhang on one RRR cut each quarter before the end of the year.
(b)Re-pricing risk of policy rate outlook: Concerns over rising inflation risk in Q2 may limit the room for the central bank to cut policy rates and the bond market will start pricing in diminishing expectation of further policy easing.
(c)Duration supply risk: We estimate the government/quasi-government bond market will need to absorb about RMB3.4-3.7trn of new bonds in Q2, up by 71%-87% from Q1.
(d)Regulatory concerns and bond market de-levering: The ongoing regulatory evaluation will keep the market nervous about any potential positioning reshuffling by highly levered investors which may trigger much broader and disorderly selling on cash bonds. On the other hand, to prevent a disorderly selloff, we believe the financial regulators will be prudent in managing bond market de-levering.
(e) Asset rotation out of fixed income market into equities: The relative valuation between equity and corporate credit is likely to shift towards asset allocation outflows from bonds into equities, but the pace of such reallocation flows is determined by equity market volatilities and activities in the IPO market.
(f) Credit differentiation amid credit events: The combination of rich valuation, relatively high exposure to leverage risk of the corporate credit market, and rising credit default risk suggests that credit market is due for a near term correction and we expect the flight to quality flows to offset partially supply risk on CGBs/policy bank bonds.
(g) Recovering in foreign investment interests: Foreigners in the interbank bond market reversed the selling trend from January-February this year and net purchased RMB29bn in March. We expect the stability in the RMB exchange rate and the relative risk/return profile against other sovereign bond investment continues to attract global reserve managers/asset allocators.
Investment strategy: We believe the balance of liquidity support, inflation expectation, supply risk, equity market re-valuation, regulatory concerns, credit risk and offshore investment flows is biased towards steepening on the CGB curve driven by selling at the long end. We expect the 10Y CGB range to widen to 2.8-3.2% and 10Y CDB range to widen to 3.2%-3.6% in Q2. We prefer to maintain our overweight position on RMB bonds but shorten our duration exposure to the 3-5Y bucket. We believe Q2 offers interesting rebalancing opportunities for asset allocators and we see a 20-30bps correction on the CGB curve as an attractive entry level. We are more cautious on credit exposure as we expect credit spread will widen (5Y AAA- rated by 30-40bps) in Q2, but weaker credits will continue to underperform along with rising credit default risk. We see another 30bps correction at the long end of the Repo IRS/NDIRS curve on the back of hedging demand for cash positions. Given the 7D repo rate is well-anchored, we would look to receive 5Y IRS/NDIRS at or above 2.9%. We expect the CNH CCS volatility to decline in Q2 as RMB exchange rate is likely to be stable and we forecast the range of 1Y CNH CCS rate to narrow from 2.5-6% to 2.5-5%.

2.US Daily Economic Notes - FOMC scorecard 06 April 2016 (1 page/ 235 kb)
JOSEPH LAVORGNA (DB's Chief US Economist) 
 
The most recent release of the Fed's dot plot last month indicated nine policymakers expected to hike interest rates only twice by yearend. This was meaningfully different from what Fed officials had estimated just three months earlier at the December 2015 FOMC meeting, when the four most dovish officials expected only two hikes, while the other 13 participants forecasted three or more hikes. Yet, as Fed Chair Yellen stated, the Committee's baseline expectations for economic activity, the labor market and inflation had not changed much since December.
 
 
The March dot plot indicates that the majority of policymakers now estimate that more monetary accommodation would now be necessary to achieve the desired levels of economic activity. This was made clear in the March meeting statement, which indicated that the FOMC continued to fret global economic and financial developments. However, since the March meeting, remarks from some Fed Presidents (Bullard, Lockhart, Harker, Lacker, Mester and Williams) have been more hawkish than the message Fed Chair Yellen conveyed at her March press conference, which she reiterated in her speech last Tuesday. In light of this, we have updated our FOMC scorecard to reflect our latest assessment of where various Fed officials lie on the monetary policy spectrum.
 
In the table below, we rank the various Fed voters on a scale from 1 to 5, with the former being the most dovish and the latter being the most hawkish—a rating of 3 is neutral. We assign Governors Brainard and Tarullo a ranking of 1, as prior to the December meeting they had advocated delaying liftoff given rapid dollar appreciation and concerns about the inflation outlook. Chicago Fed President Evans also qualifies as a 1 as he has stated his willingness to let inflation gather further momentum. We give Chair Yellen a rating of 2 and we believe her caution with respect to rate hikes is shared by New York Fed President Dudley, Boston's Rosengren, and Atlanta's Lockhart. We view Vice Chair Fischer, Governor Powell, San Francisco's Williams, Minneapolis' Kashkari and Dallas' Kaplan as centrists, thus rating them each 3. We believe Philadelphia's Harker, Cleveland's Mester and St. Louis' Bullard lean more hawkish, hence we rate them at 4. The most hawkish are Richmond's Lacker and Kansas City's George. The former ranks third all time in terms of dissenting votes on the FOMC while the latter dissented at the March meeting.
 
http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/3191-BCC5/32915944/DB_USEconDly_2016-04-06_0900b8c08afd632e.pdf
 
 
3.Fed Debated April Hike as Several Argue Caution, Minutes Show
By Craig Torres
(Bloomberg) -- Federal Reserve policy makers last month debated an April interest-rate hike, with several officials leaning against such a move because it would send the wrong signal and others saying it might be warranted.
“Several expressed the view that a cautious approach to raising rates would be prudent or noted their concern that raising the target range as soon as April would signal a sense of urgency they did not think appropriate,” minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee’s March 15-16 meeting released Wednesday in Washington said.
The debate, by flagging a potential April rate increase that’s nevertheless unlikely, may have the result of adding more focus to the June session. It also shows the FOMC is prepared to move in a meeting, if necessary, without a scheduled press conference by Fed Chair Janet Yellen.
 
U.S. central bankers, who left the benchmark interest rate unchanged in March in a range of 0.25 percent to 0.5 percent, discussed the relative health of the American economy, which contrasted against persistent global risks. They worried that slowing world growth could reduce corporate investment plans and restrain U.S. exports. Some officials argued that the U.S. was at or near full employment with inflation starting to rise.
“In contrast, some other participants indicated that an increase” in the federal funds rate target range at the April 26-27 meeting “might well be warranted” if economic data came in as expected, the minutes said.
The March meeting marked an evolution in the Fed’s policy approach as U.S. central bankers gave more weight to the impact of slowing growth abroad on their outlook.
Global Risks
“Many participants expressed a view that the global economic and financial situation still posed appreciable downside risks to the domestic economic outlook,” the minutes said. Data relevant to the Fed’s thinking “include not only domestic economic releases, but also information about developments abroad and changes in financial conditions.”
While Fed governors and regional-bank presidents revised their interest-rate forecasts to show two quarter-point increases this year instead of four, according to the median estimate, they changed their three-year projections for growth, unemployment and inflation only slightly.
Yellen explained in her press conference following the meeting that interest rates had to rise more slowly to offset the “somewhat softer pace” of economic expansion outside the U.S.
Many developed economies find themselves struggling with slow growth, too-low inflation and policy rates that are near, at or slightly below zero. While there has been no formal policy cooperation, the Fed and other central banks are collectively taking more steps to support expansion given the fragile global context.
Sustained Headwinds
“A number” of Fed officials determined that the headwinds restraining growth were likely to “subside only slowly,” the minutes said.
Fed officials met as financial markets were recovering from the depths of a selloff earlier in 2016 that rattled global leaders and boosted perceptions of recession risk in the U.S.
The unemployment rate, at 5 percent in March, is near the Fed’s definition of longer-run full employment, and some inflation indicators are starting to rise.
The personal consumption expenditures price index, minus food and energy, rose 1.7 percent for the year ending February. The FOMC targets inflation of 2 percent, including all items.
Yellen said in a March 29 speech in New York that she considered it appropriate for the committee to “proceed cautiously in adjusting policy” given the downside risks to the global outlook and the proximity of the zero boundary on interest rates.
The minutes echoed those remarks, noting the FOMC had room to raise rates if officials were surprised by the economy’s strength, while having less room to ease if growth softened.
“This asymmetry made it prudent to wait for additional information regarding the underlying strength of economic activity and prospects for inflation before taking another step to reduce policy accommodation,” the minutes said.
 
4.BRETT RYAN (Eco) : My main takeaways are these:
 
1. "Several members expressed concern that longer-run inflation expectations may have declined. Members agreed they would continue to monitor inflation developments closely."
 
- So keep a global inflation dashboard handy, not just core PCE that matters
 
2. "A number of participants judged that the headwinds restraining growth and holding down the neutral rate of interest were likely to subside only slowly." 
 
-Lower neutral rate means they can hike slower b/c the end point is lower
|
 
5.BTN关于minutes解读，重点在最后
Most FOMC members agreed it was wise not to raise rates in March. That settled, they then began to debate whether to raise rates in April. The fact they did strongly hint at an April hike on March 16
 
Here’s the key paragraph, emphasis added:
 
“Participants agreed that their ongoing assessments of the data and the implications for the outlook, rather than calendar dates, would determine the timing and pace of future adjustments to the stance of monetary policy. They expressed a range of views about the likelihood that incoming information would make an adjustment appropriate at the time of their next meeting. A number of participants judged that the headwinds restraining growth and holding down the neutral rate of interest were likely to subside only slowly. In light of this expectation and their assessment of the risks to the economic outlook, several expressed the view that a cautious approach to raising rates would be prudent or noted their concern that raising the target range as soon as April would signal a sense of urgency they did not think appropriate. In contrast, some other participants indicated that an increase in the target range at the Committee's next meeting might well be warranted if the incoming economic data remained consistent with their expectations for moderate growth in output, further strengthening of the labor market, and inflation rising to 2 percent over the medium term.”
 
In light of that final point, bear in mind the Atlanta Fed GDPNow estimate has fallen from 1.9% to 0.4%. 
 
The FOMC’s internationalist approach was in full display in the minutes. “Global” appears 22 times in the minutes; “international developments” appear twice; there are six mentions of foreign central banks (general and specific) and two mentions of China. Of course, international economic and financial contagion were major themes in the first quarter and many of these references are in the context of investor concerns. Nevertheless, some at the Fed are clearly losing sleep over about global economics. 
 
During the press conference, Yellen suggested there was a discussion of changing the formal balance-of-risks assessment from neutral to negative. There was a stalemate and the assessment was removed from the statement altogether. The minutes shed only a little more light on this discussion. The Fed staff noted the balance of risks for growth and inflation had tilted to the downside and—as a result—the balance of risks for unemployment had increased. Many participants thought international developments continued to pose appreciable downside risks. But others thought recent policy actions by foreign central banks mitigated these risks. 
 
Bottom line: Some FOMC members wanted to signal an April rate hike, but most thought their communication should stress data over calendar dependency. Besides, others thought April would be too soon based on their near-term forecasts. The decision to avoid hinting at an increased possibility of a hike at the next meeting suggests the doves dominated this discussion. Still, the failure to downgrade the balance of risks suggest it was not a complete rout. The hawks still have influence.

One of the themes that has been building since February is how the market is pricing complete policy failure out of Japan . We have taken this theme very seriously and back in February revised our USDJPY forecast down to 105 by mid-year. Other markers of "policy failure" beyond USDJPY:
-super long-dated JGB yields are back close to their all time lows 
-the huge Nikkei underperformance

4.US Daily Economic Notes - Still tracking soft Q1 05 April 2016 (1 page/ 246 kb)
Commentary for Wednesday: We continue to estimate Q1 real GDP growth of 0.5% and only gradual improvement thereafter: Our growth projections for Q2, Q3 and Q4 are 1.0%, 1.2% and 2.4%, respectively. This would result in the weakest annual growth rate of the US economy since 2012, when concerns about a Greek exit from the Eurozone and uncertainty regarding the US Presidential Election weighed on the business cycle. We learned yesterday that the February international trade deficit widened further (-$47.1 billion vs.-$45.9 billion previously) because of a larger increase in imports than in exports. For Q1, we anticipate net exports will subtract around 80 basis points from real GDP growth. To be sure, the Fed's broad trade-weighted dollar is down a sharp 6% from its January 2016 high, which will mitigate the overall impact of previous dollar appreciation in the longer term. However, given the lag with which changes in the currency impact net exports, we continue to expect the external sector to drag on real GDP growth over the next couple of quarters. In the chart below, we show the annual changes in the dollar compared to net exports' contribution to real GDP growth. 
If the dollar were to continue to weaken, this positive impact on the external sector would more likely be felt in 2017 rather than 2016. For the dovish Yellen led-Fed, this means monetary policymakers will proceed very cautiously with respect to the pace of policy normalization. For this reason, we expect the Fed to remain on hold through most of this year despite relatively robust labor data. For example, we learned yesterday that the quits (2.1% vs. 2.0% previously) and hiring (3.8% vs. 3.6%) rates improved in February. In the past, a rising quits rate has generally been associated with increasing wage pressures. At present, though, there is still little evidence of a sustained upshift in the latter. 
The only item on today's data docket is the minutes of the March 15-16 FOMC meeting. Normally, meeting minutes are eagerly anticipated by the financial markets, but given Yellen's dovish comments last week, the minutes take on less significance. Note that Yellen participates on an economic panel with former Fed Chairs Bernanke, Greenspan and Volcker tomorrow evening in New York City. We doubt that Yellen will break any new ground given the nature of the event, and the fact that she reiterated in her speech last week many of the near-term concerns she outlined at her March post-meeting press conference. For this reason, investors will also likely downplay any further hawkish rhetoric from the trio of Fed Presidents scheduled to speak today. Given our own near-term forecast, we believe the Fed Chair's caution is warranted. 
 
5.Special Report - Currency politics – What’s next 05 April 2016 (3 pages/ 253 kb)-BOJ会忍不住出手吗？
Can policymakers clutch defeat from the jaws of a currency 'truce' victory?  Of course they can, after all some currency objectives are contradictory.
The most obvious contradiction now at play, is how to square a slightly weaker USD versus EM not turning into too much USD weakness versus the EUR and JPY. 
For Japan, as JPY relative strength reinforces Nikkei weakness, this currency 'peace' already feels like a new front in the old currency war.  CNY/JPY is a much ignored cross returning to its old 20yr range, and China's 'gain' could not come without Japan 'pain'!   
Collectively, if policy could kill FX vol for awhile, it would suit G20's cause.   A USD that is neither too hot nor too cold, near current levels versus all of the Rmb, EUR, JPY works well.  
That does not mean that markets will deliver what officials want, or, policymakers will do much more to squash vol.  
Allowing the BoJ and ECB to make their FX preferences known would complicate future G20 currency politics, but the pragmatic approach would be for all major players to help the common cause and talk up stability.

3.US Equity Insights - After all that to flat: What happened and now what? - Top 5 questions
01 April 2016 (28 pages/ 1931 kb) 
Download the complete report: http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/3428-658C/40421871/0900b8c08af6dbac.pdf  
S&P flat after rocky 1Q, but EPS outlook lower than before and also for yields 
In early Dec 2015, $125 was our 2016E S&P EPS and $135 for 2017. Now we expect $118-121 in 2016 and $130 in 2017. This is mainly because we lowered our  oil price ests from $55/65 to $35/60 and lowered our Financial EPS on less Fed hikes, higher credit costs and soft markets. Energy/ Materials & Financials EPS remain the most uncertain of all sectors. Yet our EPS for Tech, Health Care and both Consumer sectors  have been stable. Industrials EPS stable too, but higher at Transports and trimmed at Capital Goods. We cut our S&P target from 2250 to 2200 in Jan on our lower EPS, but persistently low bond yields should drive the S&P PE ex. Energy & Financials above 18  from 17 today. 
Next hike timing is less important than where and when the FF rate plateaus 
The talk of the week is Yellen’s dovish speech and the view of many that only 1 hike is likely this year and thus a weaker dollar even if jobs stay strong.  But to our ear, Yellen was balanced and no more than her usual dovish self and we think June is still in play, but with a third hike not until December. We perked up at her greater acceptance, "and that of other FOMC members," that a much lower neutral Fed  Funds rate than history is likely, "not much above 0% in real terms." We share this view, but appreciate the many uncertainties in estimating new normal interest rates and thought this a strong statement from the Chair, giving more color behind the lowered  dots beyond risks to growth. This suggests the Fed doesn’t have a war to wage with the long-term bond market. If 10yr Tsy yields stays under 3% for the rest of this cycle with inflation expectations near 2%, then long-term real interest rate will stay under  1%. Currently, 10yr TIPS yield is ~20bp, a low for recent years. This would support a 5.0% real cost of equity for the overall S&P 500 or 20 S&P PE, certainly ex. Energy & Financials, versus our standing 5.5% real cost of equity estimate. 
Still prefer Growth over Value: Will Health Care stay 15x if S&P ex. E&F is 18+ 
Energy & Financials dominate Value and Tech & Health Care dominate Growth. We still prefer Growth owing to less 2017E EPS risk, especially if stable dollar,  and Tech & HC has more PE upside on low long-term interest rates. Valuation is always an important consideration in our sector or style preference, thus we prefer Health Care and Tech stocks with easier to reason PEs. Within Value, we prefer Banks given undemanding  valuations and we remain very cautious on Energy given valuations that suggest oil prices average $65-70/bbl in 2017. 
The five most frequently asked questions of us lately by investors: 
1) What is S&P EPS sensitivity to dollar, esp. Euro & GBP? Every 10% DXY rise lowers S&P EPS by 2.5% or $3. Every dime the Euro falls is $1 off S&P EPS.  S&P direct exposure to GBP is small, but risk is a Euro/DXY sympathy selloff. 
2) What is S&P EPS sensitivity to oil prices? Every $5 higher oil price increases S&P net income by roughly $7.5bn or S&P EPS by $1. This is the net effect. 
3) How much of S&P EPS growth comes from buybacks? Buybacks have boosted S&P EPS growth at a fairly consistent ~1.5% for the past four years. 
4) Are S&P margins deteriorating? Is margin compression a leading signal of recession? Some margin compression is typical during profit recessions. Survival  of profit recessions led to long cycles in the past. Normally S&P margins do not fall sharply until recessions, whereas NIPA profit margins peak in the middle of the cycle. S&P net margins differ from NIPA share of GDP. 
5) Is the S&P overly leveraged? Net debt to mkt cap (or EBITDA) of S&P ex Financials, Energy & Materials is still very low compared to history. 
4.US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 01 April 2016 (1 page/ 217 kb)
Commentary for Monday: There are several economic indicators released this week that will have some bearing on the near-term economic outlook. Monday brings the February factory orders report（同是db的salve认为pmi太好了使得这个数据不太重要了）. The headline figure (-2.0% forecast vs. +1.4% previously) is expected to be soft because of the already-reported     -2.8% decline in durable goods orders. Factory orders are nearly evenly split between durable and nondurable goods orders. Durables, which have a shelf life of more the three years, were dampened by a nearly -28% decline in aircraft orders, which are notoriously volatile. Nondurable orders, which capture perishable items, are expected to rise modestly because of some improvement in petroleum-related orders. But what matter most in the factory orders report are the data on inventories.
Factory inventories account for 35% of total inventories—the rest is composed of wholesale (32%) and retail (33%) inventories. (Note that data on February wholesale inventories (-0.2% vs. +0.2%) are released on Friday.) The economy-wide inventory-to-sales ratio edged up to 1.41 in January, which was the highest reading since the recession (1.42 in May 2009). We expect inventory investment to sharply slow as producers realign stockpiles with underlying demand, because this is typically what has happened in the past. As an aside, demand appears to be soft, as evidenced by the decline in February sales and the -0.9% decrease in durable goods shipments. Our best guess is that factory inventories will fall for the eighth consecutive month. The implication should be a very weak reading on Q1 real GDP growth—we have been projecting a gain of just 0.5% since early February.
On Tuesday, the February international trade balance (-$46.0 billion vs. -$45.7 billion) is expected to show slight widening based on the reported deterioration in the advance goods trade deficit. For the quarter, we are assuming that there was a substantial drag on output from deterioration in net exports—we estimate it was around 100 basis points. Later that morning, we get the non-manufacturing ISM survey (52.0 vs. 53.4), which is projected to moderate somewhat, consistent with the past deterioration in the manufacturing ISM survey. We also get the February Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) on Tuesday. This is a favorite report of Fed Chair Yellen's, so market participants will take note of its results. The two most important series within the report, the hiring rate and the quits rate, declined in January after reaching cyclical highs in December 2015. The Fed will be looking for them to rebound in February, consistent with that month's relatively strong employment report.
Wednesday afternoon brings the minutes of the March 15-16 FOMC meeting. We expect the transcript to be more evenhanded than the very recent dovish remarks made by Yellen, because we have also heard relatively hawkish comments from various Fed Presidents (Bullard, Harker, Lacker, Lockhart and Williams). In light of what Yellen said, the FOMC minutes probably take on less importance than they usually do. Regarding Yellen, she participates on an economic panel with former Chairs Bernanke, Greenspan and Volcker on Thursday evening in New York City. We doubt that Yellen will shed any new light on the economic outlook given that the nature of the event, a gathering with former Fed Chairs, does not lend itself to a near-term digression on the economic and financial outlook. We also get the February consumer credit report ($15.0 billion vs. $10.5 billion) on Thursday afternoon, but this series is a lagging economic indicator.
 
5.Alpha Alert:  Nikkei/S&P consistent with heavy USD/JPY and vice versa
 
Until very recently, USD/JPY was pretty much ‘the same’ line as the S&P500/Nikkei ratio.  In the past year, the coincident correlation is a stunning 0.91, slightly higher than the 0.87 for the Nikkei alone. The S&P500/Nikkei peak correlation lags USD/JPY by a day, probably in part because the Nikkei is shut when the USD/JPY first responds to the S&P.
 
Figure 1:  USD/JPY (lhs) vs. S&P/Nikkei (rhs)
[cid:image003.png@01D18E60.AFEEC340]
Source: Deutsche Bank, Bloomberg Financial L.P
 
In any event, the interesting signals from recent events are:
 
i)  given where USD/JPY is trading, the Nikkei should be meaningfully stronger relative to the S&P.  Fiscal year-end distortions could be a factor, as could concerns on policy inertia, as the BOJ and Abe government contemplate next monetary and fiscal policy steps respectively.
 
ii)  that USD/JPY is not lower may indeed reflect the large scale Japan portfolio outflows seen in Figure 2.   It is not unusual for USD/JPY to follow hedging and s/t capital flows rather than l/t portfolio flows.  Nonetheless there is some concern that if the yen can’t appreciate with strong L/T capital outflows, there is a more fundamental issue related to Current Account surplus recycling that will play yen positive in the future.
 
Figure 2:  Recent weekly Japan Capital Flows
[cid:image005.jpg@01D18E60.AFEEC340]
 
iii) if the Nikkei can’t recover relative to the S&P soon, there will be some presumption that this will add to downward pressure on USD/JPY, even if the fundamental rationale for a weaker relative Nikkei, driving a stronger yen is less well established than the currency driving equities.
 
iv) another signal arguing against buying USD/JPY dips is that March 2016 was the first March  since the Great Financial Crisis where USD/JPY went down.  Seasonals in April have been far less negative for the Yen.  The seasonals for the Nikkei in April are Ok, but not relative to the S&P (see Figure 4), where March and April  are v.good months for the S&P over the past decade ( Figure 5)

2.US Daily Economic Notes - Be wary of the wisdom of the crowd when it comes to March employment ——群体理智还是不理智？今天的有点儿小题大做31 March 2016 (1 page/ 232 kb)
Commentary for Friday: Despite a trend-like reading on March ADP employment (200k vs. 205k), which was released earlier in the week, we expect a below-consensus increase in March nonfarm payrolls. In turn, this could result in a slight uptick in the unemployment rate. Our forecast of below-trend employment is broadly consistent with our meager projection of 0.5% Q1 real GDP growth. Tepid output alongside strong job growth has resulted in unsustainably weak productivity, and the likely outcome is an eventual slowdown in labor market gains. _没看懂
Another reason we are less sanguine on March employment is that we have noticed a recent tendency for the median consensus forecast for March to overestimate the initially-reported March payroll gain. In fact, the median forecast for March has over-predicted the initial nonfarm payroll figure in five out of the last six years. The range of misses has been large. For example, last year, analysts were expecting a 248k hiring gain in March, and the initial print was 126k. This was the largest miss during the aforementioned period. Forecasters also overestimated the initial March payroll figure by 3k in 2014, 97k in 2013, 90k in 2012 and 38k in 2010. Only in 2011 did the initial March payroll gain exceed the median consensus estimate, and this was by a modest 31k. Thus, over the past six years, forecasters have overestimated the initial March employment gain by an average of 53k. 
To be sure, average hourly earnings (AHEs) and hours worked are equally important for income growth. Regarding the former, last month's decline in AHEs was unusual, and there is potential for payback in March. However, it would take slightly more than a 0.2% gain in AHEs to keep the year-over-year growth rate steady at 2.2%, which would still be well below the 2.6% post-recession peak, reached last December. With the unemployment rate near most estimates of full employment, excess slack in the labor market has largely been absorbed at this point in the cycle. Year-over-year nonfarm payroll growth peaked at 2.3% in February 2015 and has declined to 1.9% as of this February. Thus, wage inflation will be needed to support income growth. 
 
 
3.FX Daily - Trading Payrolls After the Yellen speech largely ruled out an April hike, there is an asymmetric bias toward risk positive, USD negative data.  
耶伦讲话排除了4月加息可能，对于风险资产利好，美元利空的走势就有了不对称倾向。
However, the market is struggling for asset classes where there is 'decent value' to express a risk positive view.  Commodities and related high yield are still global growth dependent, and equities are seen as rich and are becoming less responsive to Central Bank policy. 
但是，市场还是青睐那些深度价值的资产门类来诠释风险偏好。大宗及相关hy还是全球增长所依赖，还有股票已经被看做很贵了，就对cb政策没啥反应。
In contrast, EM and EM FX in particular are seen having pockets of value.  As an example, the ZAR and MXN as more liquid EM currencies, have close to 3% upside versus the USD before coming up against even more serious USD support.   
相反，em和em fx被视作好产品。例如，zar和mxn这样较好流动性的em货币，在遇到下一个像样地usd支撑位之前，已经上涨了3%。
G10 higher yielders (Aussie and Kiwi) are much less attractive and are setting themselves up for better medium-term AUD/USD and NZD/USD sell levels.   
G10高收益货币（aussie 和kiwi新元）很没有啥吸引力，自己把自己设为中期对美元的抛售水平
On the EUR 1.15 is widely seen as the top of the range that is not expected to be extended.  Whether EUR officials talk the EUR down near there will say something about how overt a (Shanghai/Plaza-lite) agreement there is, that USD strength should be discouraged. 
欧元1.15水平被广泛认为是上限。不管欧盟官员讲话与否，接近这个位置就会有声音说那个协议的事儿，同样美元走强也是有限
That the market only has one 25bp rate hike priced in for June 2017 looks far too low even with a consensus NFP number, and is one indication that Fed expectations have plenty of scope to help the USD find a base (DXY ~ 93) on a multi-week/month basis.
Of course beware: much of the immediate response comes in the 5mins after release, but in this instance, the market is apt to more easily run with softer than expected data rather than an upside surprise. 
市场只是为2017年6月之前定价了一次加息，目前看来太低了，即便是nfp仅仅符合预期，揭示了市场预期fed会使得dxy维持低位在数周/月的水平。当然，要记住， 所有这些反应都将在数据公布后的5分钟内完成，但是在这种情况下，市场对于逊于预期数据较好于预期数据更加易于反应。——又没有看懂。因为市场定价已经很低，逊于预期的数据会导致迅速更低吗？看原文，意思是只有很很强于预期，才有可能4月加息，外汇市场才会有所动作
 
 
4.7 things to know before the New York Open / earlier——纽约盘前七件事
 
1) Market Wrap: EUR buying the standout
2) Robin Winkler: Impact of fiscal year-end on JPY?
3) FX Daily: Where next for AUD and NZD?
4) DBFX Vol Report - Implieds looking cheap?
5) Spring NYC Macro Client Dinner Impressions
6) US Daily Economic Notes - Factory sector remains fragile
7) Day ahead
 
 
1)      Market Wrap: EUR buying the standout : Light flows in a relatively calm session in London – the most notable release data wise has been UK GDP which was stronger than expected, with Q4 upwardly revised to 0.6% from 0.5%.  Oliver Harvey thinks this will be moderately heartening for the BoE in that suggests economy may be slowing less than previously thought and more in line with their goal of plus 2% growth.  However, another large month of gilt outflows in Feb underscores how the flow picture has turned negative for GBP, representing a worrying combination both on its own and particularly heading into the UK referendum. Flow wise in FX, our London Desk notes the standout has been in EUR$ where they have been good buyers for corporate and macro names as spot continues to march higher.  $Asia flow continues to be consistently LHS from a mixture of names, particularly versus IDR and KRW, whilst elsewhere our NDF desk note locals have been very aggressively bidding $INR on the session as the pair holds up relatively better versus the Asia complex.
 
 
 
2)    Robin Winkler: Impact of fiscal year-end on JPY? : Ahead of Japan’s fiscal year-end, Robin Winkler notes it will be interesting to see how investors recycle large mark-to-market gains from their JGB holdings. The odds are for a large-scale sell-off, as suggested by JGB price action overnight. Importantly in this context, the weekly transaction data for last week already show the largest net capital outflows on record - net bond outflows alone recorded the largest volume since January 2005!  No doubt a large proportion of Japanese outflows are hedged and foreigners unwind hedges are they repatriate funds, but overall Robin notes the flow picture goes to show that it’s still too early to write off the BoJ’s NIRP as a failure.-nirp效果有待观察，尽管日本资金外流严重
 
 
3)    FX Daily: Where next for AUD and NZD?:  In our FX Daily, Robin Winkler reassesses our bearish Antipodean FX views – the accommodative stance from the Fed has seen us close our Blueprint short AUD and NZD trades and revise up our forecasts 8 cents each to 0.68 and 0.63. Medium term we do remain bearish as we 1) foresee an eventual turn in carry trade conditions as either China risks return or the Fed resumes tightening, 2) commodity prices (iron ore in particular) should turn when the impact of Chinese credit expansion in H1 eases while dairy prices remain low, and 3) valuations remain rich. Click here<http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/3029-459E/13043158/DB_FXDaily_2016-03-31_0900b8c08af6a30f.pdf> for the full report from Strategy.
 
 
 
4)    DBFX Vol Report - Implieds looking cheap?: My colleague Tejas Sathian makes some interesting observations as FX vols take a small leg lower with the CVIX at 9.35%. Realized tells an interesting story and implieds are now starting to look cheap on a historical lookback (1m implied is below HF realized across most of G10), but the trend lower in shorter dated realized provides reason for caution as 1w has moved steadily lower. Yesterday’s USD negative moves took a bit of time to settle and once they did gamma compressed alongside – yesterday ended up being an 8% realized day in the CVIX (compared to 10.75% on the Yellen day). Generally there’s been very little pushback to the thesis that Yellen’s message means a sustained low period of volatility. That said there are definitely believers in eventual USD strength – given how far back Fed expectations have scaled; and we’ve seen interest to earn some decay against existing USD longs. Interesting that we haven’t seen the overwhelming rush to leveraged short vol trades yet – with risk premiums at these low levels perhaps there’s a bit of hesitation to chase vols lower. And while engagement feels low, the overall volume trackers aren’t quite as anemic as some would guess – SDR shows option volumes over the last two days as not far from the average daily volume over the last 3 months, and today sees a normal pace with JPY leading the way.
 
 
 
5)    Spring NYC Macro Client Dinner Impressions:  DB’s Ozan Tarman makes interesting observations on client sentiment at our NY Macro Dinner hosted last night -  there was clearly frustration around the table and it felt like in the short term, as the risk on trade runs away from them, investors can’t afford not to chase although most remained cautious on the risk recovery in the medium term. While it was difficult to find a ‘consensus’ on the table, the path of least resistance seemed for most to be ‘sucked’ into Risk trades. Most China bears, didn’t expect the problems to re - appear right away and felt like Central Banks have moved away from ‘currency wars’. Emerging Markets rightfully got a mention as well and for the first time in a while, Ozan notes that there were more short term EM bulls than bears on that table. Not unanimous, mind you. Please let me know if you would like the detailed read of the NYC Macro Dinner notes from Ozan.
 
 
 
6)    US Daily Economic Notes - Factory sector remains fragile: We expect this morning’s Chicago PMI report and tomorrow’s manufacturing ISM release (50.0 vs forecast 49.5 previously) to improve modestly given the recent rebound in several regional PMI series. Further we note that weakness in the manufacturing sector is already depressing capital spending in the current quarter. The February level of core durable goods orders is down -5.6% annualized compared to its Q4 average. This leaves the consumer as the sole driver of GDP growth in the near term. As we learned this past Monday, consumer spending was revised down meaningfully in January. Click here<http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/cgi-bin/pull/DocPull/7819-F8E5/28957859/DB_USEconDly_2016-03-30_0900b8c08af5bd69.pdf> for the full report from LaVorgna and team.
 
 
 
7)    Day ahead: In the US today, we receive Chicago PMI, weekly initial jobless claims & the Chicago Fed's Evans is scheduled to be interviewed by Bloomberg Radio. In Canada, we get the GDP print.
