2.US Daily Economic Notes - Factory sector remains fragile 30 March 2016 (1 page/ 244 kb)
Commentary for Thursday: We expect this morning's Chicago PMI report and tomorrow's manufacturing ISM release (50.0 forecast vs. 49.5 previously) to improve modestly given the recent rebound in several regional PMI series. In March, the Philadelphia Fed index rose 15.2 points to 12.4, which snapped a six-month streak of negative readings. Similarly, the New York Fed Empire and the Richmond Fed manufacturing surveys improved 17.3 and 26.0 points, respectively, in the month. In the case of the latter, this was the largest one-month improvement on record. In turn, it appears that the manufacturing sector may be stabilizing, at least for now. However, we remain concerned that elevated inventory levels and ongoing weakness in exports may limit the extent of improvement in these series near term. While manufacturing accounts for only around 10% of total output and employment, it is highly cyclical and tends to be a leading indicator of economic activity. This is a key reason why we have been expecting sub-1.0% H1 growth for some time. 
As the chart below illustrates, the headline manufacturing ISM survey is highly correlated with the annual growth rate of real GDP. The former leads the latter by one quarter. Even assuming a modest improvement in the March ISM, the Q1 average would nonetheless remain below 50. A simple linear regression of the year-over-year change in real GDP on the manufacturing ISM points to annual growth of barely 1% in H1. In terms of the quarter-over-quarter change in real GDP, we expect just 0.5% growth in Q1 and 1.0% in Q2. This is largely due to an anticipated draw down in inventories, which, in turn, could cap any potential near-term improvement in the factory sector. 
In fact, this is what the recent trend in the ISM inventory subcomponent implies. This series is highly correlated with the change in inventories in the GDP accounts and has been pointing to a significant pullback in economy-wide stockpiling for the past couple of quarters. Recall that in Q4, the change in real private inventories only declined by $7.2 billion to $78.3 billion. This has resulted in a significantly-elevated inventory to sales ratio, which as of January stood at 1.4—the highest level since May 2009 (1.42). 
Weakness in the manufacturing sector is already depressing capital spending in the current quarter. The February level of core durable goods orders is down -5.6% annualized compared to its Q4 average. This leaves the consumer as the sole driver of GDP growth in the near term. As we learned this past Monday, consumer spending was revised down meaningfully in January. 
 
 
3.Spring NYC Macro Client Dinner Impressions:
"Will you ever make money?" is the pressure my clients/friends face. Short term, as Risk on trades run away from them, they can't afford not to chase. Medium term, that's why we may sleep walk into an accident!New York City, my city. Never a "dull, shy" dinner. And this would NOT be the first one. After all the jokes on what I had told Frau Number 2 to make her laugh like that yesterday at lunch, we got right into the core of it.Not only the bus is not crowded(满了赶紧跑). In the words of Brad (our head of US Equity trading), "my bus doesn't even have a driver. It's like that Keanu Reeves（基努里维斯） movie!" .. So what exactly is short term and medium term? And what are the risks the table is worried about?I had the sincere pleasure of hosting 23 clients/friends from the Big Apple: EM, Equities, Rates, FX and Credit all represented. Some hedge fund "titans" and "very deep pocket" Real Money players.On "stage," I had Torsten "do you guys still fear recession" Slok; Alan "is the long USD trade really dead" Ruskin and all my partners who run product in US: Xuxu Mendes for Lat Am, Carrion for FX, Pariente for swaps and Kurtzman for equity. Our head of US debt sales Gallo and co-head of US equity sales O'Brien were also there!So let's dive right into it.First of all, just like trading is very very difficult in this environment, these dinners are also getting more tricky to get that infamous "pain trade." Clearly, majority of the players are hurt. On that table and outside. Clearly, it is very in vogue to say "what I have conviction is to have very low conviction" (John Carrion). But that doesn't make it easier to choose what trades to lean against.That being said, path of least resistance seemed for that table to be "sucked" into Risk trades. Even though we are at much richer valuation levels than, say, Feb 11th. Many are desperate to make that money!I questioned Brad over NFP and equities: "Low NFP and we will get even more comfortable about Yellen's choice. High NFP and we may shake a bit. And that would be temporary."That actually made one of my (rates) clients interrupt right away: "But listen to what he's saying. （Brad注明鹰派，上周改口为鸽派）So is either wing good for the equities? We would have said just the opposite just 2 months ago!"Correct.. But it seemed we were worried much more about China two months ago. This is New York after all. So my last week's London dinner "China data short term optimism" wasn't exactly shared. There was a clear divergence of opinions. In fact, two big players had a nice little ping pong over how soon "the China credit/capital outflows" headache could resume!But I would still say even most of the (China) bears didn't expect the problems to re-appear right away. Whether you believe in a "Shanghai, Plaza II accord". (Ruskin idea!) or not, big Central Banks had shied away from "currency wars." Yellen had got the message. She had a "detente" with her dovish tilt, helping （？！I doubt）China. And they wouldn't hurt this balance yet. Only one player at the table voiced that China could bring global macro down as soon as end of April.So what else could create "sell in May and go away" yet again? Before I could say it, one big Credit client dropped "April 17th" onto the table. If oil fell very abruptly back down to "25, 30s," could that spoil the party?I actually think it could and would. But there wasn't that much buy in from that table. I think it is a short term risk we should be more cognizant of!One risk the group cared more about was inflation, to be even more specific: wage pressures! Of course I teased my Torsten Slok about what he thought about the "backhand Yellen gave to all the hawks of last week." He pretty much admitted that it was a backhand, albeit smilingly! One thing Slok thinks could wake up all this was "if wage inflation creeps higher and higher." In that, he seems to care more about AHE than necessarily the payroll number itself for Friday.Olivier highlighted that "perma bears on rates are moving from front ends to long ends. Steepeners are put on. If risk on continues, there may be back up on long end yields."For both US and Europe, they got backing/echo from 2 clients. But some in the table certainly pushed back as well: "what if we even had some inflation.. Does she really care? She just hinted you that her reaction function changed!"Pariente still thinks "pain trade is still if TY goes to 1.50% before 2.10%.. All this comeback on Risk since Feb 11th, and core yields go tighter! So many would capitulate further if yields collapse more."I have to quote a client/friend from the dinner here: ".. if you told that table in December that Eco data would be what it was for q1, Fed would be easy, USD would decline, China would get it, oil would bounce etc. and they had a chance to buy SPX only 1% higher ytd they would have jumped for it. Now they can't stomach it! Amazing how quickly the narrative can change."Talking about narrative change, EM .. EM.. EM.. For the first time in a NYC dinner in a loooong time, there were more short term EM bulls than bears on that table. Not unanimous, mind you. When our Luis Mendes said, "there's a new music in the room.. Yellen changed the tune and she's the Boss. I believe in my asset class. And Real Money certainly are not overweight," he got some push back from big Real Money EM investors: "SWFs are hurt. They are looking at this rally as an opportunity to sell!"But those voices are in minority. Especially if the NFP is an in line to mediocre number, majority on that table wanted to buy EM long end local duration and/or hard currency credit. Just like the case in London, some big Brazilian PMs believe in their country's rate and equity rally for the next few months.. "Do we sell the fact after the impeachment etc? Perhaps. But at the moment, you ride it."Xuxu also wants Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay national football teams to be merged so that they can dominate the World Cups."Will the banks ever work again?," one credit investor quipped. Just like a big hedge fund player "complained" about some of their investors calling the sector "idiots," buy side have doubts about profitability of sell side models!I brought up the issue of European bank results to come?! Can that sour the mood right before May? One lady certainly thought so. Slok thought Draghi had taken the right steps to buy us time.. At least on the CDS/fixed income front. Watch this space. There seemed to be some still waiting to short Estoxx further. There are still believers in Euro breakeves and/or Periphery debt trade. But not much in European equities per se!Credit specialists also warned about US HY when we went around the table at the end. Right around April 17th "oil" meeting, a few wanted to short HY again!Our head FX spot trader John also thinks Euro pain trade is more 1.16 rather than 1.11 here.. He also reckons JPY may strengthen towards 108. But he said the majority in his asset class has been absolutely burnt (twice!) from predicting/wishing (!) that Yellen would be "hawkish!"Japan? I drilled and drilled.. Talked about what a "forgotten trade" it was.. It wasn't even mentioned once when we around the table for "themes" at the beginning! Only one player brought up towards the end that there could be something to Abe's fiscal stimulus attempts in April & that he wanted to be long Nikkei.Absolute majority believes Japan is a bit in "no one's land.. No real buyer" etc. Hardly anybody believes in the infamous third arrow. If you believe there's good upside to Nikkei in the next month or so, you may be either on to something or you may be very, very alone!Brexit? Americans cared about it more than I thought they would. Some mentioned being short GBP as a "good value" trade still. But for them, this would be more of a "is Europe in big trouble trade" than systemic risk UK trade on its own.. Understandably, my London table was a lot more obsessed the day after Brussels tragedy.. NYC has China, oil and still Yellen timing on their mind much before Brexit.Both Ruskin and Pariente believe Frau Number 2 can go for a July hike after Brexit uncertainty is over. Olivier likes paying the July ois.. Table did consider it quite a real possibility, actually!So will I be able to hold this dinner again in December or will I be "banned" (tongue-in-cheek-comment-alert!) from entering the country as a Muslim? ;) That brings us to Trump. A big equity player was asked if "Donald was priced in."Table seems to believe it's still Hillary's to lose. That the polls looked favorable to her. So if Trump narrows the gap, some key players believe "equities can get nervous later in year." Some also do believe Republican "establishment" can indeed try to stop Trump at the Convention. I personally believe those tactics/engineerings will backfire.Brad likes selling short end VIX volatility and buying August equity vol against it.Long gold? One rare macro theme many caught. Vulnerable? Ruskin was a bit worried that it didn't trade all too well despite a very dovish Yellen lately.In conclusion, even though there were indeed variety of opinions around the table New Yorker style, it was in majority"I am under pressure to make money .. Fast and soon.""USD may have peaked.""There's not even a driver in my asset class's bus. Nobody has it on despite this rally""EM may be the place to be in short term. We will all get sucked in""But medium term, I am still afraid your sinister things can happen"Kind of dinner.Trigger for more sinister things?China Credit worries win.. Oil is a short term second. Inflation was voiced a lot, but my God, players are burnt from that wish. And Brexit is valid, but another month's issue.If core rates sell off suddenly, very very few seem prepared for it.If Nikkei is a big winner in next few months, that table will be shocked.If China/Oil (and relatedly EM) collapses sooner than expected, many would say "I knew it.. And despite that I got pushed into an accident."Time to fly back home.It was a superb two days again in the Electric City.. Macro Clients/Friends dinner is a permanent brand and highlight, but my main take away will be this:Even if you tell (arguably) the most powerful woman on Earth that she is "Frau Number 2," she will immediately giggle, but also ask:"Who's your Number 1, then?!";)So until the next one, thank you my NYC and Good night.

2.US Daily Economic Notes - Tame wage pressures may cap core inflation 29 March 2016 (1 page/ 249 kb)
Commentary for Wednesday: Core inflation has risen moderately from its cyclical low. The annual growth rate of the core PCE deflator, the Fed's preferred inflation metric, bottomed out at slightly below 1.0% in October 2010. As of the latest data for February, core PCE inflation is up 1.7% compared to a year ago, modestly below the Fed's 2% target. However, we believe that the recent pickup in core inflation is temporary because it has not occurred alongside any noticeable increase in wage pressures. Average hourly earnings, the employment cost index and worker compensation have all been trending sideways. Other survey-based price measures tell a similar story. Case in point, the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) Survey data indicate very little in the way of any wage or price pressures. We care about the NFIB small business survey because it can provide us with an early read on the direction of the economy and the trends in both wages and prices. At present, the economy remains weak, and there is little evidence to support higher wage growth and inflation. The headline index of small business optimism was 92.9 last month, which was a 24-month low. In addition, the percentage of firms expecting the economy to improve remained at its lowest reading since November 2013. This was corroborated by declines in the percentage of firms expecting higher sales as well as the percentage of firms planning capital expenditures in the near term: Each series remains well below its cyclical peak. None of these data suggest the economy's growth rate is on the cusp of turning meaningfully higher. Moreover, there is no evidence of any wage or price pressures within the NFIB. 
As shown in the chart below, the percentage of firms planning to raise worker compensation has retraced last year's increase. After rising steadily starting last September to a post-recession high of 21% last December, the series has plunged nine points in the first two months of this year to just 12%. This is where it was last August and is right in line with its trailing four-year average. This is important because small businesses (1-49 employees) account for 42% of total employment according to the ADP survey. The story is similar for price inflation. There are two NFIB price series: One measures the percentage of firms raising average selling prices, and the other measures the percentage of firms planning to raise prices. Both series fell last month—the former remained at its lowest reading since October 2010 while the latter fell two points to 14%, which is where it was last September. Given the aforementioned fragile growth backdrop—inflation-adjusted consumer spending is currently tracking up only around 1.7% annualized in Q1—we question whether the recent firming in the core PCE deflator will prove sustainable. 
 
 
3.SAMEER GOEL : YELLEN & ASIA. 
"Proceed cautiously" she said. "Asymmetric" ability for conventional monetary policy, she said. Wish she would have spoken with her team a bit more on this. June is down to 28%, 24bp priced into 2016 all together. 
 
For Asia,
 
1. Strong tailwinds going into April, which has seasonally been the best month for Asia post GFC (both FX and duration), with equity & debt flows at their strongest. To be sure, valuations & central bank bids will caution against chasing the move lower in $Asia too aggressively (IDR & THB are two pairs which are significantly off post FOMC lows). But real money should still have cash to deploy. Watch for new inflows into EM, though suspect more into hard currency.
 
2. The China sweet spot keeps getting extended. Likely that PBoC will let $CNY fix follow the big $ move lower directionally, but by a smaller beta, such as to weaken versus the TWI. Wonder how far we are from the point where PBoC feels confident enough to start scaling back on its intervention/controls.
 
3. With the Fed out of the way for the next couple of months (unless payrolls change the tune again), and the global macro possibly coming off the boil, local stories will get more airplay. Look at the cheat sheet we sent out earlier this week.
4.DOMINIC KONSTAM : headlines looking pretty dovish -- shdnt have been a surprise after the fomc but the fed speak in the interim was a bit confusing -- plays top view that u r better off ignoring the presidents.. how much they like to speak is inversely correlated to their importance because precisely no one is listening to them in DC. shd support breakevens and driver reals back to zero in 10s... while fed relent means a break on how low long rates can go (becos less risk of policy error), USTs remain v attractive globally so can still have net stable to lower long end as reasls rally more than breakevens. there is a also a nagging concern that core fomc is rightly concerned around global risks and knock on risks to US and since there is an asymmetry to what policy can do -- the old type 2 error risk （接受原假设的错误，和同事掰驰了很久）-- then net this can still keep long end well anchored. 
 
Note she is nolw going out of her way of talking up policy options -- qe if needed -- not many people ever thought that would be back in the playbook. Dollar and central bank liquidity is still critical and driving dollar lower for a more stable commodity price outlook seems to  be the subtle intent. a complete rebuttal of the former "consensus" vieww that fed could tighten becos others were easing!

6.Beyond her dovish leanings and no sign that she is trying to retreat from the dovish post-FOMC Q&A, the most interesting conclusion from the Yellen speech is her full  embrace of the bond vigilantes.                                                                                                                       She repeats herself a few times in noting that one reason the tightening in financial conditions has not hurt growth expectations materially is because rates have come down, essentially validating the bond market response.   She ends her speech by saying:   "Financial market participants appear to recognize the FOMC's data-dependent approach because incoming data surprises typically induce changes in market expectations about the likely future path of policy, resulting in movements in bond yields that act to buffer the economy from shocks. This mechanism serves as an important "automatic stabilizer" for the economy. As I have already noted, the decline in market expectations since December for the future path of the federal funds rate and accompanying downward pressure on long-term interest rates have helped to offset the contractionary effects of somewhat less favorable financial conditions and slower foreign growth. In addition, the public's expectation that the Fed will respond to economic disturbances in a predictable manner to reduce or offset their potential harmful effects means that the public is apt to react less adversely to such shocks--a response which serves to stabilize the expectations underpinning hiring and spending decisions.  Such a stabilizing effect is one consequence of effective communication by the FOMC about its outlook for the economy and how, based on that outlook, policy is expected to evolve to achieve our economic objectives."
 
7.From: Greenlaw, David (FID) 
 
I thought Alan Blinder and Glenn Hubbard posed some great questions to Yellen during the Q&A session (in stark contrast to the Congressman and Senators who cross examined Yellen during her testimony on Capitol Hill a few weeks ago).  A transcript should be available soon and I will circulate.  There was a lot of ground covered but the most important takeaways for me were:
1)  A weaker global growth outlook helps to explain the shift in the dots from Dec to Mar.
2)  Yellen claims that the Fed's reaction function hasn't changed but she seems to want to broadly define the reaction function in a way that makes the concept almost irrelevant.
3)   She tried to make the case for an eventual rebound in structural productivity growth but her arguments did not seem persuasive.  She also appeared to be stumped by the notion that the Fed's 2% estimate for real potential GDP implies a productivity growth assumption near +1.7% (the Fed's lack of awareness surrounding the slowing in population growth remains baffling to me). 
4)  When asked about the Fed's options if the US enters recession during the next few years, she reiterated some of the points contained in her prepared text involving QE and policy guidance then went on to talk about the important role that fiscal policy could play in such a  scenario.   
In the speech, Yellen also opens up the possibility that NAIRU（non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment,The specific level of unemployment that exists in an economy that does not cause inflation to increase. The non-accelerating rate of unemployment (NAIRU) often represents an equilibrium between the state of the economy and the labor market. NAIRU is also sometimes referred as a "long-run Phillips curve".） is below the SEP median estimate of 4.8%.  This is a topic that many Fed officials have been reluctant to tackle in their public statements -- and Yellen's carefully worded phrasing (along with the fact that the reference appears in a footnote!) reflects this sensitivity.  The gap between NAIRU and the unemployment rate can be an important determinant of whether Fed policy is behind the curve.  For some time now, my own view has been that NAIRU is currently closer to 4.0% than 5.0%.  Yellen may not yet be that extreme but to the extent she is starting to move in my direction it would imply a lower for longer policy path.  
8. Another risk to the inflation forecast, although one that has not changed appreciably since the turn of the year, is that the Committee may have overestimated the longer-run rate of unemployment consistent with inflation stabilizing at 2 percent. Currently, the median of FOMC participants' estimates of this rate is 4.8 percent. However, this longer-run rate cannot be estimated precisely, and so it could be appreciably higher or lower--although given low readings on wages in recent years, I think the latter possibility is more likely than the former. If so, a lower level of unemployment might be needed to fully eliminate slack in the labor market, drive faster wage growth, and return inflation to our 2 percent objective."_如果是这样，今后nfp之夜除了不低于150k外，ue不低于4.5，都不会有惊喜
The tone of the prepared text tilts quite dovish.  Here are some key excerpts -- 
On rate hikes and policy normalization:
     "Given the risks to the outlook, I consider it appropriate for the Committee to proceed cautiously in adjusting policy. This caution is especially warranted because, with the federal funds rate so low, the FOMC's ability to use conventional monetary policy to respond to economic disturbances is asymmetric.
If economic conditions were to strengthen considerably more than currently expected, the FOMC could readily raise its target range for the federal funds rate to stabilize the economy. By contrast, if the expansion was to falter or if inflation was to remain stubbornly low, the FOMC would be able to provide only a modest degree of additional stimulus by cutting the federal funds rate back to near zero.
     "One must be careful, however, not to overstate the asymmetries affecting monetary policy at the moment. Even if the federal funds rate were to return to near zero, the FOMC would still have considerable scope to provide additional accommodation. In particular, we could use the approaches that we and other central banks successfully employed in the wake of the financial crisis to put additional downward pressure on long-term interest rates and so support the economy - specifically, forward guidance about the future path of the federal funds rate and increases in the size or duration of our holdings of long-term securities.
     "While these tools may entail some risks and costs that do not apply to the federal funds rate, we used them effectively to strengthen the recovery from the Great Recession, and we would do so again if needed.
     "Of course, economic conditions may evolve quite differently than anticipated in the baseline outlook, both in the near term and over the longer run. If so, as I emphasized earlier, the FOMC will adjust monetary policy as warranted. As our March decision and the latest revisions to the Summary of Economic Projections demonstrate, the Committee has not embarked on a preset course of tightening. Rather, our actions are data dependent, and the FOMC will adjust policy as needed to achieve its dual objectives."

4.US Daily Economic Notes - What will Yellen say? 28 March 2016 (1 page/ 224 kb)
Commentary for Tuesday: Fed Chair Yellen speaks before the Economics Club of New York this morning. Market participants will pay close attention given the surprising hawkishness of recent commentary from some of the regional Fed presidents. Over the past week and a half, comments from St. Louis Fed President Bullard (voter), Richmond's Lacker (non-voter), Atlanta's Lockhart (non-voter), and San Francisco's Williams (non-voter) have all hinted at the possibility of a rate hike as soon as April or June. Case in point, Bullard noted noted last Thursday that "Fed forecasts suggest that next hike may not be far off." In an interview on April （March）21, Williams, a noted Yellen ally, stated that "All else equal, assuming everything else is basically the same and the data flow continue the way I hope and expect, then April or June would definitely be potential times to have an increase in interest rates." Lockhart, a noted dove, saw sufficient momentum in the economy to justify further rate increases "possibly as early as the meeting scheduled for end of April." In short, the tone of these comments appeared a bit inconsistent with the March FOMC meeting statement and may reflect the fact that policymakers' forecasts were prepared a couple of weeks prior to the March meeting. With financial conditions having eased, partly due to expectations that the Fed would be on hold in March, the individual FOMC member submissions to the Summary of Economic Forecasts, particularly the "dot plot", may have been stale at the time. 
Despite this, we doubt that Yellen will sound overtly hawkish. While she may reiterate as she did in her March press conference that "April remains a live meeting", we doubt that she will send a strong signal that the Fed may hike next month. The earliest the Fed is likely to raise rates again is the June meeting, and we see the probability of such a move as being well below 50%. The futures market is currently discounting slightly less than a 40% chance of a June hike, but this probability would fall if the economic data soften over the next couple of months as we presently project. So what will the Fed Chair say? 
Yellen will likely downplay the recent strength in some of the manufacturing data as well as the modest improvement in some inflation measures. With respect to the latter, recall that Yellen stated in her post-meeting press conference that "We did take note in this statement of the fact that inflation has picked up in recent months. I see some of that as having to do with unusually high inflation readings in categories that tend to be quite volatile, without very much significance for inflation over time…So I'm wary, and haven't yet concluded that we have seen any significant uptick that will be lasting in, for example, core inflation." 
To be sure, Yellen will continue to emphasize the Fed's data dependence. Yesterday's core PCE inflation data showed a one-tenth gain in February, leaving the year-over-year growth rate unchanged at 1.7%, a tenth above the Fed's latest 2016 forecast. However, the February consumption data were soft, and the level of real consumer spending is up only 1.7% annualized relative to Q4. This does not bode well for current-quarter real GDP growth, which we project at just 0.5%. In such a soft demand environment, we question how long the labor market may remain as sturdy as it has been thus far this year. In turn, this Friday's March employment report will be particularly important. We continue to expect a below-consensus 175k gain. If this is the case, it may temper some policymakers' recent enthusiasm for another rate hike in H1. 
 
 
 
5.FX Daily - What follows Yellen speeches, testimonies and press 鹰conferences 28 March 2016 (6 pages/ 356 kb)
If we look at the impact of past Yellen macro speeches since she became Fed Chairperson, we find an underwhelming market impact.
After the Yellen speech we expect the market to remain very reluctant to price in an April hike.  This should still work with the assumption of a long enough period without Fed tightening to foster some moderate follow through to the risk positive environment.   The initial reaction will be restrained in part because participants will wish to avoid getting whipsawed（洗盘） by key data at the end of the week.  
As for the USD, the median currency impact has been minimal for Yellen's past speeches and testimonies.  There is nothing here to suggest USD bulls should be holding their breath in the hope of immediate significant USD support.

2.Fed's Doves Face First Tests--来自RBS
Foreign Exchange | Asia Themes
25 Mar 2016
 
 
 
Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, People’s Bank of China and Bank of Korea policymakers are all likely to be tested by economic releases in the week ahead. US data includes the Fed’s target measure of inflation - personal consumption expenditure prices - in addition to payrolls and ISM. In Japan the Tankan survey (日本短观调查指数)will be published. China’s official and Caixin PMI data will be released and South Korea’s inflation and trade data are due. 
We continue to favour the dollar against Asian and commodity currencies. The Fed is likely to turn more hawkish again in the second quarter of the year. In contrast, the BoJ is set to ease again in April, the PBoC to raise dollar-yuan’s fixings, the BoK to cut interest rates and the Reserve Banks of Australia and New Zealand to consider acting on their easing biases.
This week’s key points for currencies are: 
-        data to test Fed dovishness
-        Tankan key in the week ahead for yen
-        PBoC stays focused on Fed cycle
-        CPI, trade data raises BoK easing risk
-        no firm signal yet for more RBA easing
 
 
1.      Data to test Fed dovishness
·         The March Federal Open Market Committee’s dovish stance - strong concerns still about the global outlook, a median forecast of only two rate rises this year, Fed Chair Yellen’s doubts that recent rises in inflation will be sustained and her willingness to see inflation potentially overshoot the central bank’s 2% target - is likely to face its first test in the week ahead.
·         First, February’s personal consumption expenditure prices will be released. The FOMC’s March Summary of Economic Projections forecast core PCE inflation would end the year at 1.6%y/y. Since December, however, the Fed’s target measure of inflation has already increased from 1.3%y/y to 1.7%y/y. At the same time core CPI inflation has risen to 2.3%y/y. If February’s core PCE series rises by 0.2%m/m, the annual rate will increase to 1.8%y/y in the week ahead. This would reach the FOMC’s median forecast for inflation at the end of 2017.
·         Second, March’s ISM manufacturing survey is published. In October the series fell into contractionary territory below 50.0 as weak global growth and the strong dollar weighed on America’s industrial sector. But after hitting a low of 48.0 in December, the ISM survey has edged back up to 49.5 in February. March’s regional releases have already seen sharply higher prints. The Empire State NY Fed survey rose from -16.6 to 0.6. The Philly Fed index jumped from -2.8 to 12.4 and the Richmond Fed release swung sharply from -4 to 22. March’s ISM survey could thus rise back into expansionary territory above 50.0.
·         Third, March’s employment report will be released. This month’s FOMC forecasts projected unemployment would decline from its current rate of 4.9% to 4.7% by the end of 2016, 4.6% by the end of 2017 and 4.5% by the end of 2018 - all below the FOMC median forecast of a longer-run jobless rate of 4.8%. Payrolls growth above 200k is likely to keep pushing the US economy to full employment. Without strong increases in the participation rate, average hourly earnings are set to rebound from last month’s surprise -0.1%m/m decline.
·         Fourth, the University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey will be published. The survey’s 1 year and 5-10 year inflation expectations prints have rebounded from near record lows of 2.5% to 2.7%. The New York Fed’s Survey of Consumer Expectations also shows a rebound in inflation expectations from series lows. Stronger prints will lower policymakers’ fears about deflation risks.
·         Ahead of the data releases, FOMC members have been taking a more hawkish line compared to this month Fed’s statement and forecasts.
·         St Louis Fed President Bullard - an FOMC voter this year - said on Bloomberg TV that this year ‘I didn’t want to be raising rates further in an environment where we had declining inflation expectations’. But since mid-February, ‘they have bounced back up…..so that is making me feel better. We are moving in the right direction.’ 
·         Bullard also said there was a ‘credible case’ for considering a rate hike this month. He agreed the April 26-27 FOMC was a ‘live’ meeting though he noted ‘there isn’t that much data between the March meeting and the April meeting. So I don’t know where the committee will come out’ and he said he wanted to stop contributing to the Fed’s ‘dot-plot’ of interest rate forecasts. In a subsequent speech he said the Fed’s new forecasts suggests the next rate hike may not be far off as the downgrades to the central bank’s projections this month were ‘relatively minor’.
·         San Francisco Fed President Williams - a non-voting FOMC member this year - also observed rates could be increased in April or at the June FOMC meeting. He said to Market News, ‘assuming everything else is basically the same and the data flow continues the way I hope and expect, then April or June would definitely be potential times to have an increase in interest rates.’
·         Similarly, Atlanta Fed President Lockhart - another non-voting FOMC member this year - said, ‘in my opinion, there is sufficient momentum evidenced by the economic data to justify a further step at one of the coming meetings….possibly as early as the meeting scheduled for end of April.’
·         Philadelphia Fed President Harker - a non-voting FOMC participant this year – was more forceful saying there was a strong case the Fed needs to continue raising interest rates and said he would rather see the central bank increase rates more than twice this year. Only the dovish Chicago Fed President Evans said March’s projected rate tightening path of two rate rises was ‘a pretty good setting’.
·         This week’s Fed speeches have given the dollar renewed support pushing the yen back to 113, the Australian dollar lower to 0.75 and the Korean won around 1170 versus the greenback. The People’s Bank of China has also increased the dollar-yuan’s fixing rate to a three week high of 6.52. None of the Fed’s senior leadership - Chair Yellen, Vice Chair Fischer and NY Fed President Dudley - have spoken since this month’s FOMC meeting and almost all central bank speakers this week have been non-voters. But the greenback is likely to gain further support in the week ahead as US data challenges the Fed’s dovish turn this month.
·         The week ahead sees Chair Yellen speak at the Economic Club of New York and take Q+A afterwards. New York Fed President Dudley also speaks. The Fed’s senior leaders are likely to defend the dovish stance of the March FOMC statement and Yellen is also likely to defend her cautious view about inflation rises. This will counter but not fully reverse dollar strength in the week ahead from firm US data releases.
 
 
2.     Tankan key in the week ahead for yen
·         We expect dollar-yen is set to trade higher again from its current 110-115 range to a higher 115-120 range in Q2’16 as financial year end finishes, the Federal Reserve turns less dovish at its April 26-27 meeting and the Bank of Japan eases policy again at its April 28 meeting. 
·         First, Japanese investors have been hedging overseas assets since the yen’s sharp rally from 121 to 111 last month against the dollar. Hedging activity, however, is likely to tail off as the current financial year ends in March. Further, the new financial year is likely to result in stronger portfolio outflows as domestic investors allocate new funds to overseas markets.
·         Second, the BoJ is mounting a robust defence of its new negative interest rate stance. Deputy Governor Nakaso - a career central bank official and widely respected within the institution - said at an event in Sweden that the BoJ could lower rates further and central banks must be prepared to meet new challenges.
 
3.     PBoC stays focused on Fed cycle
·         In the week ahead China’s official and Caixin PMI data will be released. The manufacturing prints are likely to stay in contractionary territory below 50. The weakness of China’s industrial sector is keeping monetary policy on an easing bias. But exchange rate policy still appears to be driven by the People’s Bank of China’s view of the Fed’s hiking cycle and its desire to counter capital outflows.
·         This week an official in the central bank’s State Administration of Foreign Exchange - Wang Yungui – gave a briefing in Beijing. Wang said that capital outflows had eased significantly recently as the speed of foreign exchange buying by individuals and corporates had slowed down. But he warned that Fed rate hikes will lead to further capital outflows and add pressure to the management of the yuan.
·         Wang said that China had thus made plans to deal with the next Fed rate hike and one option would be to consider introducing a ‘Tobin’ tax on foreign exchange transactions.
·         A Tobin tax appears unlikely in the near term while China still has $3.2trn of foreign exchange reserves to defend the yuan. But it’s introduction would be a sign the authorities’ position may be weaker than it appears. The PBoC still hasn’t disclosed the full extent of its forwards book. The Wall Street Journal reported the IMF was pressing the central bank to release data but this was denied by the Fund. Dollar-yuan forward sales may have been in the order of several hundred billions of dollars since August’s devaluation. This would imply the PBoC’s actual FX reserves are much less than its reported $3.2trn of spot holdings.
·         This week the PBoC raised the onshore dollar-yuan’s daily fixing rate (CNY) to a three week high of 6.5223. Currency markets continue to track the yuan’s value against the central bank’s new trade weighted index. The currency has slipped by around 2% against the China Foreign Exchange Trading System (CFETS) basket. But Wang’s comments show the authorities in practise remain focused on the dollar-yuan exchange rate and how the Fed’s tightening cycle will lead to renewed dollar demand in China.
·         Following the greenback’s FOMC-induced weakness, the PBoC has now raised the dollar-yuan fixing rate from a three month low of 6.4628 last week to 6.5223 on Friday. The high so far since August’s devaluation has been 6.5646 on January 7. 
·         We continue to see the PBoC raising its dollar-yuan fixing rates steadily higher towards 7.00 in Q2’16 as the Fed turns more hawkish and raises rates again by June. This would mirror the rise in the fixings from 6.1162 to 6.4085 in August ahead of the Fed’s anticipated first rate hike in September and the increase from 6.3154 to 6.5646 over year end when the Fed did raise rates in December. We thus continue to be bullish on dollar-yuan.
 
 
4.     CPI, trade data raises BoK easing risk
·         This week the Central Bank of China in Taipei cut its benchmark interest rate again by 12.5bps to 1.50%. The CBC warned that foreign inflows had recently been strong amid low interest rates abroad while Taiwan’s negative output gap had continued to widen.
·         The Bank of Korea is also likely to consider cutting interest rates from 1.50% in Q2’16 as its economy faces the same headwinds as Taiwan’s particularly weak global demand. S. Korea’s final Q4’15 GDP print on Friday showed growth of 3.1%y/y. But the data was flattered by a 1%q/q increase in government spending as the authorities loosened fiscal policy after last year’s Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak. 
·         In the week ahead March CPI and trade data will be released. Inflation is likely to remain well below the central bank’s 2% target for 2016-2018 and exports are also likely to have contracted by double digits y/y again. With the BoJ’s policy rate lowered to -0.10% in January and the CBC cutting its benchmark rate to 1.50%, the BoK is at risk of facing widening interest rate differentials with its major trading countries if it doesn’t move to lower rates in Q2’16.
·         The risk of further BoK easing, renewed Fed tightening plus a weaker yuan will help push dollar-won back up from current levels around 1170 to a 1200-1300 range over the next few months.
 
 
3.US Daily Economic Notes - What you need to know for the week ahead 25 March 2016 (1 page/ 224 kb)
Commentary for Monday: The economic data docket is crowded this week, with the main highlights being Fed Chair Yellen's speech before the NY Economic Club on Tuesday and the March employment report, released on Friday. With respect to Yellen, comments from Fed policymakers last week were moderately more hawkish than what the March meeting statement had implied. Case in point, San Francisco Fed President Williams (non-voter), a close Yellen ally, indicated that the next rate hike could come as soon as April or June. This was reiterated by Atlanta Fed President Lockhart (non-voter), a noted dove, who saw sufficient momentum in the economy to justify further rate increases "possibly as early as the meeting scheduled for end of April". In turn, the tone of Yellen's speech could be more upbeat than her March 16 post-FOMC press conference. 
To be sure, Yellen will reiterate that the Fed remains very much "data dependent". In turn, Friday's employment report will be the key focus this week. We expect a below-consensus +175k gain for March payrolls and a one-tenth increase in the unemployment rate to 5.0%. Wednesday's ADP employment survey (175k forecast vs. 214k previously) may influence expectations going into Friday. Average hourly earnings (+0.1% vs. -0.1%) and hours worked (34.5 vs. 34.4) are equally as important for income growth. With respect to the former, last month's decline in AHEs was unusual, and there is the potential for payback in March. However, it would take at least a 0.3% gain to keep the year-over-year growth rate steady at 2.2%, which would still be moderately below the 2.6% post-recession peak reached last December. 
This morning's personal income and consumption data should show only slight gains in February. Income growth will be muted by the aforementioned drop in AHEs and hours. February consumption should reflect weakness in retail sales as well as some slowing in utilities expenditures on the services side. At the same time, weak exports may cause the advance goods trade balance to widen further. Soft demand abroad and elevated inventory levels at home may limit the extent of any potential improvement in the manufacturing sector. Given the better-than-expected readings from the regional Fed PMIs, we expect modest gains in the Chicago PMI (50.0 vs. 47.6) and manufacturing ISM (50.0 vs. 49.5) surveys, released Thursday and Friday, respectively. However, the outlook for capital spending and production remains soft. In fact, last week, we learned that core durable goods orders fell -1.8% in February, which does not bode well for capex. 
Given the weakness in other sectors of the economy such as manufacturing and capital spending, the consumer will have to do the yeoman(自耕农)'s work with respect to GDP growth. Tuesday's consumer confidence (91.0 vs. 92.2) figures are expected to slip slightly, similar what the final U. of Michigan sentiment (90.0 vs. 91.7) data should show on Friday. While these two gauges of consumer attitudes should remain at relatively healthy levels, they have been trending downward since peaking in January 2015. Friday's unit motor vehicle sales (17.2 million vs. 17.4 million) will provide more concrete data on how consumer activity is progressing in the current quarter.

Article No. 238
2016032 晴，星期日，空气质量优
2016-03-27 随手札记

EI-Elain是我非常喜欢的一位彭博专栏作家，这个短文比较有意思，虽然没有解决方案
Why Investors FaceRoller-Coaster Markets: Mohamed A. El-Erian Volatility reflects the tug of war between a weakening global economy andcentral bank liquidity infusions. 
By Mohamed A. El-Erian
(Bloomberg View) --
Risk assets such as stocks, corporate bonds and bank loanshave been trading in a wide and volatile range, taking investors on aroller-coaster ride up and down, including most recently a rally of about 10percent in U.S. equity markets.
QuickTake: QuickTake The ECB's Dilemma
This phenomenon is likely to continue in the short-term, sohere are eight characteristics of this financial environment: 1.       Pronounced fluctuationswithin the trading range reflect primarily the tug of war between a weakeningglobal economy and continuing liquidity injections from central banks andcorporate balance sheets. 2.       The fluctuations areaccentuated by patchy market liquidity: On the way up, prices overshoot levelswarranted by the exceptional funding that markets obtain. That backing includesthe monetary stimulus programs of central banks (notably the Bank of Japan, theEuropean Central Bank and the People’s Bank of China), as well as thedeployment of corporate cash for share repurchases, higher dividend payouts andmergers and acquisitions. On the way down, prices fall below what wouldotherwise prevail on the basis of fundamentals. 3.       This behavior is likely tocontinue in the short-term, shifting the opportunities for highermonthly/quarterly returns away from conventional strategic long-term portfoliopositioning and toward more short-term trading and volatility trades. 4.       Because today's markets areheavily influenced by the direct and indirect involvement of central banks,correlations among asset classes are less reliable, weakening the effectivenessof risk mitigation through traditional portfolio diversification. Although itremains necessary, such diversification is no longer sufficient to ensureeffective risk management. Accordingly, fluctuating cash levels not onlyprovide agility for tactical positioning but also act as a risk mitigator. 5.       Over time, the trading rangeis more likely to get wider than smaller. As this occurs, the probability ofeither a policy mistake or a market accident will increase. And even absentthese two disruptive developments, the range itself will become increasinglyfragile as its gets wider. 6.       It is too early to determinewith certainty whether the eventual dismantling of the trading range willresult in an upward or downward breakout. Much will depend on the policyresponses in the systemically important economies in Asia, Europe and NorthAmerica. 7.       A constructive policyresponse would require a transition from the excessive reliance on centralbanks to a set of policies that reinvigorates growth engines, deals withaggregate demand imbalances, addresses excessive pockets of indebtedness andmakes progress in completing regional and global economic/financialarchitectures (which also would counter the rise of political extremes on bothsides of the Atlantic). If this approach were successful, range-bound tradingwould yield to genuinely higher financial asset prices that are firmlysupported by strengthening fundamentals. 8.       But the more this policyhandoff is delayed, and the greater the political polarization, the higher theprobability of notably lower markets that, in turn, would risk contaminatingeconomic fundamentals and making the politics even messier.
This column does not necessarily reflect the opinion of theeditorial board or Bloomberg LP and its owners.

20160325  星期五，晴，空气质量优
2016-03-25 随手札记

Alexander Graham Bell,scientist and inventor
 
 
1.多重因素共振之下，欧洲股市果然走低了，但是美股低开后一波又一波居然拉红了。唯一值得欣慰的是t和xau不再分歧，都跌了点儿。原油在触及38.5低点之后很快拉起，或许是个原因吧。Spx这么黏糊，这种行情真是鸡肋啊，就像国内债市一样。

Easter day，市场真是安静啊~~强烈要求姆们外币交易员在西方重大节日放假！
 
2.Subject: DB: The next US recession
 
My client conversations at the moment often end up in big picture discussions about central bank actions and where we are going, as illustrated by this question, which came up in a meeting yesterday:
 
We had a crisis in 2009 and central banks printed a lot of money, but where did that money go and why didn't it generate a bigger boost to global growth?
 
A lot of the money printed went to central bank buying of financial assets, so one answer is that central banks have pushed bond prices higher and also stock prices higher, either directly (Japan) or indirectly (US and Europe).
 
In addition, a lot of the money created since 2009 came through increased borrowing in the economy. But the new borrowing since 2009 was not so much done by consumers but instead by corporates, which spent some of their borrowing on buying back their own stock, again leading to higher stock prices.
 
So, the answer to the question is that central bank actions since 2009 have created a significant amount of asset price inflation, both via direct purchases and via low interest rates spurring significant corporate borrowing and ultimately buybacks.
 
To be sure, central bank actions have been helping the global economy but not as much as we would have expected. The main reason is that financial assets in the US are unevenly distributed, see the first two charts below. And in Europe and Japan financial assets are less in the hands of households and more inside institutions, such as pension funds and insurance companies, which don't spend on consumption or capex. As a result, the main reason why central bank money printing has not given a bigger boost to the global economy is that wealth effects have been weak, not only in the US but also in Europe and Japan. In other words, easy monetary policy did not create the good old textbook transmission channel of "low interest rates increase consumer borrowing and hence also GDP". Instead, the main transmission channel has been via higher asset prices, and hence wealth effects.
 
Looking ahead, what can be done next time the US enters a new recession? It is unclear if boosting financial asset prices further is going to help much more, in particular if valuations of stocks and bonds and homes increase so much that investors become skeptical about the implicit expected future cash flow of the underlying asset. So we are left with fiscal policy. It remains unclear if more infrastructure spending is a good idea, see also the third chart. Instead, helicopter money is an option, where a well-designed fiscal expansion is financed by using the central bank balance sheet. But the general answer to "what can be done next time" is that any economic policy, including fiscal policy, which can get money into the hands of people who are going to spend it, would be helpful.
 
As an investment thesis, these issues discussed above are complicated and seem detached from the traditional analysis of fundamentals both from a top-down and bottom-up perspective. As a result, looking at markets today, given how heavily involved central banks are in price setting and given that a lot of predicting markets is currently about second-guessing future policy actions, you cannot really blame investors that they instead decide to trade on something much simpler, namely whether oil prices are going up or down. （央妈严重干预市场，投资者无脑交易。对当下squisshy走势的感慨？）
 
3.Until Yellen Tuesday, two sides can continue to weigh each other out. For all the cries of "Rally over," levels are better than the vibe in market. Bears need either oil collapse or Yellen to sound like "her Fed-speak."（也许是节前，也许是对耶大婶讲话的谨慎，本周二开始市场交易量就开始萎缩了）
 
Good luck with the last one given data like durables and cap-ex today.. TY sold off towards close to finist at 1.90%.. But really after all the hawkish rhetoric from other Fed members, US rates don't really want to sell off（连续多位委员鹰派讲话，而t没怎么跌，可能这就是原因。大胆猜一下，如果耶大婶届时讲话比较鹰派，黄金还能狠狠跌一下）.
 
It seems US rates are trading more with data.
 
And USD with the policy rhetoric. Hence all the "Andy Warhol （超现实pop艺术家，已过世，多部文艺片）moments" of Bullard are perhaps giving USD bulls some hope.
 
There are two crowded Macro positions out there.. Long gold.. And to a less extent short GBP.. Post the Brussels spike, gold is trading so so. And GBP wasn't helped by polls today.
 
If you listen to most clients at macro dinners or one on one, GBP should have traded a lot closer to 1.30 then these levels, but In Turkey, CBT didn't cut as aggressive as I thought. Delivered more the consensus 25 bps & that helped TRY.
 
After we enjoy Easter, Yellen speech at the Economics Club will be key.. We also get NFP next week.
 
Constructive EM..
 
Ride it or fade it?
 
This week, there was a lot of excitement that we could go back to "oil lower, USD higher" formula.I am not sure whether wishes will come true. Yellen may make them frustrated again.Japan trade is too forgotten. Perhaps an orange sign（sure ，fy尾声了）.
 
Last but not least, RIP Johan Cruyff（克鲁伊夫，好人啊，永远的14号）.. Cool. Intelligent. Graceful. Confident. Forever an inspiration.
 
 
5.FX Daily - How long and wrong is Yen positioning 24 March 2016 (4 pages/ 369 kb)
There is an active debate on the current state of JPY positioning.   The IMM net non-commercial positioning showed some minor trimming of long yen exposure as of Tuesday March15th, but the JPY longs were still near historical highs.     Against this and suggestive of much more restrained long yen positions since the last, possibly dated CFTC snapshot is:  i)  The risk reversals (3m riskies) and butterflies (10 delta with sign reversed ) in Figure 1 are more consistent with near flat CFTC non-commercial positioning.  By the end of Feb, downside USD/JPY strikes were becoming less fashionable, and upside strikes were offering good value, especially once risk appetite variables had turned.  ii) Our CORAX positioning that provides an update through March 22<SUP>nd</SUP> had flipped to close to neutral. In addition, relative to long-term trends, leveraged and corporate flow was flattish, leaving real money long JPY.  A few conclusions:  i) If the derivatives market signals are correct, we should see some sizable trim in CFTC net long yen non-commercial positioning in the next couple of weeks, making positioning a much less scary factor for yen bulls.   ii)  One of the stand-outs of Figure 1, is how USD/JPY followed risk appetite indicators like the S&P until mid-Feb when risk recovered.  Since then USD/JPY's daily correlation with the S&P has remained reasonably high (a 0.54 correlation for levels based data in the last month), but the relationship shows classic statistical drift, because the yen gains more on risk-off days than it loses on risk-on days.  This is an important bullish yen signal. iii)  Figure 2, the seasonality chart, shows how the yen had weakened in each March since 2008, which presumably has some linkage to Japanese fiscal year-end, but also reflects some seasonal risk-on bias.  That the yen is holding its own this March is a bullish JPY statement.   USD/JPY won't run away on the downside  in part because the technical levels that  were resistance in the USD bull run are now acting as downside brakes.   An example is the Y110  level that is now key support.    Nonetheless, the conclusions from the above still favor selling USD/JPY upticks more than buying downticks, especially if CFTC data confirms JPY longs have been at least moderately trimmed. （意思就是非商业多头有所减弱，但还是很强，所以日元上涨概率大于下跌，但实际上非商业头寸单向累积到一定程度往往就要反转了，谁知道呢）

Article No. 240
20160324  星期四，晴，空气质量优
2016-03-24 随手札记

 
He that complies against his will is of his own opinion still.（不得已也是一种本心？）
Samuel Butler,writer
 
1.昨天黄金下跌在意料之中，不过没想到跌这么多。Bullard又不是投票委员，说不想加息，如果通胀预期下调的话。读到这儿，鸽派！接着，fed滞后加息的可能在增加，又是鹰派了！妈蛋，这些委员闲的，闭嘴！下周五日本财年就要翻篇了，到时日元好跌，t会跌，要不要fool‘s day耍耍nfp呢。Spx终于调整了，日本作为美帝忠实地狗腿子也在跌，A股也跌吧，因为我空仓啦！
石油下跌因为高处不胜寒吧，原油和汽油库存一升一跌，怎么解释都行。
新屋报喜，果然是亮点。看看今晚耐消吧
DB交易员认为t的上涨因为节日原因，但bc看来主要是国内外真钱买入。
 
2.Fed方程
1）Fed reaction "function": SPX < 1900 = EASE / SPX > 1900
 < 2000 = HOLD / SPX > 2000 = HIKE                              
2）"Hike at 2000, hold at 1800, cut at 1600."
3.S&P500 driven by fundamentals or central bank money printing?
How will the S&P500 react to the next Fed hike? I continue to get this question in client conversations.
The key to answering this question is to understand to what degree stock prices since 2009 have been driven by fundamentals or by central bank money printing.
The chart below shows that correlations across global stock markets continue to be far above correlations across global PMIs. In other words, global stock markets have in recent years been more synchronized than business cycles across countries, which is likely because of easy monetary policy and low interest rates pushing investors into stock markets despite poor fundamentals. To be sure, an important reason why stocks have increased since 2009 is that we have seen a significant increase in earnings but the fear is that the Fed pushing interest rates higher will force many investors to leave equities and walk back - or run back - the risk spectrum to safer assets, such as cash or core rates.
The bottom line is that I still believe that Fed hikes will not be associated with a correction in the S&P500 but it continues to be a risk that equities may be overvalued as a result of global central bank money printing.
 
4.Alpha Alert – Creating April Fools in March
Yesterday I put out a BBG note suggesting that “The Fed's dilemma could get worse” and that the market’s reaction to the FOMC had reduced policy optionality in a way that the Fed was ‘pushing back on’.   All of Williams, Lockhart, Evans, Harker and now Bullard have tended to affirm that a Q2 hike is very much in play; that the April FOMC is indeed ‘live’; and, even a very dovish Evans is not pushing back on two rate hikes this year.    There is some speculation that the above speakers do not represent Yellen’s own views.   However, the 2016 coalescence of dots around two hikes, suggests she and the majority are very much singing from the same hymn sheet.
The BBG below suggested the Fed will have a tough time lifting April expectations sufficiently to hike without being very explicit about their intentions before the meeting.  The June FOMC meanwhile runs into Brexit issues, and tightening then requires the Fed to take a position that a Brexit vote will not lead to systemic risk issues (a view I favor).  Another factor supporting the Fed not leaving a rate hike until H2, is that the second half of the year is going to get caught in the US election cycle.  Without a particularly compelling story, the Fed will try avoid tightening on November 2nd, six days before the election.  In addition, December tightening is never quite ideal given the run into Xmas spending, although the Dec 2015 hike is but one indication this will not be too much of a restraint.   In any event, to fit two rate hikes in this year, it would be surprising if the Fed really had in mind two hikes in H2, especially given the pending election.
What is important here, is that unlike in the recent past there appears to be a certain comfort among officials that they have now ‘right sized’ their own projections for the funds rate in 2016.   As Bullard suggests the Dec 2015 dot plot with a median four hikes, may have contributed to market instability.   A more confident view of two rate hikes, raises the danger that the next move will still be for the rates market to move rate expectations toward the Fed rather than the other way round.   Of course the Fed needs i) the data to largely comply with their projections; and ii) international events not to intercede and roil markets.
FX implications:
For currencies, the environment has clearly edged a little more USD friendly.  We started the year suggesting that there are three main states of the world:
State 1:  risk Ok, Fed tightens, USD modestly stronger against most currencies.
State 2:  risk-off, probably China led, with G3 sharply stronger vs. EM and commodity FX; and
State 3:  Risk so-so, Fed on hold that is USD negative, with positioning and valuation squeezes.
We expected that a shifting between State 1 or State 2 would tend to dominate.    What is making this year so difficult is we are oscillating across all three States.  In the last month, State 3 has dominated. This risk oscillation probably won’t change, because a more stable risk environment encourages Fed tightening expectations that tend to generate more risk negative environment that slows the Fed.  For now however the better risk environment is now edging us from State 3 back to State 1.
Obviously the natural losers are currencies that are particularly sensitive to the Fed including the CAD and MXN, but also some currencies that have been too ebullient in thinking the good (risk) times are back, including the Aussie.   One last FX conclusion:  the Fed comments work with the idea that the Shanghai G20 meeting may have generated currency cooperation, but nothing approaching currency coordination.   The Fed rates policy will not be subservient to FX policy without crisis like conditions.
5.US Daily Economic Notes - Low nominal growth and strong hiring will put pressure on corporate profits --周五！23 March 2016 (1 page/ 240 kb)
6881/DB_USEconDly_2016-03-23_0900b8c08af011b8.pdf 
Commentary for Thursday and Friday: We do not expect any significant revisions in the "final" release of Q4 2015 real GDP, which was last reported at +1.0%, up from its +0.7% "advance" print. Of course, we should note that these data are not really final as real GDP growth could be revised substantially when the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) releases its annual benchmark revisions in July. Nevertheless, these data are important because they will provide the first snapshot of Q4 2015 economy-wide corporate profits. In Q3, corporate profits declined at a -6.2% annualized pace and were down -5.1% over the previous four quarters. In dollar terms, the slowdown in profits is troubling because they are a leading indicator of economic activity, and their trend suggests that the current expansion is in the latter stages of its cycle. 
Assuming no meaningful revisions to Q4, over the last four quarters, nominal GDP would have increased only 3.0%. This is one of the slowest increases on record during a period in which the economy was neither in nor emerging from recession. In fact, since the end of WW II, the only mid-to-late-cycle period during which nominal GDP grew at less than 3% was Q1-Q2 2013. Admittedly, some of the slowdown in nominal activity is the result of the collapse in energy prices. However, even if we exclude the energy industry from GDP, the recent trend is a bit disconcerting. 
As shown in the chart below, the year-over-year trend in the growth rate of nominal GDP excluding energy slowed over the two quarters ending Q3 2015—the Q4 data are released Friday morning. Our best guess is that the downward momentum in nominal GDP excluding energy persisted through last quarter. In such an environment, we wonder how much longer employment gains can persist at such a strong rate because weak top-down GDP alongside continued job gains implies further constriction of corporate profit margins. With the latter having peaked in Q3 2014 and having historically been a leading indicator of broader economic activity, the pace of job gains should meaningfully slow over the course of this year. This is one reason we expect a below-consensus 175k gain in March nonfarm payrolls, which are released next Friday. 
 
6.Asset Allocation - Can Equities Break The Range?
23 March 2016 (25 pages/ 842 kb)
 
Download the complete report: http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/10863-1568/97956239/0900b8c08aeda63e.pdf<http://pull.db-gmresearch.com/p/10863-1568/97956239/0900b8c08aeda63e.pdf>
 
 
  *   US equities have "gone nowhere" since early 2015, an unusually long range-bound period for a growth asset even as US and global growth continued. There are many competing narratives for why. Most compelling in our read is persistently negative data surprises, for what is now the longest period on record. Data surprises did rise from negative to neutral more than once during the last 15 months, taking equities up to the top of the range. But each time a breakout into a typical positive surprise phase was thwarted by shocks (China in August) and a bout of sharp dollar appreciation (ECB expectations in October).
 
  *   So, as US equities have again been traversing up the range over the last 6 weeks, closely correlated with data surprises, can equities break the range to the upside?
 
  *   A number of indicators point to a turn up in growth. Sentiment and confidence indictors have been lagging the hard data, typical after growth scares; all key hard data remain in their recovery channels; the dollar led the turn down in manufacturing and is pointing to the recovery strengthening; consequently, the spillover to services should reverse;
 
  *   Will better US data raise the dollar and short circuit itself? With FX markets no longer following the lead of the ECB and BOJ, and the dollar having run well ahead of rate differentials, we see the risks of a rapid rise in the dollar as having diminished. The recent depreciation of the dollar also takes the pressure off the RMB with the potential for upside surprises to Chinese growth;
 
  *   Q1 earnings looks set to mark their worst (-7%) growth since 2009. But Q1 should also mark the bottom as the drag from the dollar continues to fade while underlying growth picks up, with earnings growth turning positive by Q3. We expect the market to continue to look through earnings as long as data surprises remain positive.
 
  *   Absent new shocks, a typical positive data surprise phase would see equities break well above the range, though this is unlikely until after the buyback blackout period ends in the third week of April. A recovery in growth should see equities eventually disengage from data surprises. Our demand-supply framework with buybacks continuing at their current pace and a resumption of normal inflows into equities predicts 12% upside by year-end or S&P 500 2300.
 
7.Subject: DOE stats -23 Mar and other thoughts
 
Oil has rallied quite a bit in last 4 weeks, and the rolling prompt (CL1) WTI is close to breaking the 200dma now. Along with the DOE data, I also wanted to add some comments behind this rally, and thoughts about where we stand now. A large part of the selloff in Jan/Feb was linked to global weakness, and thus part of the rally can be attributed to a correction. However, there are other fundamental factors which have helped.
- Supply disruptions: Global supply disruptions have been substantial since mid Feb, and March disruptions stand at almost 2.7mbd. Iraq exports through Ceyhan (600kbd), were offline for almost a month due to an attack on the pipeline, and took away 18mb from global supply. But even after it came back online, other global disruptions increased:
- Venezuela has been exporting almost 550kbd lower since last 12 days. 7 out of 11 loading arms at TAEJ export terminal are malfunctioning. The country is facing chronic power shortage due to low water levels in Guri dam, leading to upgrader outages. This has created further need to import light crude for blending, and Venezuela has been trying to secure imports from US, WAF and Russia. However, given the financial strains, they may have trouble securing enough supplies, and the production is expected to decline further (after -80kbd in Feb).
- Nigeria Forcados terminal has been under a force majeure since 21 Feb, due to a pipeline bombing linked to the terminal and has been exporting 250kbd lower. The disruption is expected to last till mid May now.
- Iraq exports through Turkey are lower by 150kbd even after the pipeline flow was restored, since Baghdad government stopped flows from Kirkuk field to renegotiate revenue sharing. Further, the entire pipeline flow (600kbd) was stopped yesterday due to a theft, but is expected to resume today. However, this highlights the increasing frequency of disruptions in the infrastructure.
- Colombia is facing increasing attacks on oil infra as well. The 210kbd Cano Limon-Covenas pipeline was attacked this month after the 85kbd Tansandino pipeline last month. This has led to lower exports and delayed loadings, although further details have been kept confidential.
- Even Libya, which already has substantial disruptions, has been exporting 100kbd lower following further outages.
- Declining production: Non-opec production is seeing accelerating declines as lower capex and deferred maintenance bites into output rates. Q/Q decline of 700kbd looks low in my opinion, and real declines should be higher. In US, implied production levels are pointing to 200kbd lower supply compared to reported/estimates. Globally IEA figures point to almost 1.4mbd missing barrels in total stocks (miscellaneous to balance category), of which although some could be attributed to China stock build and floating storage, at least part of this should be revised later citing lower supplies and better than expected demand (similar to 4Q15 400kbd upward revision to demand).
- Persistent Asian demand: After a dismal start to the year, demand numbers for Feb have been coming strong out of China and India. China crude imports for Feb stood at a record high of 8.03mbd, and light ends product imports also surged with gasoline imports strongest since 2008. Indian oil demand also posted a record 4.28mbd, up 0.31mbd y/y. Diesel and Gasoline demand also rose to a record high, with strong manufacturing growth and strong two-wheeler sales.
- US balances: Going by implied production figures, crude supply in US is lower by 700kbd y/y, while refinery runs have been higher by 300-400kbd compared to last year. This has created a supply gap, which needs to be partially filled by increase in imports (and rest through stock draws). The strength in WTI-brent and LLS-Brent, I believe is  indicating the declining production, and incentivizing imports. I expect imports to stay high from here, converging closer to 8mbd, compared to 7.4mbd last year. Cushing has been adding stocks, close to capacity now (barring last week's draw). However, the quality of stocks is coming into question again. With the increasing NGL/condensate production, while decline in conventional production, some reports are indicating only 30% on-spec material in Cushing. This could keep WTI grade elevated, even as stocks flirt with capacity.
- Production freeze: After canceling the March meeting (which wasn't confirmed), an OPEC/non-OPEC meeting has been scheduled for 17th April in Doha and invitations are being sent out. Iran will be attending the meeting, but will not participate in a freeze. Russia and Saudi have expressed willingness to agree on a freeze even without Iran, and Iraq has also confirmed that it will attend the meeting. This is a significant change in stance, compared to most members stating they won't participated unless Iran does so too. Even though a production freeze doesn't impact the balances materially, it limits the ability of OPEC to increase production further (even though it wasn't expected ex-Iran anyways), and adds some comfort in the market while introducing a floor to prices. Also, it means that Saudi won't be increasing production to meet summer cooling demand, which has historically been in 200-300kbd range.
- Spreads: Both WTI and Brent spreads have rallied along with flat price, flattening the backend curve substantially. Cal17 futures have been under pressure as producer hedging picked up around $45 range. Brent spreads found an elevated floor, as turnaround season approached an end, and tanker rates collapsed bringing down floating storage cost from 110-120c to 80c per month. However, spreads rallying above -40c for summer season look a bit rich as they indicate very tight supply in short term, which is unlikely to materialize (unless we see a big OPEC cut!).
 
DOE comments
- Overall looks marginally bearish, with crude stocks building 9.36mb, and disty stocks adding 920kb. However, most of the stock build can be attributed to jump in imports (with USGC arb open) and lower refinery run. Last year crude built 8.17mb for the same week, to put things in perspective. Gasoline had a strong draw of 4.64mb, and total product stocks declined 2.43mb, implying 143kbd jump in product demand.
- Imports increased by 691kbd, with most of the increase coming from Venezuela (+629), Nigeria (+251) and Saudi (+140). Imports from Venezuela may decline in coming weeks due to the disruption at their export terminal.
- Implied production increased by 283kbd, bringing 4w average to 9.04mbd, close to reported production. L48 reported production continued to decline at 20kbd
What's bullish
- Cushing had a 1.26mb draw, compared to an expected small draw
- Gasoline drew 4.64mb, compared to 2.01mb draw last year for this week
- Total products had 2.43mb draw, against 2.4mb build last year. Product demand increased 143kbd
- Reported production declined 30kbd, with Lower 48 declining 20kbd
What's bearish
- Crude stocks build 9.36mb, in line with last year, but a bit high if we factor in the y/y production decline
- Imports jumped 690kbd, with P1 +386 and P3 +428
- Refinery runs declined 176kbd, as turnarounds picked up. April turnaround are now expected to be lower than March, so runs should start picking up
- Distillate stocks built 920kbd, adding further to the inflated stock levels.

20160323   星期三，天气晴，空气质量优
2016-03-23 随手札记

Attempt the impossible in order to improve your work.
Bette Davis,actress
